{"uri": "2024-07-438479316", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:16:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:16:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://dailyprogress.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/acting-secret-service-boss-cannot-defend-why-roof-in-trump-rally-shooting-wast-secured/article_7518e369-c4aa-566f-8a4a-acd4e4756975.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting was't secured", "body": "Senior officials from the U.S. Secret Service and the FBI testify before the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees about the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump.\n\nWASHINGTON -- The acting director of the Secret Service says he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe is testifying Tuesday before two Senate committees. Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"", "source": {"uri": "dailyprogress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Daily Progress"}, "authors": {"uri": "8250888063", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:06:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:06:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:06:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/jul/30/acting-secret-service-boss-says-he-cannot-defend-w/", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss says he 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting was not secured", "body": "Kevin Wolf / AP\n\nU.S. Secret Service Acting Director Ronald Rowe, left, and FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate are sworn in before they testify before a Joint Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs and Senate Committee on the Judiciary hearing examining the security failures leading to the assassination attempt on Republican presidential candidate former President Donald Trump, Tuesday, July 30, 2024 in Washington.\n\nBy Eric Tucker, Associated Press\n\nTuesday, July 30, 2024 | 7:58 a.m.\n\nWASHINGTON -- The acting director of the Secret Service said Tuesday he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe, testifying before two Senate committees, said he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and \"What I saw made me ashamed.\"\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official said a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said {"uri": "8251053331", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:03:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:03:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:02:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://wgxa.tv/news/local/senate-to-question-new-secret-service-head-acting-director-ronald-rowe-over-donald-trump-assassination-attempt-butler-pennsylvania-kimberly-cheatle-resigned-congressional-hearing-fbi-gunman-thomas-crooks-ar-style-rifle", "title": "Senate to question new Secret Service head over Trump assassination attempt", "body": "WASHINGTON (TND) -- The FBI deputy director, Paul Abbate, shared a possible motive in the Trump assassination attempt during a hearing before Senate lawmakers.\n\nAccording to Abbate, investigators recently uncovered a social media account they believe is associated with 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks.\n\nCrooks, the would-be assassin, had over 700 comments from an account made in a 2019 and 2020 timeframe that reflected antisemitic and anti-immigration themes.\n\nAbbatte said the comments \"espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature.\"\n\nHe pointed out to lawmakers that the investigative team on the Butler, Pennsylvania rally shooting are still \"working to verify the [social media] account.\"\n\n\"We believe it important to share and noted today, particularly given the general absence of other information to date from social media and other sources of information that reflect on the shooter's potential, motive, and mindset,\" said Abbatte.\n\nAlso, testifying before lawmakers, is the U.S. Secret Service Acting Director Ronald Rowe.\n\nIn Rowe's opening statement, he testified that he \"cannot defend\" why the roof where Crooks shot from \"was not better secured.\"\n\nRowe, a 25-year veteran with the agency, said he visited the site and got on the roof. He was \"ashamed\" at what he saw.\n\n\"I laid in a prone position to evaluate his [Crooks] line of sight. What I saw made me ashamed,\"said Rowe.\n\nThe testimony from Rowe amounted to the most detailed catalogue to date of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with the Secret Service boss accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also criticizing local law enforcement for not sharing information that a gunman had been spotted on a roof near the rally site in the minutes before the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nThat information, he said, had been kept \"siloed\" among the local officers on the scene.\n\n\"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have,\" Rowe said. \"We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nRowe became acting director of the Secret Service last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers of both major political parties and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the Trump rally shooting.\n\nSen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing came a day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment. Trump, who appeared at events over the next few days with a bandage on his right ear, said he expects the interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nMost of the questions Tuesday were expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt Cheatle's hearing last week, she said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"", "source": {"uri": "wgxa.tv", "dataType": "news", "title": "WGXA"}, "authors": [{"uri": Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed. The FBI's No. 2 official is also testifying.\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said {"uri": "2024-07-438605910", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:21:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:21:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:51:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/acting-secret-service-director-says-hes-ashamed-after-the-trump-assassination-attempt/article_13d7e1a0-d2d5-5cca-8ee0-0110b039ea0e.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service director says he's 'ashamed' after the Trump assassination attempt", "body": "Senate Homeland Security Ranking Member Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., right, asks questions of U.S. Secret Service Acting Director Ronald Rowe and FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate during a Joint Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs and Senate Committee on the Judiciary hearing examining the security failures leading to the assassination attempt on Republican presidential candidate former President Donald Trump, Tuesday, July 30, 2024 in Washington.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers on Tuesday that he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured, faulting local law enforcement for not circulating urgent information ahead of the shooting and for not adequately protecting the scene.\n\nHe also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and said, \"What I saw made me ashamed.\" He said that the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalogue to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also repeatedly lacing into local law enforcement for not sharing information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been spotted on a roof near the rally site in the minutes before the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots, less than 150 yards (135 meters) from the rally stage where Trump was speaking.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nTrump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before the gunman was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue. It also suggested that Rowe, with ready and detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers from both major political parties after responses that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nMuch of Tuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees focused on what Rowe suggested was inadequate information received by Secret Service personnel in the hour before the shooting, including that Crooks had been spotted on the roof.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers had spotted a suspicious-looking man pacing near the metal detectors and circulated but ultimately lost track of Crooks before he scaled the roof of a building at AGR International Inc. Shortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take responsibility.\n\n\"Isn't it the fact that the former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress, but he assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nSen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nOn Monday, the FBI revealed that Crooks had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. Trump, who appeared at events in the days after the shooting with a bandage on his right ear, said he expects the interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nAt Cheatle's hearing last week, she said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds {"uri": "8250841432", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:36:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:36:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:35:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.brandonsun.com/world/2024/07/30/acting-secret-service-boss-says-he-cannot-defend-why-roof-in-trump-rally-shooting-was-not-secured", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss says he 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting was not secured", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- The acting director of the Secret Service says he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe is testifying Tuesday before two Senate committees. Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official is also testifying.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Senate lawmakers are expected Tuesday to grill the acting director of the Secret Service about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRonald Rowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nRowe will be joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"", "source": {"uri": "brandonsun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brandon Sun"}, "authors": [], "concepts": Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. {"uri": "8250856532", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:45:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:45:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:44:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.stripes.com/theaters/us/2024-07-30/secret-service-boss-cannot-defend-trump-rally-shooting-14661411.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss says he 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting was not secured", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The acting director of the Secret Service says he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe is testifying Tuesday before two Senate committees. Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official is also testifying.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nRowe will be joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"", "source": {"uri": "stripes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Stars and Stripes"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8250977622", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:08:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:08:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:07:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://omaha.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/acting-secret-service-boss-cannot-defend-why-roof-in-trump-rally-shooting-wasnt-secured/article_8404d75a-b80e-5d53-a0ae-0c1e008a293b.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting wasn't secured", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The acting director of the Secret Service says he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe is testifying Tuesday before two Senate committees. Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said {"uri": "8250865262", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:52:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:52:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:51:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/politics/acting-secret-service-boss-says-he-cannot-defend-why-roof-in-trump-rally-shooting-was-not-secured/", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss says he 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting was not secured - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- The acting director of the Secret Service says he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe is testifying Tuesday before two Senate committees. Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-07-438461056", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:01:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:01:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T04:04:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.aol.com/news/secret-fbi-officials-testify-trump-040446745.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss says he 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting was not secured", "body": "Acting Secret Service boss says he 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting was not secured\n\nERIC TUCKER\n\nJuly 30, 2024 at 4:52 PM\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- The acting director of the Secret Service said Tuesday he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe, testifying before two Senate committees, said recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and \"What I saw made me ashamed.\"\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official said a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": [{"uri": "eric_tucker@aol.com", Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official is also testifying.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below:\n\nSenate lawmakers are expected Tuesday to grill the acting director of the Secret Service about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRonald Rowe became acting director of the agency last week after his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers from both parties and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nRowe will be joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim; the bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut the bulk of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service countersniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\nGet Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay up-to-date on the latest in local and national {"uri": "2024-07-438502471", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:36:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:36:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T04:04:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.trentonian.com/2024/07/30/acting-secret-service-boss-says-he-cannot-defend-why-roof-in-trump-rally-shooting-was-not-secured/", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss says he 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting was not secured", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- The acting director of the Secret Service said Tuesday he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe, testifying before two Senate committees, said recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and \"What I saw made me ashamed.\"\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official said a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"", "source": {"uri": "trentonian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Trentonian"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438517408", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:51:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:51:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T04:04:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.oneidadispatch.com/2024/07/30/acting-secret-service-boss-says-he-cannot-defend-why-roof-in-trump-rally-shooting-was-unsecured/", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss says he 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting was unsecured", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers on Tuesday that he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured, faulting local law enforcement for not circulating vital information to federal authorities.\n\nRonald Rowe testified that he recently visited the shooting site and said, \"What I saw made me ashamed.\"\n\nThe testimony from Rowe amounted to the most detailed catalogue to date of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with the Secret Service boss accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also criticizing local law enforcement for not sharing information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been spotted on a roof near the rally site in the minutes before the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nThat information, he said, had been kept \"siloed\" among the local officers on the scene.\n\n\"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have,\" Rowe said. \"We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nRowe became acting director of the Secret Service last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers of both major political parties and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the Trump rally shooting.\n\nSen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing came a day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment. Trump, who appeared at events over the next few days with a bandage on his right ear, said he expects the interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nMost of the questions Tuesday were expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt Cheatle's hearing last week, she said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"", "source": {"uri": "oneidadispatch.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Oneida Dispatch"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8250859997", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:48:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:48:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:47:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/07/30/acting-secret-service-boss-says-he-cannot-defend-why-roof-in-trump-rally-shooting-was-not-secured/", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss says he 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting was not secured - Medicine Hat News", "body": "Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, listens as U.S. Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle testifies before the House Oversight and Accountability Committee about the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump at a campaign event in Pennsylvania, at the Capitol in Washington, Monday, July 22, 2024. (AP Photo/Rod Lamkey, Jr.)WASHINGTON (AP) - The acting director of the Secret Service says he \"cannot defend\"\u009d why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured. Ronald Rowe is testifying Tuesday before two Senate committees. Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed. The FBI's No. 2 official is also testifying. Senate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting. Rowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting. Rowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security. \"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\"\u009d said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again. He added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\u009d The hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister. The FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday. But most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania. One rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper. At her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\"\u009d in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\"\u009d in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\"\u009d to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it. Cheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally. Cheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt. In a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police. \"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said. He praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\u009d", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", {"uri": "8250945895", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:46:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:46:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:45:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/07/30/acting-secret-service-boss-says-he-cannot-defend-why-roof-in-trump-rally-shooting-was-unsecured/", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss says he 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting was unsecured - Medicine Hat News", "body": "Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, listens as U.S. Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle testifies before the House Oversight and Accountability Committee about the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump at a campaign event in Pennsylvania, at the Capitol in Washington, Monday, July 22, 2024. (AP Photo/Rod Lamkey, Jr.)WASHINGTON (AP) - The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers on Tuesday that he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured, faulting local law enforcement for not circulating vital information to federal authorities. Ronald Rowe testified that he recently visited the shooting site and said, \"What I saw made me ashamed.\"\u009d The testimony from Rowe amounted to the most detailed catalogue to date of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with the Secret Service boss accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also criticizing local law enforcement for not sharing information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been spotted on a roof near the rally site in the minutes before the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania. That information, he said, had been kept \"siloed\"\u009d among the local officers on the scene. \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have,\" Rowe said. \"We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\u009d The FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school. Rowe became acting director of the Secret Service last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers of both major political parties and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the Trump rally shooting. Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\u009d He added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\u009d The hearing came a day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister. The FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment. Trump, who appeared at events over the next few days with a bandage on his right ear, said he expects the interview to take place on Thursday. Most of the questions Tuesday were expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking. One rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper. At Cheatle's hearing last week, she said the Secret Service had \"failed\"\u009d in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\"\u009d in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\"\u009d to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it. Cheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally. Cheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt. In a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police. \"They didn't speak to each other,\"\u009d he said. He praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\u009d", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com",
