{"uri": "8251179235", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:45:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:45:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:44:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/trump-security-was-unaware-of-gunman-until-shots-fired-secret-service/article_81351ce4-9c63-5a72-9467-3b919bd2c7ce.html", "title": "Trump security was unaware of gunman until shots fired: Secret Service", "body": "Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump is evacuated from a rally by Secret Service agents after an assassination attempt in Butler, Pennsylvania, on July 13, 2024\n\nDonald Trump's security detail and a sniper team were not aware there was a gunman on a roof until he opened fire on the former president, the acting Secret Service director said Tuesday.\n\nLocal law enforcement identified the gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, as a \"suspicious person\" about 90 minutes before the July 13 attack at a Trump campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, according to FBI officials.\n\nSince the assassination attempt, questions have been raised about when the Secret Service became aware of the presence of the gunman on the roof of a building that overlooked the campaign event.\n\n\"Based on what I know right now, neither the Secret Service counter-sniper teams nor members of the former president's security detail had any knowledge that there was a man on the AGR roof with a firearm,\" acting Secret Service chief Ronald Rowe told a joint Senate committee.\n\n\"The only thing we had was that locals were working an issue at the three o'clock, which would have been the former president's right-hand side, which is where the shots came from,\" Rowe said.\n\n\"Nothing about man on the roof, nothing about man with a gun,\" he said.\n\nFBI special agent Kevin Rojek said Monday that a police officer was boosted on to the roof by another officer at 6:11 pm.\n\nCrooks pointed his rifle at the officer, who \"immediately dropped to the ground.\"\n\n\"Approximately 25 to 30 seconds after this encounter, the subject fired eight rounds before being successfully neutralized,\" Rojek said.\n\nRowe said Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service sniper \"within 15.5 seconds\" of firing the first shot.\n\nThe Republican presidential candidate was wounded in the right ear, while two rally attendees were injured and a Pennsylvania firefighter was killed.\n\n- 'Ashamed' -\n\nRowe said he \"cannot defend\" why the rooftop where Crooks fired from was not better secured, and said he was \"ashamed\" about the security lapses.\n\nHe said local law enforcement had been tasked with securing the rooftop. \"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" he said.\n\nAsked why Trump was allowed to take the stage, Rowe said Crooks had not been identified as a threat but only as suspicious.\n\n\"We did not have anything beyond suspicious person that was communicated to us,\" he said. \"Suspicion had not risen to the level of threat or imminent harm.\"\n\nRowe said communications failures between local law enforcement and the Secret Service contributed to what he called a \"failure on multiple levels.\"\n\nThe Secret Service had \"technical difficulties\" with its counter-drone capabilities on the day of the attack and they were not \"operational until after five o'clock,\" he said.\n\nCrooks flew a drone near the rally site for 11 minutes about two hours before the attack, according to the FBI.\n\nFBI deputy director Paul Abbate also addressed the committee hearing and said the authorities still have not established a motive.\n\nHe said they have identified a social media account believed to be associated with Crooks.\n\n\"In about the 2019, 2020 timeframe there were over 700 comments posted from this account,\" Abbate said. \"Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect anti-Semitic and anti-immigration themes, to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature.\"\n\nSecret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned last week after acknowledging that the agency had failed in its mission to prevent the assassination attempt.\n\ncl/bjt", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [{"uri": "chris_lefkow@ktbs.com", "name": "Chris Lefkow", "type": {"uri": "8251352560", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:11:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:11:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:10:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/us-secret-service-chief-blames-trump-security-lapse-on-local-police/85475096", "title": "US Secret Service chief blames Trump security lapse on local police", "body": "By Allende Miglietta, David Morgan and Sarah N. Lynch\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) -The U.S. Secret Service's new acting director said on Tuesday that he was \"ashamed\" of a security lapse that led to the July 13 attempted assassination of Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, but blamed the shortfall on local law enforcement.\n\nIn testimony before two Senate committees, Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe said he visited the outdoor rally site in Butler, Pennsylvania, and climbed onto the roof of a nearby building from which 20-year-old Thomas Crooks fired shots that wounded Trump's right ear, killed one rally attendee and wounded two others with an AR-15-style rifle.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe told a joint hearing of the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees. \"As a career law enforcement officer, and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nThe first shooting of a U.S. president or major party candidate in more than four decades was a glaring security lapse that led last week to former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle's resignation under bipartisan congressional pressure.\n\nBut Rowe went on to tell lawmakers that the Secret Service erred by assuming that a local officials would cover the building and its roof, not the Secret Service.\n\nRepublican Senator John Cornyn pushed back on the notion that the responsibility should have been left to others.\n\n\"Isn't that something that Secret Service should have covered, as opposed to delegating it to local law enforcement?\" Cornyn asked.\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe replied. \"I can assure you that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nDemocratic Senator Richard Blumenthal asked Rowe: \"Ultimately, doesn't the buck stop with the Secret Service?\"\n\n\"It stops with us, sir,\" Rowe said. But Rowe added: \"If they'd just held their post and looked left.\"\n\nRowe's comments came days after a local SWAT team assigned to help protect Trump told ABC News that it had no contact with Secret Service agents in charge of security at the rally before the shooting, and that an anticipated face-to-face briefing with Secret Service officials never happened.\n\nRowe said he has already taken steps to prevent similar lapses from occurring amid concerns among both Democrats and Republicans about further political violence as the campaign intensifies ahead of the Nov. 5 U.S. election.\n\nFBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate, who also testified before the panels, said Crooks appears to have posted violent antisemitic and anti-immigration content online as a teenager.\n\nIt is some of the first evidence of Crooks' possible inclination toward extremism and political violence found by investigators, who have yet to identify a motive.\n\nAbbate said investigators found a social media account dating to 2019-2020, when Crooks would have been 15 or 16 years old, adding that the account had posted more than 700 comments.\n\n\"Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes, to espouse political violence, and are described as extreme in nature,\" Abbate told lawmakers.\n\nCrooks flew a drone near the rally site ahead of the shooting, a flight that Secret Service officials failed to notice because a system for detecting drones was not working properly due to problems with the local cellular network, Rowe said.\n\nLawmakers sought to learn why the Secret Service did not delay the rally or prevent Trump from taking the stage, noting that local police saw Crooks with a rangefinder device for measuring distances about an hour before the shooting.\n\nRowe said Crooks was only one among a number of individuals to draw local law enforcement attention, and added that the Secret Service was not informed when local police saw Crooks on the roof with the rife, just before he opened fire.\n\n\"They were in the midst of dealing with a very critical situation and they articulated that over the radio, as I understand it. However, it was never relayed over to us,\" Rowe said.\n\nThe proceedings grew heated when Republican Senator Josh Hawley pushed Rowe to begin expelling agency employees immediately.\n\n\"I will tell you, senator ... that people will be held accountable, and I will do so with integrity and not rush to judgment and let people be unfairly persecuted,\" Rowe told Hawley with a raised voice.\n\n(Reporting by David Morgan, Sarah N. Lynch and Allende Miglietta; Editing by Scott Malone and Will Dunham)", "source": {"uri": "swissinfo.ch", "dataType": "news", "title": "SWI swissinfo.ch"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251345486", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:05:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:05:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:05:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/07/30/nx-s1-5057323/fbi-trump-shooter", "title": "Social media account with extremist comments could be tied to Trump gunman, FBI says", "body": "Ronald Rowe, Secret Service acting director, testifies Tuesday about the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump. Allison Bailey/Middle East Images/AFP via Getty hide caption\n\nThe FBI has found a social media account featuring antisemitic and anti-immigration comments that investigators believe to be associated with the gunman who tried to assassinate former President Donald Trump, a senior bureau official said Tuesday.\n\nFBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate told members of Congress that the account could be linked to the shooter, Thomas Crooks, but he cautioned that officials are still working to verify the account's authenticity.\n\n\"There were over 700 comments posted; some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature,\" Abbate told a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees.\n\nThe note of caution about the account's authenticity stems, in part, from confusion about a gaming account that the FBI had at one point attributed to Crooks but later turned out to be a hoax.\n\nThe details about the account came as lawmakers questioned Abbate and the acting director of the Secret Service about security failures and other details of the July 13 shooting targeting Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, in Butler, Pa. Crooks was able to fire eight shots from the roof of a nearby building; a bullet or bullet fragment struck Trump, killed a person at the rally, and injured two others before Crooks was killed by a Secret Service sniper.\n\nAbbate said the account dates to the 2019-2020 time period, when Crooks would have been 15 or 16 years old. It could provide a glimpse into Crooks' thinking, which has proven elusive as the FBI said the shooter generally had few social contacts and little social media presence. It wasn't clear from Abbate's comment what social media account it was on.\n\nSen. Rick Scott, R-Fla., blamed federal officials for not talking more to the press and providing regular updates on their investigations.\n\n\"You're a black hole. You lose the support of the American public because people don't believe you're being direct with them,\" he said.\n\nIn addition to questions about the shooter, lawmakers also slammed the Secret Service's security gaps. The Secret Service's acting director, Ronald Rowe, said security at the July 13 rally was a failure on multiple levels, and he had implemented changes to security to ensure another shooting doesn't happen again.\n\nRowe said he retraced Crooks' steps on the roof to try to understand how he was able to get a shot at Trump and what went wrong.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe told lawmakers. \"As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nRowe also blamed communication silos between Secret Service agents and local law enforcement. Reports being discussed on a text chain did not get shared with Secret Service agents on the scene: \"Nothing about man on the roof, nothing about man with a gun, none of that information ever made it over our net,\" he told the hearing.\n\nHe said changes to security procedures include using more drones to help detect threats on rooftops, and ensuring every security plan for events is vetted by multiple supervisors.\n\nRowe stepped in to run the Secret Service after the previous director, Kimberly Cheatle, resigned from her job last week after she faced withering criticism from both Democrats and Republicans for not being able to fully answer their questions about the attempted assassination.\n\nSome Republican senators at the hearing made it clear that Cheatle's resignation wasn't enough to assuage their concerns.\n\nSen. Josh Hawley, a Republican from Missouri, urged the agency to fire more people, while Sen. Roger Marshall, R-Kan., accused the Secret Secret of either \"incompetence or some type of a cultural problem\" -- something the acting director disputed.\n\n\"I think you would agree with me that there were multiple individual and institutional failures the day of this assassination attempt,\" Marshall told Rowe.", "source": {"uri": "npr.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "NPR"}, "authors": {"uri": "8250857130", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:46:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:46:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T14:45:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/acting-secret-service-boss-says-he-cannot-defend-why-roof-in-trump-rally-shooting-was/article_26e4d1e3-1ef2-5957-9dba-1619f0d51e17.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss says he 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting was not secured", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- The acting director of the Secret Service says he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe is testifying Tuesday before two Senate committees. Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed. The FBI's No. 2 official is also testifying.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\nRead more on the U.S. Election at thestar.com", {"uri": "8251316902", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:42:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:42:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:41:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "http://sentinelcolorado.com/nation-world/nation/acting-secret-service-director-says-hes-ashamed-after-the-trump-assassination-attempt/", "title": "Acting Secret Service director says he's 'ashamed' after the Trump assassination attempt - Sentinel Colorado", "body": "WASHINGTON | The Secret Service's acting director on Tuesday told lawmakers he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured and said it was regrettable that local law enforcement had not communicated to his agency that a gunman had been spotted on a nearby roof.\n\nRonald Rowe also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and laid down on the roof of the building where shots were fired in order to evaluate the gunman's line of sight during the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed. As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year Secret Service veteran, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured,\" he said.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalog to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also pointedly criticizing local law enforcement for communication breakdowns that resulted in his agency not sharing information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been spotted on the roof of a building less than 150 yards (135 meters) from the rally stage where Trump was speaking.\n\n\"Neither the Secret Service counter sniper teams nor members of the former president's security detail had any knowledge that there was a man on the roof of the building with a firearm,\" Rowe said. \"It is my understanding those personnel were not aware the assailant had a firearm until they heard gunshots.\"\n\nHe said that the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination and a \"failure to challenge our assumptions.\"\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nHe said he had implemented multiple reforms since taking over as acting director last week, including mandating that every event security plan is vetted by multiple experienced supervisors before being implemented, expanding the use of aerial drones to improve visibility of roofs and dedicating more resources to improve communications at events where the Secret Service is operating.\n\nTrump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before the gunman was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue. It also suggested that Rowe, with ready and generally detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers from both major political parties following responses at a congressional hearing that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nTuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees was the latest in a series of congressional sessions dedicated to the law enforcement lapses and missed communications that preceded the shooting.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers had first observed a suspicious-looking man at the rally site more than an hour before the event and circulated that information, including photographs of a man who turned out to be Crooks. But the officers ultimately lost track of Crooks, who was able to scale the roof of a building at AGR International Inc., a supplier of automation equipment for the glass and plastic packaging industry, and fire an estimated eight shots with an AR-15-style rife.\n\nShortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\nEven though text messages among local snipers revealed anxiety about the man, Rowe said the only thing the Secret Service knew at the time of the shooting was that law enforcement was contending with a suspicious-looking man.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take sufficient responsibility.\n\n\"Isn't the fact that a former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be in the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress. He assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nSen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019-2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nAbbate did not identify the social media platform, saying investigators were still trying to definitively determine that it belonged to Crooks. However, he indicated that it was separate from an account on a different platform called Gab that was active in 2021.\n\nThe chief executive of Gab posted on X, formerly known as Twitter, during the Senate hearing that Crooks's presence on that platform was consistent with being \"pro-Biden and in particular pro-Biden's immigration policy.\"\n\nOn Monday, the FBI revealed that Crooks had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister Robert Fico.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim.", "source": {"uri": "sentinelcolorado.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sentinel Colorado"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": deputy grilled in Senate over Trump assassination bid", "body": "The acting director of the Secret Service says he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former US president Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe is testifying on Tuesday before two Senate committees.\n\nMr Rowe says he recently travelled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nThe FBI's number two official is also testifying.\n\nSenate legislators are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Mr Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nMr Rowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by legislators and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nMr Rowe is being joined by FBI deputy director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said senator Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee.\n\n\"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Mr Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim.\n\nThe bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one.\n\nMr Trump said on Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions on Tuesday are expected to be directed at Mr Rowe as legislators demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Mr Trump.\n\nInvestigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 metres (147 yards) from where Mr Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured.\n\nCrooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Ms Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Mr Trump.\n\nShe called the attempt on Mr Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nMs Cheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally.\n\nShe also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nMs Cheatle said she apologised to Mr Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Mr Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good {"uri": "8252164100", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:41:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:41:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:40:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/jul/31/cant-defend-secret-service-chief-testifies/", "title": "Can't defend Secret Service, chief testifies", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers Tuesday that he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured and said it was regrettable that local law enforcement had not alerted his agency before the shooting that an armed subject had been spotted on a nearby roof.\n\nRonald Rowe Jr. also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and laid down on the roof of the building from where shots were fired in order to evaluate the gunman's line of sight during the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pa.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed. As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year Secret Service veteran, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured,\" he said.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalog to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also pointedly criticizing local law enforcement for communication breakdowns that resulted in his agency not receiving information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been seen on the roof of a building less than 450 feet from the rally stage where Trump was speaking.\n\n\"Neither the Secret Service counter sniper teams nor members of the former president's security detail had any knowledge that there was a man on the roof of the building with a firearm,\" Rowe said. \"It is my understanding those personnel were not aware the assailant had a firearm until they heard gunshots.\"\n\nHe said that the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination and a \"failure to challenge our assumptions.\"\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from where Crooks fired shots.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nHe said he had implemented multiple reforms since taking over as acting director last week, including mandating that every event security plan is vetted by multiple experienced supervisors before being implemented, expanding the use of aerial drones to improve visibility of roofs and dedicating more resources to improve communications at events where the Secret Service is operating. He said he's also directed that federal and local counter snipers work together on roofs.\n\nTrump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before the gunman was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue. It also suggested that Rowe, with ready and generally detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers from both major political parties following responses at a congressional hearing that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nMISSED CHANCES\n\nTuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees was the latest in a series of congressional sessions dedicated to the law enforcement lapses and missed communications that preceded the shooting.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers had first observed a suspicious-looking man at the rally site more than an hour before the event and circulated that information, including photographs of a man who turned out to be Crooks. But the officers ultimately lost track of Crooks, who was able to scale the roof of a building at AGR International Inc., a supplier of automation equipment for the glass and plastic packaging industry, and fire an estimated eight shots with an AR-15-style rife.\n\nShortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\nEven though text messages among local snipers revealed anxiety about the man, Rowe said the only thing the Secret Service knew at the time of the shooting was that law enforcement was contending with a suspicious-looking man.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take sufficient responsibility.\n\n\"Isn't the fact that a former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be in the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress. He assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nSouth Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019-2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nAbbate did not identify the social media platform, saying investigators were still trying to definitively determine that it belonged to Crooks. However, he indicated that it was separate from an account on a different platform called Gab that was active in 2021.\n\nThe chief executive of Gab, Andrew Torba, posted on the social media platform X during the Senate hearing that Crooks' presence on that platform was consistent with being \"pro-Biden and in particular pro-Biden's immigration policy.\"\n\nSen. John Kennedy, R-La. meets with FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate, center, and U.S. Secret Service Acting Director Ronald Rowe, left, before they testify before a Joint Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs and Senate Committee on the Judiciary hearing examining the security failures leading to the assassination attempt on Republican presidential candidate former President Donald Trump, Tuesday, July 30, 2024 in Washington. {"uri": "2024-07-437799795", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "04:47:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T04:47:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T04:04:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/secret-service-fbi-officials-to-testify-about-trump-assassination-attempt-in-latest-hearing/article_7b6ef04e-0834-5234-8c58-0226aa1864a0.html", "title": "Secret Service, FBI officials to testify about Trump assassination attempt in latest hearing", "body": "Senate lawmakers are expected to grill the acting director of the Secret Service about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Senate lawmakers are expected Tuesday to grill the acting director of the Secret Service about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRonald Rowe became acting director of the agency last week after his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers from both parties and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nRowe will be joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim; the bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut the bulk of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service countersniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\nMore from this section\n\nInformative Research's Kelly Richards Receives MPA Elite Women Award\n\nRocking Out at a Drug-Free World Art and Music Festival at the Church of Scientology\n\nFix Support Apple Com/iPhone/Restore in 5 Minutes - iOS 18 Supported", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-438925787", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:03:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:03:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:30:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.thenationalherald.com/acting-secret-service-director-says-hes-ashamed-after-the-trump-assassination-attempt/", "title": "Acting Secret Service Director Says He's 'Ashamed' after the Trump Assassination Attempt", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers Tuesday that he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured and said it was regrettable that local law enforcement had not alerted his agency before the shooting that an armed subject had been spotted on a nearby roof.\n\nRonald Rowe Jr. also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and lied down on the roof of the building where shots were fired in order to evaluate the gunman's line of sight during the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed. As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year Secret Service veteran, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured,\" he said.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalog to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also pointedly criticizing local law enforcement for communication breakdowns that resulted in his agency not receiving information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been seen on the roof of a building less than 150 yards (135 meters) from the rally stage where Trump was speaking.\n\n\"Neither the Secret Service counter sniper teams nor members of the former president's security detail had any knowledge that there was a man on the roof of the building with a firearm,\" Rowe said. \"It is my understanding those personnel were not aware the assailant had a firearm until they heard gunshots.\"\n\nHe said that the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination and a \"failure to challenge our assumptions.\"\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nHe said he had implemented multiple reforms since taking over as acting director last week, including mandating that every event security plan is vetted by multiple experienced supervisors before being implemented, expanding the use of aerial drones to improve visibility of roofs, dedicating more resources to improve communications at events where the Secret Service is operating. He said he's also directed that federal and local counter snipers work together on roofs.\n\nTrump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before the gunman was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue. It also suggested that Rowe, with ready and generally detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers from both major political parties following responses at a congressional hearing that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nTuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees was the latest in a series of congressional sessions dedicated to the law enforcement lapses and missed communications that preceded the shooting.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers had first observed a suspicious-looking man at the rally site more than an hour before the event and circulated that information, including photographs of a man who turned out to be Crooks. But the officers ultimately lost track of Crooks, who was able to scale the roof of a building at AGR International Inc., a supplier of automation equipment for the glass and plastic packaging industry, and fire an estimated eight shots with an AR-15-style rife.\n\nShortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\nEven though text messages among local snipers revealed anxiety about the man, Rowe said the only thing the Secret Service knew at the time of the shooting was that law enforcement was contending with a suspicious-looking man.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take sufficient responsibility.\n\n\"Isn't the fact that a former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be in the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress. He assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nSen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019-2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nAbbate did not identify the social media platform, saying investigators were still trying to definitively determine that it belonged to Crooks. However, he indicated that it was separate from an account on a different platform called Gab that was active in 2021.\n\nThe chief executive of Gab posted on X, formerly known as Twitter, during the Senate hearing that Crooks's presence on that platform was consistent with being \"pro-Biden and in particular pro-Biden's immigration policy.\"\n\nOn Monday, the FBI revealed that Crooks had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister Robert Fico.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim.", "source": {"uri": "thenationalherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The National Herald"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8250494841", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "11:05:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T11:05:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T11:04:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/secret-service-and-fbi-officials-will-testify-about-trump-assassination-attempt-in-latest-hearing/article_26e4d1e3-1ef2-5957-9dba-1619f0d51e17.html", "title": "Secret Service and FBI officials will testify about Trump assassination attempt in latest hearing", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Senate lawmakers are expected Tuesday to grill the acting director of the Secret Service about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRonald Rowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nRowe will be joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. {"uri": "2024-07-438933030", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:16:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:16:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:09:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2808250/", "title": "Secret Service, FBI officials to testify on Trump assassination attempt in final hearing | News", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) Senate lawmakers are expected to question the acting Secret Service director on Tuesday about law enforcement failures in the hours leading up to the election. assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings devoted to the shooting.\n\nRonald Rowe became the agency's interim director last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned. following a hearing in the House in which she was reprimanded by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about communication failures leading up to the July 13 shooting.\n\nRowe will be joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security Committees.\n\nThe hearing comes a day after the The FBI has released new details about its investigation into the shooting.revealing that the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, 20had searched online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the attempted assassination of Slovakia's prime minister in May.\n\nThe FBI also said Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential candidate, had agreed to be questioned by agents as a victim of a crime. The office said last week The former president said Monday night that he expected the interview to take place Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe, with lawmakers demanding answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots at Trump from an AR-style rifle after climbing onto the roof of a building about 450 feet from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rally participant was killed and two others were wounded. Crooks was shot dead by a secret service sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service failed in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attack on Trump the most significant operational failure by the Secret Service in decades and vowed to move heaven and earth to find out what happened and make sure it doesn't happen again.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service had been notified of a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the rooftop from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn an interview Monday night on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting, but said someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They weren't talking to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he called an incredible shot, but noted: \"It would have been nice if it had happened nine seconds earlier.\"", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8251111722", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:48:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:48:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:47:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13689063/trump-shooter-thomas-crooks-comments-social-media-encrypted-apps.html", "title": "FBI finds social media account linked to Trump shooter Thomas Crooks", "body": "By Jon Michael Raasch, Political Reporter On Capitol Hill, For Dailymail.Com\n\nThe FBI revealed they found a social media account possibly tied to Trump shooter Thomas Matthew Crooks that could shine light on the motive behind his assassination attempt.\n\nSo far very little has been uncovered about Crooks and what led to his shooting of Trump, which injured others and fatally wounded former firefighter Corey Comperatore on July 13.\n\nThe bombshell developments in the investigation into the assassination attempt at Trump's Butler, Pennsylvania, rally came during a Senate hearing Tuesday.\n\nCongress dragged in the Secret Service's new acting head Ronald Rowe and the number two at the FBI, Deputy Director Paul Abbate, to testify on the shooting.\n\nAbbate revealed that at least one social media account on an unnamed platform believed to be associated with Crooks was discovered by the FBI. That account posted over 700 comments between 2019 and 2020, he added.\n\n'Some of these comments ... appear to reflect anti-Semitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence,' Abbate said.\n\nActing Director of the U.S. Secret Service, Ronald L. Rowe, Jr. and Deputy Director of the FBI Paul Abbate are sworn-in before a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on the attempted assassination of Republican presidential nominee and former U.S. President Donald Trump, on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., July 30, 2024\n\nRead MoreBREAKING NEWS Acting Secret Service director says he's 'ashamed' gunman was able to get on the Trump rally roof\n\nHe wouldn't confirm the name of the social media platform until after his agents could prove with 100% certainty Crooks made the posts.\n\nAbbate said the posts were 'extreme in nature,' but that the FBI is still determining whether the account actually belonged to Crooks.\n\nHe also disclosed that the agency is still working to identify and infiltrate Crooks's various 'encrypted' accounts that could shine light on his motive.\n\nThat angered Sen. Lindsey Graham who wanted more information on his. motive.\n\n'So you're telling me, the guy that took eight shots at the president, former president, has apps that we can't get into, that may if you could get into [them] reveal some relevant information.'\n\n'That is correct, senator,' the officials responded.\n\nThis concerned Graham who later pushed for better methods to infiltrate encrypted accounts.\n\n'We need a solution that provides lawful access,' the officials noted, inferring current options only provide illegal entry into Crooks's suspected accounts.\n\nThomas Crooks shown in his high school yearbook from 2020. Little is known about the reclusive shooter\n\nImages show law enforcement approaching the building from where Crooks shot just minutes before he opened fire at the rally\n\nFormer President Donald Trump raises his fist after being shot in the ear by Crooks on July 13\n\nIn addition to the online account discoveries, the number two man at the FBI disclosed more about the timeline behind the assassination attempt.\n\n'Approximately 25 minutes prior to the shooting, the U.S. Secret Service command post was notified of a suspicious person,' Abbate testified.\n\nThe Secret Service acting director also admitted he had no defense as for why the rooftop where Crooks fired shots toward former President Trump was left open.\n\n'I went to the roof of the AGR building where the assailant fired shots, and I laid in a prone position to evaluate his line of sight.'\n\n'What I saw made me ashamed as a career law enforcement officer and a 25 year veteran with the Secret Service. I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured,' he told Congress on Tuesday.\n\nCrooks fired eight rounds toward Trump, grazing him with a bullet in his ear.\n\n'When I laid in that position I could not, will not understand why there was not better coverage or at least somebody looking at that roof line when that's where they were posted,' Rowe said, noting that Crooks' head would have been clearly visible from the unmanned rooftop.\n\nThirty seconds before Crooks fired his shots, local law enforcement had radioed to Secret Service warning about a man with a rifle on the roof. Around three and a half minutes before that, he'd been 'observed on the roof.'\n\nFormer Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle appears before the House Oversight and Accountability Committee hearing on oversight of the Secret Service on July 23, 2024. She resigned the day after the hearing\n\nTrump assassination attempt timeline, according to Secret Service acting director\n\nJuly 7: Crooks travels to rally site to spend 20 minutes doing reconnaissance\n\nJuly 12: Shooter visits Clairton Sportsmen's Club to practice shooting\n\nJuly 13, 10 a.m.: Shooter visits rally site again\n\n90 minutes before shooting: local law enforcement 'suspicious' of Crooks\n\n20 minutes before Trump takes stage, 30 minutes before shooting: Secret Service made aware of an individual with a rangefinder\n\n10 minutes before Trump takes stage, 20 minutes before shooting: Secret Service counter sniper team given photograph of the 'suspicious subject'\n\n3.5 minutes before shooting: Crooks spotted on the roof\n\n30 seconds before shooting: Crooks seen with a gun\n\nAdvertisement\n\nRowe said that since the shooting he'd implemented a number of changes at the Secret Service, including having security plans go through multiple supervisors before implementation, expanded use of drones, more resources for protective site communications and 'expeditious' approval of requests for personnel at protective sites with heightened security environments.\n\nRowe and Abbate spoke to the Judiciary and Homeland Security committees after their boss, former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle submitted her resignation last week after a six-hour-long hearing where Republicans and Democrats accused her of stonewalling.\n\nThe FBI and Secret Service officials also disclosed a more accurate timeline of events leading up to the shooting.\n\nAlmost a week before the rally, Crooks scouted the site of the event, spending 20 minutes doing reconnaissance on the location, they shared.\n\nJust a day before the shooting Crooks went to a shooting range to practice his shot.\n\nThe morning of the July 13 rally, Crooks again visited the grounds, the officials said.\n\nAbbate and Rowe also disclosed Crooks's activity on the day of the shooting and what authorities did in response.\n\nLocal law enforcement marked Crooks as 'suspicious' 90 minutes before he opened fire, the officials shared.\n\nSecret Service was informed that the would-be assassin had a range finder 30 minutes before the shooting occurred.\n\nMinutes later, just 20 before the shooting, the Secret Service counter sniper team was given a photo of the 'suspicious suspect.'\n\nThen, 3.5 minutes before Crooks opened fire, he was spotted on the roof.\n\nThe officials also disclosed that Crooks was seen with a gun on the roof 30 seconds before firing his first shot.\n\n'Within 15.5 seconds of his first shot, he's neutralized,' Rowe testified about how quickly Crooks was killed after opening fire.\n\nDeputy Director of the FBI Paul Abbate testified that the agency is still working to crack encrypted online accounts related to Crooks\n\nBut prior to his first shot Secret Service was unaware of his location, the Secret Service acting chief added.\n\nHe noted that the counter snipers did not see him because he was initially hiding on the other side of the roof.\n\n'I believe he was obscured by that roof,' Rowe testified.", "source": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.ccenterdispatch.com/news/national/article_5bafe918-251e-5167-8167-ed9275e81960.html", "title": "Trump security was unaware of gunman until shots fired: Secret Service", "body": "Donald Trump's security detail and a sniper team were not aware there was a gunman on a roof until he opened fire on the former president, the acting Secret Service director said Tuesday.\n\nLocal law enforcement identified the gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, as a \"suspicious person\" about 90 minutes before the July 13 attack at a Trump campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, according to FBI officials.\n\nSince the assassination attempt, questions have been raised about when the Secret Service became aware of the presence of the gunman on the roof of a building that overlooked the campaign event.\n\n\"Based on what I know right now, neither the Secret Service counter-sniper teams nor members of the former president's security detail had any knowledge that there was a man on the AGR roof with a firearm,\" acting Secret Service chief Ronald Rowe told a joint Senate committee.\n\n\"The only thing we had was that locals were working an issue at the three o'clock, which would have been the former president's right-hand side, which is where the shots came from,\" Rowe said.\n\n\"Nothing about man on the roof, nothing about man with a gun,\" he said.\n\nFBI special agent Kevin Rojek said Monday that a police officer was boosted on to the roof by another officer at 6:11 pm.\n\nCrooks pointed his rifle at the officer, who \"immediately dropped to the ground.\"\n\n\"Approximately 25 to 30 seconds after this encounter, the subject fired eight rounds before being successfully neutralized,\" Rojek said.\n\nRowe said Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service sniper \"within 15.5 seconds\" of firing the first shot.\n\nThe Republican presidential candidate was wounded in the right ear, while two rally attendees were injured and a Pennsylvania firefighter was killed.\n\n- 'Ashamed' -\n\nRowe said he \"cannot defend\" why the rooftop where Crooks fired from was not better secured, and said he was \"ashamed\" about the security lapses.\n\nHe said local law enforcement had been tasked with securing the rooftop. \"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" he said.\n\nAsked why Trump was allowed to take the stage, Rowe said Crooks had not been identified as a threat but only as suspicious.\n\n\"We did not have anything beyond suspicious person that was communicated to us,\" he said. \"Suspicion had not risen to the level of threat or imminent harm.\"\n\nRowe said communications failures between local law enforcement and the Secret Service contributed to what he called a \"failure on multiple levels.\"\n\nThe Secret Service had \"technical difficulties\" with its counter-drone capabilities on the day of the attack and they were not \"operational until after five o'clock,\" he said.\n\nCrooks flew a drone near the rally site for 11 minutes about two hours before the attack, according to the FBI.\n\nFBI deputy director Paul Abbate also addressed the committee hearing and said the authorities still have not established a motive.\n\nHe said they have identified a social media account believed to be associated with Crooks.\n\n\"In about the 2019, 2020 timeframe there were over 700 comments posted from this account,\" Abbate said. \"Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect anti-Semitic and anti-immigration themes, to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature.\"\n\nSecret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned last week after acknowledging that the agency had failed in its mission to prevent the assassination {"uri": "8251046650", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:57:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:57:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:57:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/2484284/fbi-says-trump-shooter-posted-violent-content-online", "title": "FBI says Trump shooter posted violent content online", "body": "The man who tried to assassinate Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump appears to have posted violent antisemitic and anti-immigration content online as a teenager, a senior FBI official told a US Senate hearing on Tuesday.\n\nFBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at the hearing revealed the existence of the social media account, which dated to 2019-2020 - when Thomas Crooks, who authorities have identified as the shooter, would have been 15 or 16 years old. It is some of the first evidence to become public about a potential motive in the July 13 attack at a campaign rally in western Pennsylvania.\n\n\"Something just very recently uncovered that I want to share is a social media account which is believed to be associated with the shooter in about the 2019-2020 time frame,\" Abbate told lawmakers, adding that more than 700 comments were posted by the account.\n\n\"Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature,\" Abbate said.\n\nCrooks, who was 20, shot at Trump with an AR-15-style rifle during the rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, wounding the former president's ear, killing one rally attendee and wounding two others. Secret Service snipers killed Crooks after he opened fire.\n\nInvestigators have described Crooks as a loner with no close friends and a social network limited mainly to immediate family members.\n\nThe first shooting of a US president or major party candidate in more than four decades was a glaring security lapse that led last week to former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle's resignation under bipartisan congressional pressure.\n\nHer immediate successor, Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe, told lawmakers that he visited the outdoor rally site in Butler and climbed onto the roof of a nearby building from which Crooks fired.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe told a joint hearing of the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees. \"As a career law enforcement officer, and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nRowe sought to assure lawmakers that he has since taken steps to prevent similar lapses from occurring amid concerns among both Democrats and Republicans about further political violence as the campaign intensifies ahead of the Nov. 5 US election.\n\nCrooks flew a drone near the rally site ahead of his assassination attempt, a flight that officials failed to detect because a system designed to detect drones was not working properly due to problems with cellular network bandwidth, Rowe said.\n\nThe Secret Service, a federal law enforcement agency whose duties including protecting the president and certain other top political figures, has added six people to its protection list since July 13, including Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance and his family and independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy, while reinforcing security details, Rowe said.\n\n\"This attack was a shocking reminder that the threat of political violence is alive and well in our country. By all accounts, this was inexcusable security, and planning failure,\" Democratic Senate Homeland Security Chairman Gary Peters said, adding that his panel is working on reforms to strengthen security protocols for the Secret Service.\n\nSenator Rand Paul, the committee's top Republican, said his staff had found communication gaps between local police who first noticed Crooks and the Secret Service.\n\nRowe said that Secret Service counter snipers and members of the Trump security detail had no knowledge that there was a man with a firearm on the roof of a nearby building.\n\nThe attempted assassination is the topic of multiple investigations by House and Senate committees, as well as a new bipartisan task force.", "source": {"uri": "tribune.com.pk", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-438219858", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "11:35:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T11:35:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T10:52:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/secret-service-and-fbi-officials-will-testify-about-trump-assassination-attempt-in-latest-hearing/article_7b6ef04e-0834-5234-8c58-0226aa1864a0.html", "title": "Secret Service and FBI officials will testify about Trump assassination attempt in latest hearing", "body": "Senate lawmakers are expected to grill the Secret Service's acting director about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Senate lawmakers are expected Tuesday to grill the acting director of the Secret Service about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRonald Rowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nRowe will be joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\nMore from this section\n\nPIC's WooSOS Plugin Streamlines Ecommerce Through WooCommerce and SOS Inventory
