{"uri": "8251933294", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "07:20:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T07:20:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T07:12:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://omaha.com/eedition/sunrise/articles/head-of-secret-service-ashamed/article_51500d08-e1e7-5b9e-a203-287495a78ec1.html", "title": "Head of Secret Service 'ashamed'", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers Tuesday he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured and said it was regrettable that local law enforcement didn't communicate to his agency that a gunman was spotted on a nearby roof.\n\nRonald Rowe also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and laid down on the roof of the building where shots were fired to evaluate the gunman's line of sight during the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed. As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year Secret Service veteran, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured,\" he said.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalog to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Ronald Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also criticizing local law enforcement for not sharing information that a gunman, later identified as Thomas Matthew Crooks, 20, was spotted on a roof of a building less than 150 yards from the rally stage where Trump spoke.\n\n\"Neither the Secret Service counter-sniper teams nor members of the former president's security detail had any knowledge that there was a man on the roof of the building with a firearm,\" Rowe said. \"It is my understanding those personnel were not aware the assailant had a firearm until they heard gunshots.\"\n\nHe said the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination and a \"failure to challenge our assumptions.\"\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nHe said he implemented reforms since taking over as acting director last week, including mandating that every event security plan is vetted by multiple experienced supervisors before being implemented, expanding the use of aerial drones to improve visibility of roofs and dedicating more resources to improve communications at events where the Secret Service operates.\n\nTrump, now the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before a Secret Service counter-sniper shot and killed the gunman.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue.\n\nIt also suggested that Rowe, with ready and generally detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers after responses at a congressional hearing that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nTuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security Committees was the latest in a series of congressional sessions dedicated to the law enforcement lapses and missed communications that preceded the shooting.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers first observed a suspicious-looking man at the rally site more than an hour before the event and circulated that information, including photographs of a man who turned out to be Crooks.\n\nThe officers ultimately lost track of Crooks, who scaled the roof of a building at AGR International Inc., a supplier of automation equipment for the glass and plastic packaging industry, and fire an estimated eight shots with an AR-15-style rife.\n\nShortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\nEven though text messages among local snipers revealed anxiety about the man, Rowe said the only thing the Secret Service knew at the time of the shooting was that law enforcement was contending with a suspicious-looking man.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take sufficient responsibility.\n\n\"Isn't the fact that a former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be in the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress. He assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment.\n\nThe posts were from the 20192020 time frame, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nAbbate did not identify the social media platform, saying investigators were still trying to definitively determine that it belonged to Crooks. However, he indicated that it was separate from an account on a different platform called Gab that was active in 2021.", "source": {"uri": "omaha.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Omaha.com"}, {"uri": "2024-07-438494445", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:29:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:29:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://richmond.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/watch-live-acting-secret-service-boss-cannot-defend-why-roof-in-trump-rally-shooting-wasnt/article_28608856-9d35-52ee-bb08-413edc5a6507.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting wasn't secured", "body": "Senior officials from the U.S. Secret Service and the FBI testify before the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees about the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump.\n\nWASHINGTON -- The acting director of the Secret Service says he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe is testifying Tuesday before two Senate committees. Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nYoungkin names Scalia daughter to Board of Education 'Illegal' recruiting a hot topic at VHSL meeting in Abingdon; John Marshall called out Former Virginia EMS employee pleads guilty to embezzling $4 million Outer Banks wild stallion hit, killed on the beach As Kings Dominion merges with Six Flags, some fans worry quality will suffer New Virginia state law changes the way reading is taught Thousands watch Chincoteague wild ponies complete 99th swim Virginia collects $1.2 billion more revenue than expected UPDATE: Police identify man found dead in vehicle in Chesterfield pond UVa's Gretchen Walsh sets Olympic record in 100 butterfly on opening night of Paris Games UPDATE: Police ID victim, announce arrest in shooting involving Chesterfield couple Dominion customers' bills to rise for offshore project costs Woman featured on '16 and Pregnant' pronounced dead in Sandston Richmonders weigh in on Kamala Harris as presumptive Democratic nominee Henrico homeowners upset by Goochland quarry expansion\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"", "source": {"uri": "richmond.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Richmond Times-Dispatch"}, "authors": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9772518", "eventUri": "eng-9772518", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-13", "textStart": 2530, "textEnd": {"uri": "8252241620", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:28:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:28:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:28:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://abc7ny.com/post/takeaways-senate-hearing-trump-assassination-attempt-secret-service-failure/15126089/", "title": "Takeaways from Senate hearing on Trump assassination attempt and Secret Service failure", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Secret Service acting Director Ronald Rowe provided new details about the assassination attempt of Donald Trump on Tuesday, delivering forceful testimony at a Senate hearing about the agency's failures earlier this month in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nBut at the joint hearing of the Judiciary and Homeland Security committees, Rowe also highlighted the missteps of local law enforcement on July 13, when the former president was shot.\n\nRowe testified that Secret Service agents on Trump's security detail, as well as snipers on duty, were not told that the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, was positioned on a nearby roof with a rifle and only learned of his presence after he started shooting.\n\nFederal investigators are looking into a YouTube account possibly connected to Crooks in which the user espoused political violence as well as antisemitic and anti-immigration themes, a source familiar with the investigation tells CNN. Deputy FBI Director Paul Abbate described the account but did not reveal the platform at the hearing.\n\nRELATED: Homeland Security Secretary Mayorkas announces independent review of Trump assassination plot\n\nThe hearing was the fourth such one held on Capitol Hill since the assassination attempt, and though it grew testy at times, especially during some exchanges with Republican senators, lawmakers appeared largely satisfied with the information provided by Rowe and Abbate during their more than three hours of testimony.\n\nOverall, it stood in stark contrast with a House hearing held last week in which lawmakers grilled then-Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle over what went wrong earlier this month, with several members demanding she resign over the lapses. A day later, she did just that.\n\nHere are the takeaways from Tuesday's joint hearing:\n\nDuring Tuesday's hearing, Rowe highlighted the failures of communications during the rally, in Butler, saying that information about Crooks was \"siloed\" and \"stuck\" in local law enforcement channels.\n\n\"The only thing we had was that locals were working an issue at the three o'clock - which would have been the former president's right-hand side - which is where the shot came,\" Rowe said. \"Nothing about man on the roof, nothing about man with a gun. None of that information ever made it over our net.\"\n\nHomeland Security Committee Chairman Gary Peters said that local law enforcement has claimed they were \"only able to call in to a state command center\" and not able to easily communicate threats to the Secret Service.\n\nBut Peters also noted that Abbate testified during the hearing that \"there was about 30 seconds between when the local law enforcement reported that there was a man on the roof with a gun\" and when the shooter began firing.\n\n\"If it's communicated directly to a counter-sniper team, would that be enough time to react prior to the firing of those shots?\" Peters asked.\n\n\"If we'd had that information, they would have been able to address it more quickly,\" Rowe replied. \"It appears that that information was stuck or siloed in that local channel.\"\n\n\"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have,\" he said. \"We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nCrooks was killed within 15.5 seconds of the first shot, Rowe said.\n\nRowe confirmed that the reason a counter-drone system was not deployed at the Butler rally earlier in the day was because of connectivity issues.\n\n\"On this day in particular, because of the connectivity challenge ... there was a delay,\" he said. Crooks flew his own drone around the area two hours before Trump took the stage.\n\nThe issue has \"cost me a lot of sleep,\" Rowe said. \"What if we would have geolocated him because that counter (unmanned aircraft system) platform would have been up.\"\n\nRowe said that had the system been up, law enforcement may have been able to see Crooks' use of his own drone and approached him well before the shooting.\n\nRELATED: Failure of communication: Beaver County SWAT team details account of Trump assassination attempt\n\nMoving forward, Rowe said, his agency will use drones to help better secure future events.\n\n\"It is clear to me that other protective enhancements could have strengthened our security at the Butler event,\" he told lawmakers. \"As such, I have directed the expanded use of unmanned aerial systems at protective sites to help detect threats on roofs and other elevated threats.\"\n\nThe acting director also said that the Secret Service will now work with the Department of Homeland Security to set up their own, private connection and not rely on public domain connections.\n\nThe rally also did not deploy a Secret Service counter surveillance unit that would be dedicated to observing and tracking suspicious people like Crooks, according to multiple sources familiar with the operation.\n\nA law enforcement source told CNN the counter surveillance units were not requested as part of the plan put together by the Secret Service. The source said the units are not typically used for protection of former presidents.\n\nAs lawmakers pressed Rowe for answers on what went wrong earlier this month, the interim Secret Service director sought to shirk some of the responsibility for the security lapses, partially blaming the issues on the local law enforcement officers with whom they were working.\n\nMoving forward, Rowe told the committees, his agency will avoid assuming local law enforcement agencies are fully capable of fulfilling their role in protecting an event.\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said of the area where Crooks climbed up the side of a building near the rally with his rifle.\n\n\"We made an assumption,\" he said, explaining that the Secret Service believed there would be sufficient eyes to cover the area and that local law enforcement would have a counter sniper in the AGR building where Crooks took his position.\n\nRowe told the lawmakers that local law enforcement was positioned in a nearby building and should have had a clear line of sight of Crooks on the roof.\n\n\"I cannot understand why there was not better coverage or at least somebody looking at that roofline when that's where they were posted,\" Rowe said, noting that a local sniper team could have looked from their post and seen the would-be assassin.\n\n\"Looking left, why was the assailant not seen?\" Rowe asked of the local team, as he showed lawmakers photographs of the roofs snipers were positioned on.\n\n\"I'm not saying that they should have neutralized him, but if they'd have held their post and looked left maybe...\" Rowe said later, though he was quickly cut off by an unrelated comment.\n\nSeveral senators lambasted Rowe for not firing any members in his agency and over the amount of security provided to former President Trump compared to President Joe Biden.\n\nIn one such exchange, Rowe loudly objected to Sen. Josh Hawley's persistent questions about why individuals weren't fired in recent weeks.\n\n\"I will not rush to judgment. People will be held accountable,\" Rowe said, adding that investigations into the failures that day are ongoing.\n\nThe Missouri Republican responded: \"Is it not prima facie that somebody has failed? The former president was shot.\"\n\n\"Sir, this could have been our Texas School Book Depository,\" Rowe responded, referring to the 1963 assassination of President John F. Kennedy in Dallas. \"I have lost sleep over that for the last 17 days, just like you have.\"\n\n\"Then fire somebody,\" Hawley shouted, to which Rowe replied: \"We have to be able to have a proper investigation into this.\"\n\nAt another point during Tuesday's hearing, Republican Sen. Ted Cruz repeatedly pressed Rowe on why Trump doesn't receive the same security level as Biden.\n\n\"There is a difference between the sitting president of the United States,\" Rowe said.\n\n\"Then what's the difference,\" Cruz yelled, cutting Rowe off.\n\n\"The difference - national command authority to launch a nuclear strike, sir,\" Rowe responded. \"There are other assets that travel with the president that the former president will not get.\"\n\nInvestigators have uncovered a social media account with posts espousing political violence that may be connected to the would-be Trump assassin, Abbate said.\n\nOfficials have repeatedly said that they have struggled to understand what the 20-year-old shooter's motive was, and that they are combing his online presence for more information.\n\n\"Something just very recently uncovered that I want to share is a social media account, which is believed to be associated with this with the shooter - in about the 2019, 2020 timeframe,\" Abbate said.\n\nOn that account, \"there were over 700 comments,\" Abbate said, which, \"if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes, to espouse political violence, and are described as extreme in nature.\"\n\nRELATED: New details reveal officers left post to look for Crooks before Trump shooting\n\nCNN has learned the account is on the YouTube platform.\n\nA separate account on the platform Gab - which was made years earlier - appears to have \"differing points of view,\" Abbate added.\n\nGab CEO Andrew Tobra revealed last week that the would-be assassin may have had an account on the site, which is an alternative social media network popular with conservatives, the alt-right and some extremists. Tobra claimed that the account in question was \"pro-Biden.\"\n\nThe Gab account has also not been conclusively connected to Crooks.", "source": {"uri": "abc7ny.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ABC7 New York"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Peters", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Gary Peters"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F. Kennedy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_enforcement", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Law enforcement"}}, {"uri": the bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one.\n\nMr Trump said on Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut the bulk of the questions on Tuesday are expected to be directed at Mr Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Mr Trump.\n\nInvestigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Mr Trump's direction using an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters from where Mr Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Ms Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Mr Trump.\n\nShe called the attempt on Mr Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there is no repeat of it.\n\nMs Cheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person up to five times before the shooting at the rally.\n\nShe also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nMs Cheatle said she apologised to Mr Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News, Mr Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good {"uri": "8251175398", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:41:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:41:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:40:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/trump-security-was-unaware-of-gunman-until-shots-fired-secret-service/article_e0d0dd03-db76-5fff-8862-6983f80e7050.html", "title": "Trump security was unaware of gunman until shots fired: Secret Service", "body": "Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump is evacuated from a rally by Secret Service agents after an assassination attempt in Butler, Pennsylvania, on July 13, 2024\n\nDonald Trump's security detail and a sniper team were not aware there was a gunman on a roof until he opened fire on the former president, the acting Secret Service director said Tuesday.\n\nLocal law enforcement identified the gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, as a \"suspicious person\" about 90 minutes before the July 13 attack at a Trump campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, according to FBI officials.\n\nSince the assassination attempt, questions have been raised about when the Secret Service became aware of the presence of the gunman on the roof of a building that overlooked the campaign event.\n\n\"Based on what I know right now, neither the Secret Service counter-sniper teams nor members of the former president's security detail had any knowledge that there was a man on the AGR roof with a firearm,\" acting Secret Service chief Ronald Rowe told a joint Senate committee.\n\n\"The only thing we had was that locals were working an issue at the three o'clock, which would have been the former president's right-hand side, which is where the shots came from,\" Rowe said.\n\n\"Nothing about man on the roof, nothing about man with a gun,\" he said.\n\nFBI special agent Kevin Rojek said Monday that a police officer was boosted on to the roof by another officer at 6:11 pm.\n\nCrooks pointed his rifle at the officer, who \"immediately dropped to the ground.\"\n\n\"Approximately 25 to 30 seconds after this encounter, the subject fired eight rounds before being successfully neutralized,\" Rojek said.\n\nRowe said Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service sniper \"within 15.5 seconds\" of firing the first shot.\n\nThe Republican presidential candidate was wounded in the right ear, while two rally attendees were injured and a Pennsylvania firefighter was killed.\n\n- 'Ashamed' - More from this section Israel targets Hezbollah commander in south Beirut strike Old Rajinder Nagar Horror: Students Organise Candle March to Protest Against the Authorities Study claims eating fruit can reduce risk of depression\n\nRowe said he \"cannot defend\" why the rooftop where Crooks fired from was not better secured, and said he was \"ashamed\" about the security lapses.\n\nHe said local law enforcement had been tasked with securing the rooftop. \"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" he said.\n\nAsked why Trump was allowed to take the stage, Rowe said Crooks had not been identified as a threat but only as suspicious.\n\n\"We did not have anything beyond suspicious person that was communicated to us,\" he said. \"Suspicion had not risen to the level of threat or imminent harm.\"\n\nRowe said communications failures between local law enforcement and the Secret Service contributed to what he called a \"failure on multiple levels.\"\n\nThe Secret Service had \"technical difficulties\" with its counter-drone capabilities on the day of the attack and they were not \"operational until after five o'clock,\" he said.\n\nCrooks flew a drone near the rally site for 11 minutes about two hours before the attack, according to the FBI.\n\nFBI deputy director Paul Abbate also addressed the committee hearing and said the authorities still have not established a motive.\n\nHe said they have identified a social media account believed to be associated with Crooks.\n\n\"In about the 2019, 2020 timeframe there were over 700 comments posted from this account,\" Abbate said. \"Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect anti-Semitic and anti-immigration themes, to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature.\"\n\nSecret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned last week after acknowledging that the agency had failed in its mission to prevent the assassination attempt.\n\ncl/bjt", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251177666", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:46:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:46:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:42:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/this-is-a-failure-of-the-secret-service-key-takeaways-from-the-senate-hearing-on-trumps-attempted-assassination-183417376.html", "title": "'This is a failure of the Secret Service': Key takeaways from the Senate hearing on Trump's attempted assassination", "body": "Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe told Congress on Tuesday that the agency failed to protect former President Donald Trump when he was wounded during an assassination attempt at a rally in Butler, Pa., earlier this month.\n\n\"This is a failure of the Secret Service,\" Rowe said in his testimony before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees.\n\nHis appearance on Capitol came a week after Secret Service Director Kim Cheatle resigned following her own testimony before the House Oversight committee.\n\nRowe appeared alongside FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate, who told lawmakers that a social media account believed to be used by Trump's would-be assassin contains posts that \"appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes.\"\n\nFederal investigators continue to search for the motive of the shooter, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, who was killed by a countersniper at the rally.\n\nHere are other key takeaways from Tuesday's hearing:\n\nIn his opening statement, Rowe said that he can't explain nor defend why Crooks was able to gain access to the roof where he opened fire.\n\n\"I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured,\" Rowe testified.\n\nRowe said that he visited the rally site last week \"to better understand how our protection failed.\"\n\n\"I went to the roof of [the building] where the assailant fired shots and laid in a prone position to evaluate his line of sight,\" Rowe recalled to the committees. \"What I saw made me ashamed.\"\n\nDuring his testimony, Abbate revealed that a local police officer spotted Crooks on the roof with a firearm seconds before he opened fire.\n\nAbbate said that surveillance video from a local business captured Crooks getting onto the roof of the building from which he staged his shooting at approximately 6:06 p.m.\n\n\"And at approximately 6:08 p.m. the subject was observed on the roof by local law enforcement,\" Abbate said. \"At approximately 6:11 p.m., a local police officer was lifted to the roof by another officer, saw the shooter and radioed that he was armed with a long gun. Within approximately the next 30 seconds, the shots were fired.\"\n\nThe acting director testified that in those 30 or so seconds, radio communication between local law enforcement and federal agents got \"stuck\" and that information about the shooter on the roof never made it to the Secret Service.\n\nRowe said that problems with Wi-Fi connectivity impacted the Secret Service's counter-drone operations, which weren't working when Crooks flew a drone over the rally site earlier in the day.\n\nHe also said that the Secret Service's radio communications from the day of the shooting were not recorded because the agency typically does not record them during events not involving the president or vice president outside of Washington. Rowe said that he has directed that the agency will be recording radio communications from all campaign events moving forward.\n\nDuring the hearing, Republican Sens. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina and Josh Hawley of Missouri demanded that heads roll over the security failures that led to Trump's shooting.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people will be fired,\" Graham said. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\n\"We need to learn what happened, make corrective action,\" he added. \"But somebody's gotta be fired. Nothing's gonna change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nLater, during a tense exchange with Hawley, Rowe said he \"will not rush to judgment\" amid the Secret Service's ongoing internal investigations into the failures that day.\n\n\"Sir, this could have been our Texas School Book Depository,\" Rowe explained, referring to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in 1963. \"I have lost sleep over that for the last 17 days, just like you have.\"", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Secret_Service", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "United States Secret Service"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Rowe", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Ronald Rowe"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kimberly_Cheatle", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kimberly Cheatle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Abbate", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Paul Abbate"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F. {"uri": "8251360956", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:18:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:18:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:17:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.kgou.org/politics-and-government/2024-07-30/social-media-account-with-extremist-comments-could-be-tied-to-trump-gunman-fbi-says", "title": "Social media account with extremist comments could be tied to Trump gunman, FBI says", "body": "The FBI has found a social media account featuring antisemitic and anti-immigration comments that investigators believe to be associated with the gunman who tried to assassinate former President Donald Trump, a senior bureau official said Tuesday.\n\nFBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate told members of Congress that the account could be linked to the shooter, Thomas Crooks, but he cautioned that officials are still working to verify the account's authenticity.\n\n\"There were over 700 comments posted; some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature,\" Abbate told a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees.\n\nThe note of caution about the account's authenticity stems, in part, from confusion about a gaming account that the FBI had at one point attributed to Crooks but later turned out to be a hoax.\n\nThe details about the account came as lawmakers questioned Abbate and the acting director of the Secret Service about security failures and other details of the July 13 shooting targeting Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, in Butler, Pa. Crooks was able to fire eight shots from the roof of a nearby building; a bullet or bullet fragment struck Trump, killed a person at the rally, and injured two others before Crooks was killed by a Secret Service sniper.\n\nAbbate said the account dates to the 2019-2020 time period, when Crooks would have been 15 or 16 years old. It could provide a glimpse into Crooks' thinking, which has proven elusive as the FBI said the shooter generally had few social contacts and little social media presence. It wasn't clear from Abbate's comment what social media account it was on.\n\nSen. Rick Scott, R-Fla., blamed federal officials for not talking more to the press and providing regular updates on their investigations.\n\n\"You're a black hole. You lose the support of the American public because people don't believe you're being direct with them,\" he said.\n\nIn addition to questions about the shooter, lawmakers also slammed the Secret Service's security gaps. The Secret Service's acting director, Ronald Rowe, said security at the July 13 rally was a failure on multiple levels, and he had implemented changes to security to ensure another shooting doesn't happen again.\n\nRowe said he retraced Crooks' steps on the roof to try to understand how he was able to get a shot at Trump and what went wrong.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe told lawmakers. \"As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nRowe also blamed communication silos between Secret Service agents and local law enforcement. Reports being discussed on a text chain did not get shared with Secret Service agents on the scene: \"Nothing about man on the roof, nothing about man with a gun, none of that information ever made it over our net,\" he told the hearing.\n\nHe said changes to security procedures include using more drones to help detect threats on rooftops, and ensuring every security plan for events is vetted by multiple supervisors.\n\nRowe stepped in to run the Secret Service after the previous director, Kimberly Cheatle, resigned from her job last week after she faced withering criticism from both Democrats and Republicans for not being able to fully answer their questions about the attempted assassination.\n\nSome Republican senators at the hearing made it clear that Cheatle's resignation wasn't enough to assuage their concerns.\n\nSen. Josh Hawley, a Republican from Missouri, urged the agency to fire more people, while Sen. Roger Marshall, R-Kan., accused the Secret Secret of either \"incompetence or some type of a cultural problem\" -- something the acting director disputed.\n\n\"I think you would agree with me that there were multiple individual and institutional failures the day of this assassination attempt,\" Marshall told Rowe.", "source": {"uri": "kgou.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "KGOU 106.3"}, Trump and two others were injured, and one attendee was killed.\n\nSenators on the Homeland Security Committee and Judiciary Committee questioned Rowe about the planning for the event and the communication breakdowns between Secret Service agents on site and local law enforcement who were helping with security. Rowe said local officers who were stationed near the roof where the gunman was perched should have seen him before he opened fire, but acknowledged the Secret Service was ultimately responsible for {"uri": "8250129538", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "07:15:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T07:15:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T07:14:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/07/30/nation/secret-service-fbi-officials-testify-about-trump-assassination-attempt-latest-hearing/", "title": "Secret Service, FBI officials to testify about Trump assassination attempt in latest hearing - The Boston Globe", "body": "Rowe will be joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim; the bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut the bulk of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service countersniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8251062914", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:15:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:15:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:09:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/trump-shooter-thomas-crooks-posted-violent-content-online-as-teen-says-fbi-officer-6225737", "title": "Trump Shooter Posted Violent Content Online As Teen, Says FBI Officer", "body": "Thomas Crooks shot at Trump with an AR-15-style rifle during the rally in Butler\n\nWashington:\n\nThe man who tried to assassinate Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump appears to have posted violent antisemitic and anti-immigration content online as a teenager, a senior FBI official told a U.S. Senate hearing on Tuesday.\n\nFBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at the hearing revealed the existence of the social media account, which dated to 2019-2020 - when Thomas Crooks, who authorities have identified as the shooter, would have been 15 or 16 years old. It is some of the first evidence to become public about a potential motive in the July 13 attack at a campaign rally in western Pennsylvania.\n\n\"Something just very recently uncovered that I want to share is a social media account which is believed to be associated with the shooter in about the 2019-2020 time frame,\" Abbate told lawmakers, adding that more than 700 comments were posted by the account.\n\n\"Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature,\" Abbate said.\n\nCrooks, who was 20, shot at Trump with an AR-15-style rifle during the rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, wounding the former president's ear, killing one rally attendee and wounding two others. Secret Service snipers killed Crooks after he opened fire.\n\nInvestigators have described Crooks as a loner with no close friends and a social network limited mainly to immediate family members.\n\nThe first shooting of a U.S. president or major party candidate in more than four decades was a glaring security lapse that led last week to former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle's resignation under bipartisan congressional pressure.\n\nHer immediate successor, Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe, told lawmakers that he visited the outdoor rally site in Butler and climbed onto the roof of a nearby building from which Crooks fired.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe told a joint hearing of the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees. \"As a career law enforcement officer, and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nRowe sought to assure lawmakers that he has since taken steps to prevent similar lapses from occurring amid concerns among both Democrats and Republicans about further political violence as the campaign intensifies ahead of the Nov. 5 U.S. election.\n\nCrooks flew a drone near the rally site ahead of his assassination attempt, a flight that officials failed to detect because a system designed to detect drones was not working properly due to problems with cellular network bandwidth, Rowe said.\n\nThe Secret Service, a federal law enforcement agency whose duties including protecting the president and certain other top political figures, has added six people to its protection list since July 13, including Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance and his family and independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy, while reinforcing security details, Rowe said.\n\n\"This attack was a shocking reminder that the threat of political violence is alive and well in our country. By all accounts, this was inexcusable security, and planning failure,\" Democratic Senate Homeland Security Chairman Gary Peters said, adding that his panel is working on reforms to strengthen security protocols for the Secret Service.\n\nSenator Rand Paul, the committee's top Republican, said his staff had found communication gaps between local police who first noticed Crooks and the Secret Service.\n\nRowe said that Secret Service counter snipers and members of the Trump security detail had no knowledge that there was a man with a firearm on the roof of a nearby building.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nThe attempted assassination is the topic of multiple investigations by House and Senate committees, as well as a new bipartisan task force\n\n(Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is published from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "ndtv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NDTV"}, Service deputy to be grilled in Senate over Trump assassination bid", "body": "Senate politicians are expected to grill the acting director of the Secret Service on Tuesday about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRonald Rowe became acting director of the agency last week after his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by legislators from both parties and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nMr Rowe will be joined by FBI deputy director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nMr Trump said on Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut the bulk of the questions on Tuesday are expected to be directed at Mr Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Mr Trump.\n\nInvestigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Mr Trump's direction using an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters from where Mr Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Ms Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Mr Trump.\n\nShe called the attempt on Mr Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there is no repeat of it.\n\nMs Cheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person up to five times before the shooting at the rally.\n\nShe also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nMs Cheatle said she apologised to Mr Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News, Mr Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good {"uri": "8251250150", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:44:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:44:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:43:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.wuky.org/local-regional-news/2024-07-30/sen-paul-questions-acting-secret-service-head-about-security-lapses-surrounding-the-trump-assassination-attempt", "title": "Sen. Paul questions acting Secret Service head about security lapses surrounding the Trump assassination attempt", "body": "Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul co-chaired a hearing Tuesday focused on getting more answers about the security failures surrounding the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump.\n\nPaul is one of two senators leading the bipartisan Senate investigation into the July 13th incident. It's one of multiple ongoing probes working to get to the bottom of why the security threat was allowed to materialize.\n\nPaul said in his opening remarks that it's more than a question of getting the facts straight -- it's about ensuring the safety of candidates amid an election season.\n\n\"What remains unclear is who specifically failed, how they failed, and what must be done to ensure that something like this never happens again,\" the senator said. \"America deserves to know that those responsible for this failure are frankly not going to be in charge of securing the upcoming Democrat National Convention. We need to know that someone's been placed on suspension, that someone won't be in charge of the next Donald Trump rally.\"\n\nThe hearing comes after former Secret Service director Kimberly Cheadle resigned the post, leaving acting director Ronald Rowe in charge.\n\nThe Secret Service's acting director on Tuesday told lawmakers he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured and said it was regrettable that local law enforcement had not communicated to his agency that a gunman had been spotted on a nearby roof.\n\nRonald Rowe also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and laid down on the roof of the building where shots were fired in order to evaluate the gunman's line of sight during the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed. As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year Secret Service veteran, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured,\" he said.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalog to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also pointedly criticizing local law enforcement for communication breakdowns that resulted in his agency not sharing information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been spotted on the roof of a building less than 150 yards (135 meters) from the rally stage where Trump was speaking.\n\n\"Neither the Secret Service counter sniper teams nor members of the former president's security detail had any knowledge that there was a man on the roof of the building with a firearm,\" Rowe said. \"It is my understanding those personnel were not aware the assailant had a firearm until they heard gunshots.\"\n\nHe said that the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination and a \"failure to challenge our assumptions.\"\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nHe said he had implemented multiple reforms since taking over as acting director last week, including mandating that every event security plan is vetted by multiple experienced supervisors before being implemented, expanding the use of aerial drones to improve visibility of roofs and dedicating more resources to improve communications at events where the Secret Service is operating.\n\nTrump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before the gunman was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue. It also suggested that Rowe, with ready and generally detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers from both major political parties following responses at a congressional hearing that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nTuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees was the latest in a series of congressional sessions dedicated to the law enforcement lapses and missed communications that preceded the shooting.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers had first observed a suspicious-looking man at the rally site more than an hour before the event and circulated that information, including photographs of a man who turned out to be Crooks. But the officers ultimately lost track of Crooks, who was able to scale the roof of a building at AGR International Inc., a supplier of automation equipment for the glass and plastic packaging industry, and fire an estimated eight shots with an AR-15-style rife.\n\nShortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\nEven though text messages among local snipers revealed anxiety about the man, Rowe said the only thing the Secret Service knew at the time of the shooting was that law enforcement was contending with a suspicious-looking man.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take sufficient responsibility.\n\n\"Isn't the fact that a former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be in the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress. He assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nSen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019-2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nAbbate did not identify the social media platform, saying investigators were still trying to definitively determine that it belonged to Crooks. However, he indicated that it was separate from an account on a different platform called Gab that was active in 2021.\n\nThe chief executive of Gab posted on X, formerly known as Twitter, during the Senate hearing that Crooks's presence on that platform was consistent with being \"pro-Biden and in particular pro-Biden's immigration policy.\"\n\nOn Monday, the FBI revealed that Crooks had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister Robert Fico.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump {"uri": "2024-07-438742654", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:14:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:14:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:13:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.timesofisrael.com/trump-shooter-posted-antisemitic-anti-immigrant-content-online-fbi-official-says/", "title": "Trump shooter posted antisemitic, anti-immigrant content online, FBI official says", "body": "WASHINGTON (Reuters) -- The man who tried to assassinate Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump appears to have posted violent antisemitic and anti-immigration content online as a teenager, a senior FBI official told a US Senate hearing on Tuesday.\n\nFBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at the hearing revealed the existence of the social media account, which dated to 2019-2020 -- when Thomas Crooks, who authorities have identified as the shooter, would have been 15 or 16 years old. It is some of the first evidence to become public about a potential motive in the July 13 attack at a campaign rally in western Pennsylvania.\n\n\"Something just very recently uncovered that I want to share is a social media account which is believed to be associated with the shooter in about the 2019-2020 time frame,\" Abbate told lawmakers, adding that more than 700 comments were posted by the account.\n\n\"Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature,\" Abbate said.\n\nCrooks, who was 20, shot at Trump with an AR-15-style rifle during the rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, wounding the former president's ear, killing one rally attendee and wounding two others. Secret Service snipers killed Crooks after he opened fire.\n\nInvestigators have described Crooks as a loner with no close friends and a social network limited mainly to immediate family members.\n\nThe first shooting of a US president or major party candidate in more than four decades was a glaring security lapse that led last week to former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle's resignation under bipartisan congressional pressure.\n\nHer immediate successor, Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe, told lawmakers that he visited the outdoor rally site in Butler and climbed onto the roof of a nearby building from which Crooks fired.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe told a joint hearing of the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees.\n\n\"As a career law enforcement officer, and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nRowe sought to assure lawmakers that he has since taken steps to prevent similar lapses from occurring amid concerns among both Democrats and Republicans about further political violence as the campaign intensifies ahead of the November 5 US election.\n\nCrooks flew a drone near the rally site ahead of his assassination attempt, a flight that officials failed to detect because a system designed to detect drones was not working properly due to problems with cellular network bandwidth, Rowe said.\n\nThe Secret Service, a federal law enforcement agency whose duties include protecting the president and certain other top political figures, has added six people to its protection list since July 13, including Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance and his family, and independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy, while reinforcing security details, Rowe said.\n\n\"This attack was a shocking reminder that the threat of political violence is alive and well in our country. By all accounts, this was inexcusable security and planning failure,\" Democratic Senate Homeland Security Chairman Gary Peters said, adding that his panel is working on reforms to strengthen security protocols for the Secret Service.\n\nSenator Rand Paul, the committee's top Republican, said his staff had found communication gaps between local police who first noticed Crooks and the Secret Service.\n\nRowe said that Secret Service counter snipers and members of the Trump security detail had no knowledge that there was a man with a firearm on the roof of a nearby building.", "source": What I saw made me ashamed. As a career law enforcement officer, and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured,\" Rowe said in his opening statement to the joint Senate panel.\n\nThe shooting was a \"failure on multiple levels.\"\n\nHe acknowledged the many ongoing investigations into the shooting. \"I pledge my full support to those inquiries...so that the American people have a full understanding of what happened, leading up to and during\" the events of the July 13,\" Rowe continued.\n\nRowe became the acting director after Kimberly Cheatle stepped down last week. Lawmakers called for her resignation after she called the tragedy the \"most significant operational failure\" in decades in her testimony to the House.\n\nThomas Matthew Crooks, 20, opened fire from a nearby rooftop into the Butler, Pennsylvania rally venue, killing one, striking Trump, and injuring two others. A Secret Service agent killed Crooks at the scene.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was informed of a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting -- and that the roof where Crooks fired his AR-15-style rifle was considered a security vulnerability.\n\nTrump confirmed that he would be participating in an interview with the FBI about the assassination attempt.\n\nFBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate also testified. It is some of the first evidence to become public about a potential motive in the July 13 attack at a campaign rally in western Pennsylvania.\n\n\"Something just very recently uncovered that I want to share is a social media account which is believed to be associated with the shooter in about the 2019-2020 time frame,\" Abbate told lawmakers, adding that more than 700 comments were posted by the account.\n\n\"Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature,\" Abbate said.\n\nCrooks, who was 20, shot at Trump with an AR-15-style rifle during the rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, wounding the former president's ear, killing one rally attendee and wounding two others. Secret Service snipers killed Crooks after he opened fire.\n\nLoner with no friends\n\nInvestigators have described Crooks as a loner with no close friends and a social network limited mainly to immediate family members.\n\nThe first shooting of a US president or major party candidate in more than four decades was a glaring security lapse that led last week to former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle's resignation under bipartisan congressional pressure.\n\nHer immediate successor, Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe, told lawmakers that he visited the outdoor rally site in Butler and climbed onto the roof of a nearby building from which Crooks fired.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe told a joint hearing of the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees. \"As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nRowe sought to assure lawmakers that he has since taken steps to prevent similar lapses from occurring amid concerns among both Democrats and Republicans about further political violence as the campaign intensifies ahead of the November 5 US election.\n\nCrooks flew a drone near the rally site ahead of his assassination attempt, a flight that officials failed to detect because a system designed to detect drones was not working properly due to problems with cellular network bandwidth, Rowe said.\n\nThe Secret Service, a federal law enforcement agency whose duties include protecting the president and certain other top political figures, has added six people to its protection list since July 13, including Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance and his family and independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy, while reinforcing security details, Rowe said.\n\n\"This attack was a shocking reminder that the threat of political violence is alive and well in our country. By all accounts, this was inexcusable security and planning failure,\" Democratic Senate Homeland Security Chairman Gary Peters said, adding that his panel is working on reforms to strengthen security protocols for the Secret Service.\n\nSenator Rand Paul, the committee's top Republican, said his staff had found communication gaps between local police who first noticed Crooks and the Secret Service.\n\nRowe said that Secret Service counter snipers and members of the Trump security detail had no knowledge that there was a man with a firearm on the roof of a nearby building.\n\nThe {"uri": "8250496472", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "11:05:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T11:05:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T11:05:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13687817/Secret-Service-deputy-grilled-Senate-Trump-assassination-bid.html", "title": "Secret Service deputy to be grilled in Senate over Trump...", "body": "Senate politicians are expected to grill the acting director of the Secret Service on Tuesday about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRonald Rowe became acting director of the agency last week after his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by legislators from both parties and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nMr Rowe will be joined by FBI deputy director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nMembers of the House Oversight and Accountability Committee prepare to question US Secret Service director Kimberly Cheatle about the attempted assassination (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite)\n\nThe FBI also said that Mr Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim; the bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one.\n\nMr Trump said on Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut the bulk of the questions on Tuesday are expected to be directed at Mr Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Mr Trump.\n\nInvestigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Mr Trump's direction using an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters from where Mr Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Ms Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Mr Trump.\n\nShe called the attempt on Mr Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there is no repeat of it.\n\nMs Cheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person up to five times before the shooting at the rally.\n\nShe also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nMs Cheatle said she apologised to Mr Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News, Mr Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good
