"https://img.resized.co/breaking--service-deputy-to-be-grilled-in-senate-over-trump-assassination-bid.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9772518", "eventUri": "eng-9772518", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-13", "textStart": 574, "textEnd": 581}], "sentiment": -0.2784313725490196, "wgt": 196, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8252240628", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:28:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:28:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:27:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://abc7news.com/post/takeaways-senate-hearing-trump-assassination-attempt-secret-service-failure/15126089/", "title": "Takeaways from Senate hearing on Trump assassination attempt and Secret Service failure", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Secret Service acting Director Ronald Rowe provided new details about the assassination attempt of Donald Trump on Tuesday, delivering forceful testimony at a Senate hearing about the agency's failures earlier this month in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nBut at the joint hearing of the Judiciary and Homeland Security committees, Rowe also highlighted the missteps of local law enforcement on July 13, when the former president was shot.\n\nRowe testified that Secret Service agents on Trump's security detail, as well as snipers on duty, were not told that the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, was positioned on a nearby roof with a rifle and only learned of his presence after he started shooting.\n\nFederal investigators are looking into a YouTube account possibly connected to Crooks in which the user espoused political violence as well as antisemitic and anti-immigration themes, a source familiar with the investigation tells CNN. Deputy FBI Director Paul Abbate described the account but did not reveal the platform at the hearing.\n\nThe hearing was the fourth such one held on Capitol Hill since the assassination attempt, and though it grew testy at times, especially during some exchanges with Republican senators, lawmakers appeared largely satisfied with the information provided by Rowe and Abbate during their more than three hours of testimony.\n\nOverall, it stood in stark contrast with a House hearing held last week in which lawmakers grilled then-Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle over what went wrong earlier this month, with several members demanding she resign over the lapses. A day later, she did just that.\n\nHere are the takeaways from Tuesday's joint hearing:\n\nDuring Tuesday's hearing, Rowe highlighted the failures of communications during the rally, in Butler, saying that information about Crooks was \"siloed\" and \"stuck\" in local law enforcement channels.\n\n\"The only thing we had was that locals were working an issue at the three o'clock - which would have been the former president's right-hand side - which is where the shot came,\" Rowe said. \"Nothing about man on the roof, nothing about man with a gun. None of that information ever made it over our net.\"\n\nHomeland Security Committee Chairman Gary Peters said that local law enforcement has claimed they were \"only able to call in to a state command center\" and not able to easily communicate threats to the Secret Service.\n\nBut Peters also noted that Abbate testified during the hearing that \"there was about 30 seconds between when the local law enforcement reported that there was a man on the roof with a gun\" and when the shooter began firing.\n\n\"If it's communicated directly to a counter-sniper team, would that be enough time to react prior to the firing of those shots?\" Peters asked.\n\n\"If we'd had that information, they would have been able to address it more quickly,\" Rowe replied. \"It appears that that information was stuck or siloed in that local channel.\"\n\n\"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have,\" he said. \"We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nCrooks was killed within 15.5 seconds of the first shot, Rowe said.\n\nRowe confirmed that the reason a counter-drone system was not deployed at the Butler rally earlier in the day was because of connectivity issues.\n\n\"On this day in particular, because of the connectivity challenge ... there was a delay,\" he said. Crooks flew his own drone around the area two hours before Trump took the stage.\n\nThe issue has \"cost me a lot of sleep,\" Rowe said. \"What if we would have geolocated him because that counter (unmanned aircraft system) platform would have been up.\"\n\nRowe said that had the system been up, law enforcement may have been able to see Crooks' use of his own drone and approached him well before the shooting.\n\nMoving forward, Rowe said, his agency will use drones to help better secure future events.\n\n\"It is clear to me that other protective enhancements could have strengthened our security at the Butler event,\" he told lawmakers. \"As such, I have directed the expanded use of unmanned aerial systems at protective sites to help detect threats on roofs and other elevated threats.\"\n\nThe acting director also said that the Secret Service will now work with the Department of Homeland Security to set up their own, private connection and not rely on public domain connections.\n\nThe rally also did not deploy a Secret Service counter surveillance unit that would be dedicated to observing and tracking suspicious people like Crooks, according to multiple sources familiar with the operation.\n\nA law enforcement source told CNN the counter surveillance units were not requested as part of the plan put together by the Secret Service. The source said the units are not typically used for protection of former presidents.\n\nAs lawmakers pressed Rowe for answers on what went wrong earlier this month, the interim Secret Service director sought to shirk some of the responsibility for the security lapses, partially blaming the issues on the local law enforcement officers with whom they were working.\n\nMoving forward, Rowe told the committees, his agency will avoid assuming local law enforcement agencies are fully capable of fulfilling their role in protecting an event.\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said of the area where Crooks climbed up the side of a building near the rally with his rifle.\n\n\"We made an assumption,\" he said, explaining that the Secret Service believed there would be sufficient eyes to cover the area and that local law enforcement would have a counter sniper in the AGR building where Crooks took his position.\n\nRowe told the lawmakers that local law enforcement was positioned in a nearby building and should have had a clear line of sight of Crooks on the roof.\n\n\"I cannot understand why there was not better coverage or at least somebody looking at that roofline when that's where they were posted,\" Rowe said, noting that a local sniper team could have looked from their post and seen the would-be assassin.\n\n\"Looking left, why was the assailant not seen?\" Rowe asked of the local team, as he showed lawmakers photographs of the roofs snipers were positioned on.\n\n\"I'm not saying that they should have neutralized him, but if they'd have held their post and looked left maybe...\" Rowe said later, though he was quickly cut off by an unrelated comment.\n\nSeveral senators lambasted Rowe for not firing any members in his agency and over the amount of security provided to former President Trump compared to President Joe Biden.\n\nIn one such exchange, Rowe loudly objected to Sen. Josh Hawley's persistent questions about why individuals weren't fired in recent weeks.\n\n\"I will not rush to judgment. People will be held accountable,\" Rowe said, adding that investigations into the failures that day are ongoing.\n\nThe Missouri Republican responded: \"Is it not prima facie that somebody has failed? The former president was shot.\"\n\n\"Sir, this could have been our Texas School Book Depository,\" Rowe responded, referring to the 1963 assassination of President John F. Kennedy in Dallas. \"I have lost sleep over that for the last 17 days, just like you have.\"\n\n\"Then fire somebody,\" Hawley shouted, to which Rowe replied: \"We have to be able to have a proper investigation into this.\"\n\nAt another point during Tuesday's hearing, Republican Sen. Ted Cruz repeatedly pressed Rowe on why Trump doesn't receive the same security level as Biden.\n\n\"There is a difference between the sitting president of the United States,\" Rowe said.\n\n\"Then what's the difference,\" Cruz yelled, cutting Rowe off.\n\n\"The difference - national command authority to launch a nuclear strike, sir,\" Rowe responded. \"There are other assets that travel with the president that the former president will not get.\"\n\nInvestigators have uncovered a social media account with posts espousing political violence that may be connected to the would-be Trump assassin, Abbate said.\n\nOfficials have repeatedly said that they have struggled to understand what the 20-year-old shooter's motive was, and that they are combing his online presence for more information.\n\n\"Something just very recently uncovered that I want to share is a social media account, which is believed to be associated with this with the shooter - in about the 2019, 2020 timeframe,\" Abbate said.\n\nOn that account, \"there were over 700 comments,\" Abbate said, which, \"if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes, to espouse political violence, and are described as extreme in nature.\"\n\nCNN has learned the account is on the YouTube platform.\n\nA separate account on the platform Gab - which was made years earlier - appears to have \"differing points of view,\" Abbate added.\n\nGab CEO Andrew Tobra revealed last week that the would-be assassin may have had an account on the site, which is an alternative social media network popular with conservatives, the alt-right and some extremists. Tobra claimed that the account in question was \"pro-Biden.\"\n\nThe Gab account has also not been conclusively connected to Crooks.", "source": {"uri": "abc7news.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ABC7 News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Peters", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Gary Peters"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F. {"uri": "8250998751", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:22:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:22:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:21:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.livemint.com/news/world/donald-trumps-shooter-thomas-crooks-posted-antisemitic-and-anti-immigration-content-online-fbi-11722355328886.html", "title": "Donald Trump's shooter Thomas Crooks posted 'antisemitic and anti-immigration' content online: FBI | Today News", "body": "Crooks, who was 20, shot at Trump with an AR-15-style rifle during the rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, wounding the former president's ear, killing one rally attendee and wounding two others. Secret Service snipers killed Crooks after he opened fire.\n\nThe man who tried to assassinate Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump appears to have posted violent antisemitic and anti-immigration content online as a teenager, a senior FBI official told a US Senate hearing on Tuesday.\n\nFBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at the hearing revealed the existence of the social media account, which dated to 2019-2020 - when Thomas Crooks, who authorities have identified as the shooter, would have been 15 or 16 years old. It is some of the first evidence to become public about a potential motive in the July 13 attack at a campaign rally in western Pennsylvania.\n\n\"Something just very recently uncovered that I want to share is a social media account which is believed to be associated with the shooter in about the 2019-2020 time frame,\" Abbate told lawmakers, adding that more than 700 comments were posted by the account.\n\n\"Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature,\" Abbate said.\n\nCrooks, who was 20, shot at Trump with an AR-15-style rifle during the rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, wounding the former president's ear, killing one rally attendee and wounding two others. Secret Service snipers killed Crooks after he opened fire.\n\nInvestigators have described Crooks as a loner with no close friends and a social network limited mainly to immediate family members.\n\nThe first shooting of a U.S. president or major party candidate in more than four decades was a glaring security lapse that led last week to former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle's resignation under bipartisan congressional pressure.\n\nHer immediate successor, Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe, told lawmakers that he visited the outdoor rally site in Butler and climbed onto the roof of a nearby building from which Crooks fired.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe told a joint hearing of the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees. \"As a career law enforcement officer, and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nRowe sought to assure lawmakers that he has since taken steps to prevent similar lapses from occurring amid concerns among both Democrats and Republicans about further political violence as the campaign intensifies ahead of the Nov. 5 U.S. election.\n\nCrooks flew a drone near the rally site ahead of his assassination attempt, a flight that officials failed to detect because a system designed to detect drones was not working properly due to problems with cellular network bandwidth, Rowe said.\n\nThe Secret Service, a federal law enforcement agency whose duties including protecting the president and certain other top political figures, has added six people to its protection list since July 13, including Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance and his family and independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy, while reinforcing security details, Rowe said.\n\n\"This attack was a shocking reminder that the threat of political violence is alive and well in our country. By all accounts, this was inexcusable security, and planning failure,\" Democratic Senate Homeland Security Chairman Gary Peters said, adding that his panel is working on reforms to strengthen security protocols for the Secret Service.\n\nSenator Rand Paul, the committee's top Republican, said his staff had found communication gaps between local police who first noticed Crooks and the Secret Service.\n\nRowe said that Secret Service counter snipers and members of the Trump security detail had no knowledge that there was a man with a firearm on the roof of a nearby building.\n\nThe attempted assassination is the topic of multiple investigations by House and Senate committees, as well as a new bipartisan task force.", "source": {"uri": "livemint.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nPeople are also reading... Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9772518", "eventUri": "eng-9772518", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Washington, D.C."}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": {"uri": "2024-07-438702843", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:18:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:18:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:13:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/30/politics/takeaways-from-the-senate-hearing-on-the-trump-shooting-and-secret-service-failure/index.html", "title": "Takeaways from the Senate hearing on the Trump assassination attempt and Secret Service failure | CNN Politics", "body": "Acting Director of the US Secret Service Ronald Rowe and and Deputy Director of the FBI Paul Abbate appear before a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, on Capitol Hill in Washington, DC, on July 30.\n\nWashington CNN --\n\nSecret Service acting Director Ronald Rowe provided new details about the assassination attempt of Donald Trump on Tuesday, delivering forceful testimony at a Senate hearing about the agency's failures earlier this month in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nBut at the joint hearing of the Judiciary and Homeland Security committees, Rowe also highlighted the missteps of local law enforcement on July 13, when the former president was shot.\n\nRowe testified that Secret Service agents on Trump's security detail, as well as snipers on duty, were not told that the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, was positioned on a nearby roof with a rifle and only learned of his presence after he started shooting.\n\nThe hearing was the fourth such one held on Capitol Hill since the assassination attempt, and though it grew testy at times, especially during some exchanges with Republican senators, lawmakers appeared largely satisfied with the information provided by Rowe and Deputy FBI Director Paul Abbate during their more than three hours of testimony.\n\nOverall, it stood in stark contrast with a House hearing held last week in which lawmakers grilled then-Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle over what went wrong earlier this month, with several members demanding she resign over the lapses. A day later, she did just that.\n\nHere are the takeaways from Tuesday's joint hearing:\n\n'Siloed' information about Crooks' presence\n\nDuring Tuesday's hearing, Rowe highlighted the failures of communications during the rally, in Butler, saying that information about Crooks was \"siloed\" and \"stuck\" in local law enforcement channels.\n\n\"The only thing we had was that locals were working an issue at the three o'clock - which would have been the former president's right-hand side - which is where the shot came,\" Rowe said. \"Nothing about man on the roof, nothing about man with a gun. None of that information ever made it over our net.\"\n\nHomeland Security Committee Chairman Gary Peters said that local law enforcement has claimed they were \"only able to call in to a state command center\" and not able to easily communicate threats to the Secret Service.\n\nVideo Ad Feedback\n\nHawley has tense exchange with Secret Service official\n\n01:30 - Source: CNN\n\nBut Peters also noted that Abbate testified during the hearing that \"there was about 30 seconds between when the local law enforcement reported that there was a man on the roof with a gun\" and when the shooter began firing.\n\n\"If it's communicated directly to a counter-sniper team, would that be enough time to react prior to the firing of those shots?\" Peters asked.\n\n\"If we'd had that information, they would have been able to address it more quickly,\" Rowe replied. \"It appears that that information was stuck or siloed in that local channel.\"\n\n\"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have,\" he said. \"We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nCrooks was killed within 15.5 seconds of the first shot, Rowe said.\n\nCounter-drone system could have prevented the attack\n\nRowe confirmed that the reason a counter-drone system was not deployed at the Butler rally earlier in the day was because of connectivity issues.\n\n\"On this day in particular, because of the connectivity challenge ... there was a delay,\" he said. Crooks flew his own drone around the area two hours before Trump took the stage.\n\nThe issue has \"cost me a lot of sleep,\" Rowe said. \"What if we would have geolocated him because that counter (unmanned aircraft system) platform would have been up.\"\n\nRowe said that had the system been up, law enforcement may have been able to see Crooks' use of his own drone and approached him well before the shooting.\n\nMoving forward, Rowe said, his agency will use drones to help better secure future events.\n\n\"It is clear to me that other protective enhancements could have strengthened our security at the Butler event,\" he told lawmakers. \"As such, I have directed the expanded use of unmanned aerial systems at protective sites to help detect threats on roofs and other elevated threats.\"\n\nThe acting director also said that the Secret Service will now work with the Department of Homeland Security to set up their own, private connection and not rely on public domain connections.\n\nRowe points fingers at local law enforcement\n\nAs lawmakers pressed Rowe for answers on what went wrong earlier this month, the interim Secret Service director sought to shirk some of the responsibility for the security lapses, partially blaming the issues on the local law enforcement officers with whom they were working.\n\nMoving forward, Rowe told the committees, his agency will avoid assuming local law enforcement agencies are fully capable of fulfilling their role in protecting an event.\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said of the area where Crooks climbed up the side of a building near the rally with his rifle.\n\n\"We made an assumption,\" he said, explaining that the Secret Service believed there would be sufficient eyes to cover the area and that local law enforcement would have a counter sniper in the AGR building where Crooks took his position.\n\nRowe told the lawmakers that local law enforcement was positioned in a nearby building and should have had a clear line of sight of Crooks on the roof.\n\n\"I cannot understand why there was not better coverage or at least somebody looking at that roofline when that's where they were posted,\" Rowe said, noting that a local sniper team could have looked from their post and seen the would-be assassin.\n\n\"Looking left, why was the assailant not seen?\" Rowe asked of the local team, as he showed lawmakers photographs of the roofs snipers were positioned on.\n\n\"I'm not saying that they should have neutralized him, but if they'd have held their post and looked left maybe...\" Rowe said later, though he was quickly cut off by an unrelated comment.\n\nShouting matches over firings and Biden v. Trump resources\n\nSeveral senators lambasted Rowe for not firing any members in his agency and over the amount of security provided to former President Trump compared to President Joe Biden.\n\nIn one such exchange, Rowe loudly objected to Sen. Josh Hawley's persistent questions about why individuals weren't fired in recent weeks.\n\n\"I will not rush to judgment. People will be held accountable,\" Rowe said, adding that investigations into the failures that day are ongoing.\n\nThe Missouri Republican responded: \"Is it not prima facie that somebody has failed? The former president was shot.\"\n\n\"Sir, this could have been our Texas School Book Depository,\" Rowe responded, referring to the 1963 assassination of President John F. Kennedy in Dallas. \"I have lost sleep over that for the last 17 days, just like you have.\"\n\nVideo Ad Feedback\n\n'Stop interrupting me': Cruz gets in heated exchange with Secret Service official\n\n01:55 - Source: CNN\n\n\"Then fire somebody,\" Hawley shouted, to which Rowe replied: \"We have to be able to have a proper investigation into this.\"\n\nAt another point during Tuesday's hearing, Republican Sen. Ted Cruz repeatedly pressed Rowe on why Trump doesn't receive the same security level as Biden.\n\n\"There is a difference between the sitting president of the United States,\" Rowe said.\n\n\"Then what's the difference,\" Cruz yelled, cutting Rowe off.\n\n\"The difference - national command authority to launch a nuclear strike, sir,\" Rowe responded. \"There are other assets that travel with the president that the former president will not get.\"\n\nCrooks' online presence\n\nInvestigators have uncovered a social media account with posts espousing political violence that may be connected to the would-be Donald Trump assassin, Abbate said.\n\nOfficials have repeatedly said that they have struggled to understand what the 20-year-old shooter's motive was, and that they are combing his online presence for more information.\n\n\"Something just very recently uncovered that I want to share is a social media account, which is believed to be associated with this with the shooter - in about the 2019, 2020 timeframe,\" Abbate said.\n\nOn that account, \"there were over 700 comments,\" Abbate said, which, \"if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes, to espouse political violence, and are described as extreme in nature.\"\n\nA separate account on the platform Gab - which was made years earlier - appears to have \"differing points of view,\" Abbate added.\n\nGab CEO Andrew Tobra revealed last week that the would-be assassin may have had an account on the site, which is an alternative social media network popular with conservatives, the alt-right and some extremists. Tobra claimed that the account in question was \"pro-Biden.\"\n\nThe Gab account has also not been conclusively connected to Crooks.", "source": {"uri": "cnn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNN"}, {"uri": "8251063863", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:10:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:10:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:10:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.newser.com/story/353669/acting-secret-service-director-cannot-defend-the-lapse.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service Director 'Ashamed' by What He Saw", "body": "The acting director of the Secret Service said Tuesday he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Trump was not secured. Ronald Rowe, testifying before two Senate committees, said he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and \"What I saw made me ashamed.\" The FBI's No. 2 official, Paul Abbate, said a social media account associated with the gunman espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment, reports the AP. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when Thomas Matthew Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings. Rowe became acting director last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the July 13 shooting. Rowe is being joined by Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security. \"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again. Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. In a Monday interview on Fox News, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks. \"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said. He praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\" (More Trump rally shooting stories.)", "source": {"uri": "newser.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newser"}, "authors": [{"uri": "polly_davis_doig@newser.com", "name": "Polly Davis Doig", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251065245", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:13:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:13:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:11:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13689597/secret-service-director-ronald-rowe-josh-hawley.html", "title": "Senator demands to know why no one has been fired at Secret Service", "body": "By Morgan Phillips, Congress Reporter On Capitol Hill For Dailymail.Com\n\nA high-profile hearing descended into chaos when Sen. Josh Hawley pressed acting Secret Service director Ronald Rowe on why no one had been fired for the security breach yet.\n\n'Has the person who decided, who made the decision to send Donald Trump on stage knowing that you had a security situation. Has that person been relieved of duty?' Hawley, R-Mo., asked.\n\n'No sir they haven't,' said Rowe.\n\n'Has the person who decided not to pull the former president off of stage when you knew that in your words, the locals were working a serious security situation? Has that person been relieved of duty?'\n\nA high-profile hearing descended into chaos when Sen. Josh Hawley pressed acting Secret Service director Ronald Rowe on why no one had been fired for the security breach yet\n\n'Has the person who decided, who made the decision to send Donald Trump on stage knowing that you had a security situation. Has that person been relieved of duty?' Hawley, R-Mo., asked. 'No sir they haven't,' said Rowe\n\n'No, sir. Again, I refer you back to my original answer that we are investigating this through a mission assurance -- ' Rowe said.\n\n' -- What more do you need to investigate? To know exactly what you need to investigate to know the failures that something ought to be held accountable? What more do you need to know?' Hawley interjected.\n\n'You're asking me, Senator, to completely make a rush to judgment about somebody failing. I acknowledge this was a failure,' Rowe went on.\n\n'Sir, this could have been our Texas School Book Depository,' he said, in reference to the building from which Lee Harvey Oswald fatally shot President John F. Kennedy.\n\n'I have lost sleep over that for the last 17 days. I will tell you Senator, that I will not rush a judgment, that people will be held accountable, and I will do so with integrity and not rush to judgment and put people unfairly persecuted. We have to be able to have a proper investigation into this.'\n\nIn another fraught moment Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, asked Rowe whether Trump's team had been given the same amount of protection resources as a comparable Biden event.\n\n'You're using president a way that it's not clear. Is it your testimony that in Butler Pennsylvania, Donald Trump had the same number of agents protecting him that Joe Biden has at a comparable event?\n\n'You asked me senator and I'm trying to answer it.'\n\n'You are not answering it. Is it the same number of agents or not?' Cruz went on.\n\n'There is a difference between the sitting President of the United States,' Rowe shot back. 'What's the difference?'\n\n'The difference is an actual authority to launch a nuclear strike,' said Rowe.\n\nBut Rowe confusingly also said that Trump had the same number of agents surrounding him as Joe Biden has, a 'full shift.'\n\nRowe admitted he had no defense as for why the rooftop where Thomas Matthew Crooks fired shots toward former President Trump was left open.\n\nCrooks fired eight rounds toward Trump from a nearby unsecured rooftop, killing firefighter veteran Corey Comperatore, critically injuring two and grazing Trump with a bullet in his ear.\n\n'I went to the roof of the AGR building where the assailant fired shots, and I laid in a prone position to evaluate his line of sight. What I saw made me ashamed as a career law enforcement officer and a 25 year veteran with the Secret Service. I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured,' he told Congress on Tuesday.\n\n'When I laid in that position I could not, will not understand why there was not better coverage or at least somebody looking at that roof line when that's where they were posted,' Rowe said, noting that Crooks' head would have been clearly visible from the unmanned rooftop.\n\nFormer Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle had been criticized for not visiting the rally site prior to her hearing on Capitol Hill last week, which prompted her resignation.\n\nActing Director Rowe and Deputy FBI Director Paul Abbate testified in a rare joint Senate hearing on Tuesday.\n\nThirty seconds before Crooks fired his shots, local law enforcement had radioed to Secret Service warning about a man with a rifle on the roof. Around three and a half minutes before that, he'd been 'observed on the roof.'\n\nActing Director Rowe and Deputy Secret Service Director Paul Abbate testified in a rare joint Senate hearing on Tuesday\n\nLaw enforcement 'should've been on that roof and the fact that they were in the building is something that I'm still trying to understand,' Rowe said when Sen. Josh Hawley, R-Mo., pressed him on whistleblower reports that law enforcement was supposed to be stationed on the roof but was not up there because it was 'too hot.'\n\nAbbate revealed that the FBI had identified a social media account they believed belonged to the shooter\n\n'In about the 2019, 2020 time frame, there were over 700 comments posted from this account. Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect anti-Semitic and anti-immigrant themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature,' Abbate said.\n\nRowe said that since the shooting he'd implemented a number of changes at the Secret Service, including having security plans go through multiple supervisors before implementation, expanded use of drones, more resources for protective site communications and 'expeditious' approval of requests for personnel at protective sites with heightened security environments.\n\nRowe and Abbate spoke to the Judiciary and Homeland Security committees after their boss, Cheatle submitted her resignation last week after a six-hour-long hearing where Republicans and Democrats accused her of stonewalling.\n\nTrump assassination attempt timeline, according to Secret Service acting director\n\nJuly 7: Crooks travels to rally site to spend 20 minutes doing reconnaissance\n\nJuly 12: Shooter visits Clairton Sportsmen's Club to practice shooting\n\nJuly 13, 10 a.m.: Shooter visits rally site again\n\n90 minutes before shooting: local law enforcement 'suspicious' of Crooks\n\n20 minutes before Trump takes stage, 30 minutes before shooting: Secret Service made aware of an individual with a rangefinder\n\n10 minutes before Trump takes stage, 20 minutes before shooting: Secret Service counter sniper team given photograph of the 'suspicious subject'\n\n3.5 minutes before shooting: Crooks spotted on the roof\n\n30 seconds before shooting: Crooks seen with a gun\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn his opening statement the Homeland Security Committee's top Republican Rand Paul revealed that local law enforcement had told his office they'd warned the Secret Service about the vulnerabilities of the rooftop where Thomas Matthew Crooks fired shots at the president.\n\n'Local law enforcement told my staff that they specifically flagged the vulnerability of the building to the Secret Service, and were told that it would be taken care of. Clearly, these vulnerabilities were not addressed.'\n\nJudiciary Chairman Dick Durbin, D-Ill., asked why more action wasn't taken when Crooks was seen to be holding a range finder 30 minutes before the shooting.\n\n'I thought I had read that it was a golf range finder. Nonetheless, it still would have provided him the ability to provide the distance that he was away from his intended target.'\n\n'Wasn't that enough?' Durbin asked.\n\n'As far as raising suspicion, yes I think.'\n\nIn another heated moment, Sen. Josh Hawley, R-Mo., pressed Rowe on why no one had been fired for the security breach yet.\n\n'Has the Person who decided, who made the decision to send Donald Trump on stage knowing that you had a security situation. Has that person been relieved of duty?' Hawley asked.\n\n'No sir they haven't,' said Rowe.\n\n'Has the person who decided not to pull the former president off of stage when you knew that in your work the locals were working a serious security situation? Has that person been relieved of duty?'\n\n'No, sir. Again, I refer you back to my original answer that we are investigating this through a mission assurance -- ' Rowe said.\n\n' -- What more do you need to investigate? To know exactly what you need to investigate to know the failures that something ought to be held accountable? What more do you need to know?' Hawley interjected.\n\n'What I need to know is exactly what happened ... I will not rush to judgment. People will be held accountable and I will do so with integrity, and not rush to judgment and put people like unfairly persecuted.'\n\nOn Monday new text messages revealed local law enforcement officers working former President Donald Trump's Butler, Pennsylvania, rally were severely understaffed ahead of the attempted assassination.\n\nDuring the tragic rally, Trump was shot in the ear and a former volunteer firefighter lost his life after 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks opened fire from the roof of a nearby building just outside the security perimeter.\n\nBombshell new text messages between the Beaver County emergency services team from the days leading up to the rally show that there was a staffing shortage.\n\nOn July 8, five days before the rally, an unnamed team leader officer wrote in a text chat that they had been 'requested by Butler to assist' with Trump's rally and needed six people to step up for the 12-hour detail. Two offered to do so for the whole time, and two more offered to split the Saturday shift.\n\nThe law enforcement leader wrote in the thread that he only had a few people available to work the event because 'everyone else is either working, on vacation or hurt.'\n\nThe never-seen-before messages also lay out a timeline of nearly 90 minutes from between the identification of Crooks and his deadly fire.\n\nNew messages, bodycam footage and law enforcement debrief were obtained by Sen. Chuck Grassley, R-Iowa, who is conducting oversight of the event.\n\nThe messages showed that law enforcement were aware of Crooks, whom they spotted more than an hour and a half before Trump took the stage.\n\nAt 4:26 p.m., a Beaver County sniper finished his shift and departed the AGR building, where Crooks was able to access and take his shots from.\n\nAs the sniper left the building, he texted a chain about a suspicious person he'd spotted - which turned out to be Crooks.\n\n'Someone followed our lead and snuck in and parked by our cars just so you know,' read one message.\n\n'I'm just letting you know because you see me go out with my rifle and put it in my car so he knows you guys are up there.'\n\nThe officer noted that he was sitting at a picnic table 'about 50 yards from the exit.'\n\n'That bike was not there when I pulled out. Maybe have them check that car,' they went on.\n\nLater on, officers exchanged photos of Crooks, who had then been marked a 'suspicious person,' at 5:38 p.m., over 30 minutes before Trump was shot.\n\n'Kid learning (sic) around building we are in. I did see him with a range finder looking towards stage. FYI. If you wanna notify SS snipers to look out.\n\nAnother officer asked what direction Crooks was headed, to which an unnamed officer replied, 'if I had to guess toward the back. Away from the event.'\n\nIt comes after a whistleblower last week revealed Secret Service stood in the way of using drone technology to survey the scene of the Butler rally where an assassin tried to shoot former President Donald Trump.\n\nHawley revealed last week that one whistleblower had told his office the night before the rally Secret Service 'repeatedly denied offers from a local law enforcement partner to utilize drone technology to secure the rally.'\n\nThe whistleblower alleged that after the shooting Secret Service 'changed course and asked the local partner to deploy the drone technology to surveil the site in the aftermath.'", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438489192", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:25:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:25:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://theeagle.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/acting-secret-service-boss-cannot-defend-why-roof-in-trump-rally-shooting-wast-secured/article_656e33bb-f98b-50f3-9326-0995c126a763.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting was't secured", "body": "Senior officials from the U.S. Secret Service and the FBI testify before the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees about the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump.\n\nWASHINGTON -- The acting director of the Secret Service says he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe is testifying Tuesday before two Senate committees. Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nHometown superhero: College Station's Brianna Hildebrand lands in 'Deadpool & Wolverine' A&M's Prager passes on Angels and will return Rudder's Kimora Maxey has run cut short at Junior Olympics Chris Johnson makes return to Bryan as football team's offensive coordinator Texas A&M announces 2024 class of distinguished alumni After closure, Village Cafe staff creates weekly food delivery business Noms of the Week Texas A&M student claims dorm mold caused adverse health effects Teen victim identified in College Station homicide A&M tennis greats Krajicek, Habib get things rolling for the Aggies in Paris Texas A&M selected for research security initiative by National Science Foundation Rudder's Kimora Maxey qualifies for girls 100-meter hurdles semifinals at Junior Olympics The Eagle's 2024 All-Brazos Valley Baseball Team BVSWMA eliminates tipping fees, saving Bryan-College Station $6M yearly Profiles of Aggies at the Paris Olympics Two arrested in high-speed chase in College Station\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\nGet Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay up-to-date on the latest in local and national government and political topics with our newsletter.\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", {"uri": "8251016556", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:35:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:35:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:35:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2024-07-30/fbi-exploring-trump-shooter-social-media", "title": "Acting Secret Service head 'ashamed' rooftop wasn't secure at rally where Trump was shot", "body": "A week after the Secret Service director's disastrous appearance before a House committee, her interim replacement and a top FBI official offered a Senate hearing a more detailed breakdown of the security failures at a rally where former President Trump was shot -- and the first potential clues about the shooter's thinking.\n\nFBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate told a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees that while the agency still could not establish a clear motive for the July 13 shooting, it is poring over a social media account that could possibly belong to the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, looking for clues.\n\nThe account includes several hundred messages with antisemitic and anti-immigration messages from 2019 and 2020 that \"espoused political violence and are described as extreme in nature,\" Abbate said.\n\nActing Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe Jr. said before the panel that the shooting \"was a failure on multiple levels\" for the agency, striking a different tone from his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, whose unresponsive and combative answers to a House committee's questions July 22 sparked bipartisan calls for her ouster. She stepped down as the head of the agency the following day.\n\nRowe said he and his investigators traveled to the Pennsylvania rally site and lay prone on the same roof where Crooks was when he shot at Trump on July 13.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe said at the hearing about the clear line of sight to the rally stage. \"I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nRowe stressed that the Secret Service has been reviewing its actions leading up to the day of the attack. Since the shooting, Rowe said, the agency has identified gaps in the security detail on the day of the rally and implemented corrective actions.\n\n\"I do not believe that inadequate time to plan for this event was a factor in the failure,\" Rowe said.\n\nAccording to Abbate, who provided a comprehensive timeline of events leading up to the shooting, the FBI has conducted over 460 interviews as part of their investigation.\n\nEvidence of the security failures included a text message thread among local police countersnipers who said they saw a suspicious person around the rally site but failed to approach him, according to reporting from the New York Times.\n\nCrooks was spotted by law enforcement up to 90 minutes before he climbed onto the roof and fired what investigators believe were eight shots at Trump.\n\nRowe emphasized that the Secret Service countersniper teams and members of Trump's security detail did not have any inkling that there was a man on the roof of the American Glass Research building armed with a gun.\n\n\"It is my understanding those personnel were not aware the assailant had a firearm until they heard gunshots,\" Rowe said.\n\nOne of the gunman's bullets grazed the former president's ear, and in the barrage of gunfire from Crooks a spectator was killed and two others were wounded. {"uri": "2024-07-439253399", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:52:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:52:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:13:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://internewscast.com/politics/the-fbi-finds-social-media-profile-connected-to-thomas-crooks-the-person-who-targeted-trump-containing-700-posts-with-disturbing-content-about-jewish-people-and-migrants/", "title": "The FBI finds social media profile connected to Thomas Crooks, the person who targeted Trump, containing 700 posts with disturbing content about Jewish people and migrants. - Internewscast Journal", "body": "The FBI revealed they found a social media account possibly tied to Trump shooter Thomas Matthew Crooks that could shine light on the motive behind his assassination attempt.\n\nSo far very little has been uncovered about Crooks and what led to his shooting of Trump, which injured others and fatally wounded former firefighter Corey Comperatore on July 13.\n\nThe bombshell developments in the investigation into the assassination attempt at Trump's Butler, Pennsylvania, rally came during a Senate hearing Tuesday.\n\nCongress dragged in the Secret Service's new acting head Ronald Rowe and the number two at the FBI, Deputy Director Paul Abbate, to testify on the shooting.\n\nAbbate revealed that at least one social media account on an unnamed platform believed to be associated with Crooks was discovered by the FBI. That account posted over 700 comments between 2019 and 2020, he added.\n\n'Some of these comments ... appear to reflect anti-Semitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence,' Abbate said.\n\nHe wouldn't confirm the name of the social media platform until after his agents could prove with 100% certainty Crooks made the posts.\n\nAbbate said the posts were 'extreme in nature,' but that the FBI is still determining whether the account actually belonged to Crooks.\n\nHe also disclosed that the agency is still working to identify and infiltrate Crooks's various 'encrypted' accounts that could shine light on his motive.\n\nThat angered Sen. Lindsey Graham who wanted more information on his. motive.\n\n'So you're telling me, the guy that took eight shots at the president, former president, has apps that we can't get into, that may if you could get into [them] reveal some relevant information.'\n\n'That is correct, senator,' the officials responded.\n\nThis concerned Graham who later pushed for better methods to infiltrate encrypted accounts.\n\n'We need a solution that provides lawful access,' the officials noted, inferring current options only provide illegal entry into Crooks's suspected accounts.\n\nIn addition to the online account discoveries, the number two man at the FBI disclosed more about the timeline behind the assassination attempt.\n\n'Approximately 25 minutes prior to the shooting, the U.S. Secret Service command post was notified of a suspicious person,' Abbate testified.\n\nThe Secret Service acting director also admitted he had no defense as for why the rooftop where Crooks fired shots toward former President Trump was left open.\n\n'I went to the roof of the AGR building where the assailant fired shots, and I laid in a prone position to evaluate his line of sight.'\n\n'What I saw made me ashamed as a career law enforcement officer and a 25 year veteran with the Secret Service. I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured,' he told Congress on Tuesday.\n\nCrooks fired eight rounds toward Trump, grazing him with a bullet in his ear.\n\n'When I laid in that position I could not, will not understand why there was not better coverage or at least somebody looking at that roof line when that's where they were posted,' Rowe said, noting that Crooks' head would have been clearly visible from the unmanned rooftop.\n\nThirty seconds before Crooks fired his shots, local law enforcement had radioed to Secret Service warning about a man with a rifle on the roof. Around three and a half minutes before that, he'd been 'observed on the roof.'\n\nRowe said that since the shooting he'd implemented a number of changes at the Secret Service, including having security plans go through multiple supervisors before implementation, expanded use of drones, more resources for protective site communications and 'expeditious' approval of requests for personnel at protective sites with heightened security environments.\n\nRowe and Abbate spoke to the Judiciary and Homeland Security committees after their boss, former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle submitted her resignation last week after a six-hour-long hearing where Republicans and Democrats accused her of stonewalling.\n\nThe FBI and Secret Service officials also disclosed a more accurate timeline of events leading up to the shooting.\n\nAlmost a week before the rally, Crooks scouted the site of the event, spending 20 minutes doing reconnaissance on the location, they shared.\n\nJust a day before the shooting Crooks went to a shooting range to practice his shot.\n\nThe morning of the July 13 rally, Crooks again visited the grounds, the officials said.\n\nAbbate and Rowe also disclosed Crooks's activity on the day of the shooting and what authorities did in response.\n\nLocal law enforcement marked Crooks as 'suspicious' 90 minutes before he opened fire, the officials shared.\n\nSecret Service was informed that the would-be assassin had a range finder 30 minutes before the shooting occurred.\n\nMinutes later, just 20 before the shooting, the Secret Service counter sniper team was given a photo of the 'suspicious suspect.'\n\nThen, 3.5 minutes before Crooks opened fire, he was spotted on the roof.\n\nThe officials also disclosed that Crooks was seen with a gun on the roof 30 seconds before firing his first shot.\n\n'Within 15.5 seconds of his first shot, he's neutralized,' Rowe testified about how quickly Crooks was killed after opening fire.\n\nBut prior to his first shot Secret Service was unaware of his location, the Secret Service acting chief added.\n\nHe noted that the counter snipers did not see him because he was initially hiding on the other side of the roof.\n\n'I believe he was obscured by that roof,' Rowe testified.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Internewscast Journal"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-07-438512778", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:47:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:47:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:42:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/us-secret-service-acting-director-ashamed-about-trump-shooting-9485371/", "title": "US Secret Service acting director 'ashamed' about Trump shooting | World News - The Indian Express", "body": "Investigators have still not discovered Crooks' motive, but FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate testified that they have newly found a social media account dating to 2019-2020 that appeared to be linked to the shooter.\n\nThe US Secret Service's new acting director said on Tuesday he is \"ashamed\" of a major security lapse that preceded the July 13 attempted assassination of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump at a Pennsylvania campaign rally.\n\nIn testimony before two Senate committees, Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe said he visited the outdoor rally site in Butler and climbed onto the roof of a nearby building from which 20-year-old Thomas Crooks fired shots that wounded Trump's right ear, killed one rally attendee and wounded two others, with an AR-15-style rifle.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe told a joint hearing of the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees. \"As a career law enforcement officer, and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nInvestigators have still not discovered Crooks' motive, but FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate testified that they have newly found a social media account dating to 2019-2020 that appeared to be linked to the shooter.\n\n\"There were over 700 comments posted from this account,\" Abbate said. \"Some of these comments appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature.\"\n\nRowe's admission of a glaring security lapse came a week after former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned under bipartisan congressional pressure after refusing to detail security shortfalls in testimony before a House of Representatives panel.\n\nRowe sought to assure lawmakers that he has since taken steps to prevent similar lapses from occurring amid concerns among both Democrats and Republicans about further political violence as the campaign intensifies ahead of the Nov. 5 US election.\n\nThe Secret Service, a federal law enforcement agency whose duties including protecting the president and certain other top political figures, has added six people to its protection list since July 13, including Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance and his family and independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy, while reinforcing security details, Rowe said.\n\nAlso read | Trump agrees to 'victim interview' as part of FBI probe into July 13 rally shooting\n\n\"This attack was a shocking reminder that the threat of political violence is alive and well in our country. By all accounts, this was inexcusable security, and planning failure,\" Democratic Senate Homeland Security Chairman Gary Peters said, adding that his panel is working on reforms to strengthen security protocols for the Secret Service.\n\nSenator Rand Paul, the committee's top Republican, said his staff had found communication gaps between local police who first noticed Crooks and the Secret Service.\n\nRowe said that Secret Service counter snipers and members of the Trump security detail had no knowledge that there was a man with a firearm on the roof of a nearby building.\n\nAlso read | What is the US Secret Service, tasked with protecting US Presidents, current and former\n\nThe attempted assassination is the topic of multiple investigations by House and Senate committees, as well as a new bipartisan task force established by Republican House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nInvestigators have been unable to determine a clear motive for Crooks, who they have described as a loner with no close friends and a social network limited mainly to immediate family members. Much interest revolves around the timeline from when law enforcement officials first noticed Crooks to when Secret Service snipers killed him after he opened fire.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438809711", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:58:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:58:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:57:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.eadt.co.uk/news/national/24486444.secret-service-deputy-grilled-senate-trump-assassination-bid/", "title": "Secret Service deputy grilled in Senate over Trump assassination bid", "body": "The Secret Service's acting director told legislators on Tuesday that he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former US president Donald Trump was unsecured.\n\nRonald Rowe Jr also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and lay down on the roof of the building where shots were fired in order to evaluate the gunman's line of sight during the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" he said. \"As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year Secret Service veteran, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalogue to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Mr Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also pointedly criticising local law enforcement for communication breakdowns that resulted in his agency not receiving information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been seen on the roof of a building less than 150 yards from the rally stage where Mr Trump was speaking.\n\n\"Neither the Secret Service counter sniper teams nor members of the former president's security detail had any knowledge that there was a man on the roof of the building with a firearm,\" Mr Rowe said.\n\n\"It is my understanding those personnel were not aware the assailant had a firearm until they heard gunshots.\"\n\nHe said that the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination and a \"failure to challenge our assumptions\".\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Mr Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Mr Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nHe said he had implemented multiple reforms since taking over as acting director last week, including mandating that every event security plan is vetted by multiple experienced supervisors before being implemented, expanding the use of aerial drones to improve visibility of roofs and dedicating more resources to improve communications at events where the Secret Service is operating.\n\nHe said he is also directed that federal and local counter snipers work together on roofs.\n\nMr Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before the gunman was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony on Tuesday ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue.\n\nIt also suggested that Mr Rowe, with ready and generally detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from legislators from both major political parties following responses at a congressional hearing that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nTuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees was the latest in a series of congressional sessions dedicated to the law enforcement lapses and missed communications that preceded the shooting.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers had first observed a suspicious-looking man at the rally site more than an hour before the event and circulated that information, including photographs of a man who turned out to be Crooks.\n\nBut the officers ultimately lost track of Crooks, who was able to scale the roof of a building at AGR International Incorporated, a supplier of automation equipment for the glass and plastic packaging industry, and fire an estimated eight shots with an AR-15-style rife.\n\nShortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\nEven though text messages among local snipers revealed anxiety about the man, Mr Rowe said the only thing the Secret Service knew at the time of the shooting was that law enforcement was contending with a suspicious-looking man.\n\nMr Rowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress.\n\nHe assured legislators that \"people will be held accountable\".\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with deputy director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment.\n\nThe posts were from the 2019-2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nMr Abbate did not identify the social media platform, saying investigators were still trying to definitively determine that it belonged to Crooks.\n\nHowever, he indicated that it was separate from an account on a different platform called Gab that was active in 2021.\n\nThe chief executive of Gab posted on X, formerly known as Twitter, during the Senate hearing that Crooks's presence on that platform was consistent with being \"pro-Biden and in particular pro-Biden's immigration policy\".\n\nOn Monday, the FBI revealed that Crooks had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister Robert Fico.\n\nThe FBI also said that Mr Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim.", "source": {"uri": "eadt.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8251177675", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:44:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:44:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:42:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/secret-agents-could-fired-trump-183200431.html", "title": "Secret Service agents could be fired after Trump shooting, acting director says", "body": "The acting director of the Secret Service testified Tuesday that he was \"ashamed\" at the security gaps that led to the assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump and pledged to discipline any agents who failed to do their jobs.\n\nDuring a rare joint Senate committee hearing, acting Director Ronald Rowe Jr. said he could not understand or defend why the roof where the 20-year-old shooter fired from on July 13 was not better secured.\n\nHe said the Secret Service was investigating whether any employees broke any rules that day. Those employees, Rowe said, would be held accountable through the agency's disciplinary process and face penalties that could include termination.\n\n\"That roof should have had better coverage,\" he said, \"and we will get to the bottom of if there were any policy violations.\"\n\nRowe displayed bursts of anger early in his testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee and the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee as he discussed what went wrong during Trump's presidential campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nRowe said he traveled to the site of the shooting and went up on the roof to evaluate the gunman's line of sight and laid in the prone position.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" he said. \"As a career law enforcement officer, and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nAt a minimum, Rowe said, somebody should have been looking at the roof, but there was a \"failure of imagination.\"\n\nRowe raised his voice again as Sen. Tom Cotton, R-Ark., pressured him to make immediate terminations. Rowe said he would not do so, or rush judgement, until a proper investigation is completed.\n\n\"You're asking me, senator, to completely make a rush to judgment about somebody failing,\" Rowe said.\n\nRowe said he would take disciplinary action as warranted and \"with integrity.\"\n\n\"This was a failure and we will get to the bottom of it,\" he said.\n\nTuesday's hearing is the latest in a series that lawmakers have held to investigate how Thomas Crooks, 20, was able to evade law enforcement and open fire at Trump.\n\nTrump was shot in the ear, one rallygoer was killed and two others were wounded before Crooks was fatally shot by a counter-sniper with the Secret Service.\n\nRowe said an inability for all the agencies to directly communicate with each other hindered the Secret Service.\n\nLocal law enforcement confirmed Crooks was armed at about 6:11 p.m. The local officers called out the threat through a radio, but that information was not relayed to the Secret Service, Rowe said.\n\nThe Secret Service countersnipers did not have any knowledge that Crooks was armed on the roof \"until they heard gunshots,\" Rowe said.\n\nOnly about 30 seconds had passed from the time the local officer confirmed Crooks was armed to when Crooks opened fire.\n\nRowe said there was a \"delay in reporting\" and that authorities had not set up a way for all the agencies to directly communicate with each other. That process would have taken months of planning and would require \"a lot,\" he said.\n\n\"Technically you could do it, but it would take a long time to get it done,\" Rowe said.\n\nRowe was appointed acting director last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned, following a blistering House Oversight Committee hearing in which legislators skewered her over her lack of cooperation.\n\n\"I've heard your calls for accountability, and I take them very seriously,\" Rowe said.\n\nFBI deputy director Paul Abbate, who is also testifying, said investigators found a social media account that may have belonged to Crooks, which espoused anti-Semitic and anti-immigrant views and had posts about political violence.\n\nAbbate said the FBI has not yet confirmed the account belonged to Crooks. The agency still does not know a motive.\n\nLast week, FBI Director Christopher Wray testified that Crooks may have had a firearm with a collapsible stock, making it easier for him to carry and conceal the weapon.\n\nThe gunman had researched President John F. Kennedy's assassination and had previously traveled to the rally site.\n\nOn the morning of the rally, he went back to the campaign site, where he stayed for about an hour, and left that afternoon to buy 50 rounds of ammunition.\n\nWray said Crooks was back at the rally site shortly before 4 p.m., when he flew a drone about 200 yards from the main stage area.\n\nTwo hours later, witnesses began to shout about a suspicious man on the roof of a nearby building.\n\nCrooks began firing at least eight gunshots seconds after he noticed a law enforcement officer on the ground had spotted him, Wray said.\n\nThe officer had gotten a boost from a colleague and pulled his head up over the roof. Crooks pointed his gun at the officer, causing him to fall, and then started shooting at Trump, Wray said.\n\nOn Monday, Kevin Rojek, special agent in charge of the FBI's Pittsburgh field office, said Crooks was \"highly intelligent\" and made \"significant efforts to conceal his activity.\"\n\nRojek confirmed that Crooks' gun had a collapsible stock and that he climbed up the roof by scaling HVAC equipment and pipes.\n\nOn the internet, the gunman had also searched power plants, mass shootings, explosive devices, and the attempted assassination of Slovakian Prime Minister Robert Fico in May, Rojek said.\n\nCrooks bought more than 25 firearms through online vendors, using an alias, starting in the spring of 2023, Rojek said.\n\nHis father legally purchased the assault-style rifle that Crooks used in the shooting and legally transferred it to Crooks last year, Rojek said.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
