{"uri": "8251082111", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:25:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:25:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:24:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://magicvalley.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/acting-secret-service-director-says-hes-ashamed-after-the-trump-assassination-attempt/article_e64c4e28-dd12-5f05-8c50-3f811af00a2e.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting wasn't secured", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers on Tuesday that he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured, faulting local law enforcement for not circulating urgent information ahead of the shooting and for not adequately protecting the scene.\n\nHe also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and said, \"What I saw made me ashamed.\" He said that the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalogue to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also repeatedly lacing into local law enforcement for not sharing information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been spotted on a roof near the rally site in the minutes before the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nPeople are also reading... Crash in Shoshone claims life of motorcyclist Death Notices Idaho man accused of lewd conduct with Filer girl Negligent discharge of shotgun kills teenage girl near Gooding Death Notices 2 injured after Sun Valley Tour de Force crash Twin Falls man suspected of sharing child exploitative material Gooding Police Department seeks help identifying subjects Kimberly grad Zach Wright thriving in Finnish football league Haunts and scares ghost through Twin Falls The problem of theft in retail creates problems for local owners Death Notices GUEST COMMENTARY: Evil has become good in Christian America Elizabeth Boulevard and Hankins Road closed for Hankins Pressure Zone project Bradford James Craig\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots, less than 150 yards (135 meters) from the rally stage where Trump was speaking.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nTrump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before the gunman was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue. It also suggested that Rowe, with ready and detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers from both major political parties after responses that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nMuch of Tuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees focused on what Rowe suggested was inadequate information received by Secret Service personnel in the hour before the shooting, including that Crooks had been spotted on the roof.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers had spotted a suspicious-looking man pacing near the metal detectors and circulated but ultimately lost track of Crooks before he scaled the roof of a building at AGR International Inc. Shortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take responsibility.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"Isn't it the fact that the former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress, but he assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nSen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nOn Monday, the FBI revealed that Crooks had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. Trump, who appeared at events in the days after the shooting with a bandage on his right ear, said he expects the interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nAt Cheatle's hearing last week, she said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nGet Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay up-to-date on the latest in local and national government and political topics {"uri": "8250959710", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:56:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:56:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:54:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/trump-shooter-posted-violent-content-online-fbi-official-says/article_eb29be66-a1d8-50b2-99f1-890e3902bd65.html", "title": "Trump shooter posted violent content online, FBI official says", "body": "By Allende Miglietta, David Morgan and Sarah N. Lynch\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) -The man who tried to assassinate Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump appears to have posted violent antisemitic and anti-immigration content online as a teenager, a senior FBI official told a U.S. Senate hearing on Tuesday.\n\nFBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at the hearing revealed the existence of the social media account, which dated to 2019-2020 - when Thomas Crooks, who authorities have identified as the shooter, would have been 15 or 16 years old. It is some of the first evidence to become public about a potential motive in the July 13 attack at a campaign rally in western Pennsylvania.\n\n\"Something just very recently uncovered that I want to share is a social media account which is believed to be associated with the shooter in about the 2019-2020 time frame,\" Abbate told lawmakers, adding that more than 700 comments were posted by the account.\n\n\"Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature,\" Abbate said.\n\nCrooks, who was 20, shot at Trump with an AR-15-style rifle during the rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, wounding the former president's ear, killing one rally attendee and wounding two others. Secret Service snipers killed Crooks after he opened fire.\n\nInvestigators have described Crooks as a loner with no close friends and a social network limited mainly to immediate family members.\n\nThe first shooting of a U.S. president or major party candidate in more than four decades was a glaring security lapse that led last week to former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle's resignation under bipartisan congressional pressure.\n\nHer immediate successor, Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe, told lawmakers that he visited the outdoor rally site in Butler and climbed onto the roof of a nearby building from which Crooks fired.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe told a joint hearing of the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees. \"As a career law enforcement officer, and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nRowe sought to assure lawmakers that he has since taken steps to prevent similar lapses from occurring amid concerns among both Democrats and Republicans about further political violence as the campaign intensifies ahead of the Nov. 5 U.S. election.\n\nCrooks flew a drone near the rally site ahead of his assassination attempt, a flight that officials failed to detect because a system designed to detect drones was not working properly due to problems with cellular network bandwidth, Rowe said.\n\nThe Secret Service, a federal law enforcement agency whose duties including protecting the president and certain other top political figures, has added six people to its protection list since July 13, including Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance and his family and independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy, while reinforcing security details, Rowe said.\n\n\"This attack was a shocking reminder that the threat of political violence is alive and well in our country. By all accounts, this was inexcusable security, and planning failure,\" Democratic Senate Homeland Security Chairman Gary Peters said, adding that his panel is working on reforms to strengthen security protocols for the Secret Service.\n\nSenator Rand Paul, the committee's top Republican, said his staff had found communication gaps between local police who first noticed Crooks and the Secret Service.\n\nRowe said that Secret Service counter snipers and members of the Trump security detail had no knowledge that there was a man with a firearm on the roof of a nearby building.\n\nThe attempted assassination is the topic of multiple investigations by House and Senate committees, as well as a new bipartisan task force.\n\n(Reporting by David Morgan, Sarah N. Lynch and Allende Miglietta; Editing by Scott Malone and Will Dunham)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Colorado Springs Gazette"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sarah_n_lynch@gazette.com", "name": "Sarah N. {"uri": "8251075378", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:19:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:19:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:18:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://scnow.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/acting-secret-service-director-says-hes-ashamed-after-the-trump-assassination-attempt/article_93b0dda4-61d2-53d5-8d00-d58758c5407e.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting wasn't secured", "body": "U.S. Secret Service Acting Director Ronald Rowe, left, and FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate are sworn in before they testify before a Joint Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs and Senate Committee on the Judiciary hearing examining the security failures leading to the assassination attempt on Republican presidential candidate former President Donald Trump, Tuesday, July 30, 2024 in Washington.\n\nBy ERIC TUCKER Associated Press\n\nWASHINGTON -- The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers on Tuesday that he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured, faulting local law enforcement for not circulating urgent information ahead of the shooting and for not adequately protecting the scene.\n\nHe also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and said, \"What I saw made me ashamed.\" He said that the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalogue to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also repeatedly lacing into local law enforcement for not sharing information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been spotted on a roof near the rally site in the minutes before the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nPeople are also reading... New Lake City public charter school planned to open in August 2025 Bicyclist hurt in Florence crash with minivan One person dies in Tuesday Darlington County house fire SLED issues statement on July 22 fatal police shooting Florence County Animal Shelter offers adoption specials Lake City search warrants turns up drugs, guns, arrests Jordan hosting third annual back-to-school drive in Marion Florence's former Griffin Motors dealership up for sale New concept Bojangles set to open in downtown Florence Post 1 rallies for walk-off victory against Chapin/Newberry 1 dead after man fires shots at Florence officers Marion County Habitat for Humanity dedicates home in Mullins Richardson, Rogers help Post 1 shut out West Columbia Lake City man arrested in drug investigation Man wounded in Thursday night Florence shooting\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots, less than 150 yards (135 meters) from the rally stage where Trump was speaking.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nTrump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before the gunman was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue. It also suggested that Rowe, with ready and detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers from both major political parties after responses that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nMuch of Tuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees focused on what Rowe suggested was inadequate information received by Secret Service personnel in the hour before the shooting, including that Crooks had been spotted on the roof.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers had spotted a suspicious-looking man pacing near the metal detectors and circulated but ultimately lost track of Crooks before he scaled the roof of a building at AGR International Inc. Shortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take responsibility.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"Isn't it the fact that the former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress, but he assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nSen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nOn Monday, the FBI revealed that Crooks had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. Trump, who appeared at events in the days after the shooting with a bandage on his right ear, said he expects the interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nAt Cheatle's hearing last week, she said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\nGet Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay up-to-date on the latest in local and national government and political topics with our newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and {"uri": "2024-07-438672448", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:38:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:38:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:42:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/trump-security-was-unaware-of-gunman-until-shots-fired-secret-service/article_84339252-00d2-5609-b6b2-0b4d1eae5291.html", "title": "Trump security was unaware of gunman until shots fired: Secret Service", "body": "Donald Trump's security detail and a sniper team were not aware there was a gunman on a roof until he opened fire on the former president, the acting Secret Service director said Tuesday.\n\nLocal law enforcement identified the gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, as a \"suspicious person\" about 90 minutes before the July 13 attack at a Trump campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, according to FBI officials.\n\nSince the assassination attempt, questions have been raised about when the Secret Service became aware of the presence of the gunman on the roof of a building that overlooked the campaign event.\n\n\"Based on what I know right now, neither the Secret Service counter-sniper teams nor members of the former president's security detail had any knowledge that there was a man on the AGR roof with a firearm,\" acting Secret Service chief Ronald Rowe told a joint Senate committee.\n\n\"The only thing we had was that locals were working an issue at the three o'clock, which would have been the former president's right-hand side, which is where the shots came from,\" Rowe said.\n\n\"Nothing about man on the roof, nothing about man with a gun,\" he said.\n\nFBI special agent Kevin Rojek said Monday that a police officer was boosted on to the roof by another officer at 6:11 pm.\n\nCrooks pointed his rifle at the officer, who \"immediately dropped to the ground.\"\n\n\"Approximately 25 to 30 seconds after this encounter, the subject fired eight rounds before being successfully neutralized,\" Rojek said.\n\nRowe said Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service sniper \"within 15.5 seconds\" of firing the first shot.\n\nThe Republican presidential candidate was wounded in the right ear, while two rally attendees were injured and a Pennsylvania firefighter was killed.\n\n- 'Ashamed' -\n\nRowe said he \"cannot defend\" why the rooftop where Crooks fired from was not better secured, and said he was \"ashamed\" about the security lapses.\n\nHe said local law enforcement had been tasked with securing the rooftop. \"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" he said.\n\nAsked why Trump was allowed to take the stage, Rowe said Crooks had not been identified as a threat but only as suspicious.\n\n\"We did not have anything beyond suspicious person that was communicated to us,\" he said. \"Suspicion had not risen to the level of threat or imminent harm.\"\n\nRowe said communications failures between local law enforcement and the Secret Service contributed to what he called a \"failure on multiple levels.\"\n\nThe Secret Service had \"technical difficulties\" with its counter-drone capabilities on the day of the attack and they were not \"operational until after five o'clock,\" he said.\n\nCrooks flew a drone near the rally site for 11 minutes about two hours before the attack, according to the FBI.\n\nFBI deputy director Paul Abbate also addressed the committee hearing and said the authorities still have not established a motive.\n\nHe said they have identified a social media account believed to be associated with Crooks.\n\n\"In about the 2019, 2020 timeframe there were over 700 comments posted from this account,\" Abbate said. \"Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect anti-Semitic and anti-immigration themes, to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature.\"\n\nSecret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned last week after acknowledging that the agency had failed in its mission to prevent the assassination attempt.\n\ncl/bjt\n\nMore from this section\n\nFix Support Apple Com/iPhone/Restore in 5 Minutes - iOS 18 Supported\n\nPIC's WooSOS Plugin {"uri": "8250929673", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:37:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:37:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:34:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://buffalonews.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/acting-secret-service-boss-cannot-defend-why-roof-in-trump-rally-shooting-wasnt-secured/article_38024388-2621-5d94-963e-c7e82b22d056.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting wasn't secured", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The acting director of the Secret Service says he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe is testifying Tuesday before two Senate committees. Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nPeople are also reading... Kim Pegula greets Bills players, coaches after training camp practice: 'That's still the Mama Bear' Erie County prosecutor charged with misconduct, fired from DA's office Mystery still unsolved: Niagara Falls Police conclude probe into Rainbow Bridge crash that killed couple Another property near the new Bills stadium is going up for sale Bills GM Brandon Beane claps back at NFL executive who called Josh Allen 'overrated' End of an era as Rev. Jud Weiksnar departs, leaving Buffalo without Franciscans for first time in 166 years The NFL hopes its radical new kickoff rule produces excitement. Here's how it will work Under pressure: Some Bills fans feeling angst over new stadium season ticket decision 97 Rock's 'Slick Tom' Tiberi fired over Facebook meme showing Trump in coffin Kenmore East sophomore dies after being hit while riding bicycle Judge dismisses lawsuit filed by Dunkirk mother drug tested without consent at Children's Hospital Sabres sign goalie Ukko-Pekka Luukkonen to five-year, $23.75 million deal Salamanca killer Edward Kindt breaks parole, taken into custody Erie County real estate transactions Man hospitalized with severe leg injury after Chautauqua Lake boating mishap\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\n0 Comments Get Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay up-to-date on the latest in local and "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.deccanherald.com/world/us-secret-service-acting-director-ashamed-about-trump-shooting-3129226", "title": "US Secret Service acting director 'ashamed' about Trump shooting", "body": "In testimony before two Senate committees, Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe said he visited the outdoor rally site in Butler and climbed onto the roof of a nearby building from which 20-year-old Thomas Crooks fired shots that wounded Trump's right ear, killed one rally attendee and wounded two others, with an AR-15-style rifle.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe told a joint hearing of the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees. \"As a career law enforcement officer, and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nInvestigators have still not discovered Crooks' motive, but FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate testified that they have newly found a social media account dating to 2019-2020 that appeared to be linked to the shooter.\n\n\"There were over 700 comments posted from this account,\" Abbate said. \"Some of these comments appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature.\"\n\nRowe's admission of a glaring security lapse came a week after former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned under bipartisan congressional pressure after refusing to detail security shortfalls in testimony before a House of Representatives panel.\n\nRowe sought to assure lawmakers that he has since taken steps to prevent similar lapses from occurring amid concerns among both Democrats and Republicans about further political violence as the campaign intensifies ahead of the Nov. 5 US election.\n\nThe Secret Service, a federal law enforcement agency whose duties including protecting the president and certain other top political figures, has added six people to its protection list since July 13, including Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance and his family and independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy, while reinforcing security details, Rowe said.\n\n\"This attack was a shocking reminder that the threat of political violence is alive and well in our country. By all accounts, this was inexcusable security, and planning failure,\" Democratic Senate Homeland Security Chairman Gary Peters said, adding that his panel is working on reforms to strengthen security protocols for the Secret Service.\n\nSenator Rand Paul, the committee's top Republican, said his staff had found communication gaps between local police who first noticed Crooks and the Secret Service.\n\nRowe said that Secret Service counter snipers and members of the Trump security detail had no knowledge that there was a man with a firearm on the roof of a nearby building.\n\nThe attempted assassination is the topic of multiple investigations by House and Senate committees, as well as a new bipartisan task force established by Republican House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nInvestigators have been unable to determine a clear motive for Crooks, who they have described as a loner with no close friends and a social network limited mainly to immediate family members. Much interest revolves around the timeline from when law enforcement officials first noticed Crooks to when Secret Service snipers killed him after he opened fire.", "source": {"uri": of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rand_Paul", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Rand Paul"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy", "type": Kennedy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_enforcement", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Law enforcement"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Party_leaders_of_the_United_States_House_of_Representatives", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Party leaders of the United States House of Representatives"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Johnson_(Louisiana_politician)", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Mike Johnson (Louisiana politician)"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Theft", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Theft", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Activism/Strategies", "label": "dmoz/Society/Activism/Strategies", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Government_Operations", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Government Operations", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 93}], "image": "https://images.deccanherald.com/deccanherald%2F2024-07%2Fd35e2697-f577-45ce-94ea-ef5bff4bdcdd%2F2024newsmlRC2R59AO4FTA1872921932.jpeg?rect=0%2C0%2C3500%2C1838&w=1200&ar=40%3A21&auto=format%2Ccompress&ogImage=true&mode=crop", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9772518", "eventUri": "eng-9772518", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-11-05", "textStart": 1524, "textEnd": 1530}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-13", "textStart": 1737, "textEnd": 1744}], "sentiment": -0.2627450980392156, "wgt": 188, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8251290569", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:21:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:21:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:18:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://kion546.com/politics/cnn-us-politics/2024/07/30/takeaways-from-the-senate-hearing-on-the-trump-assassination-attempt-and-secret-service-failure/", "title": "Takeaways from the Senate hearing on the Trump assassination attempt and Secret Service failure - KION546", "body": "By Holmes Lybrand, Hannah Rabinowitz, Devan Cole and Tierney Sneed, CNN\n\nWashington (CNN) -- Secret Service acting Director Ronald Rowe provided new details about the assassination attempt of Donald Trump on Tuesday, delivering forceful testimony at a Senate hearing about the agency's failures earlier this month in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nBut at the joint hearing of the Judiciary and Homeland Security committees, Rowe also highlighted the missteps of local law enforcement on July 13, when the former president was shot.\n\nRowe testified that Secret Service agents on Trump's security detail, as well as snipers on duty, were not told that the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, was positioned on a nearby roof with a rifle and only learned of his presence after he started shooting.\n\nFederal investigators are looking into a YouTube account possibly connected to Crooks in which the user espoused political violence as well as antisemitic and anti-immigration themes, a source familiar with the investigation tells CNN. Deputy FBI Director Paul Abbate described the account but did not reveal the platform at the hearing.\n\nThe hearing was the fourth such one held on Capitol Hill since the assassination attempt, and though it grew testy at times, especially during some exchanges with Republican senators, lawmakers appeared largely satisfied with the information provided by Rowe and Abbate during their more than three hours of testimony.\n\nOverall, it stood in stark contrast with a House hearing held last week in which lawmakers grilled then-Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle over what went wrong earlier this month, with several members demanding she resign over the lapses. A day later, she did just that.\n\nHere are the takeaways from Tuesday's joint hearing:\n\nDuring Tuesday's hearing, Rowe highlighted the failures of communications during the rally, in Butler, saying that information about Crooks was \"siloed\" and \"stuck\" in local law enforcement channels.\n\n\"The only thing we had was that locals were working an issue at the three o'clock - which would have been the former president's right-hand side - which is where the shot came,\" Rowe said. \"Nothing about man on the roof, nothing about man with a gun. None of that information ever made it over our net.\"\n\nHomeland Security Committee Chairman Gary Peters said that local law enforcement has claimed they were \"only able to call in to a state command center\" and not able to easily communicate threats to the Secret Service.\n\nBut Peters also noted that Abbate testified during the hearing that \"there was about 30 seconds between when the local law enforcement reported that there was a man on the roof with a gun\" and when the shooter began firing.\n\n\"If it's communicated directly to a counter-sniper team, would that be enough time to react prior to the firing of those shots?\" Peters asked.\n\n\"If we'd had that information, they would have been able to address it more quickly,\" Rowe replied. \"It appears that that information was stuck or siloed in that local channel.\"\n\n\"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have,\" he said. \"We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nCrooks was killed within 15.5 seconds of the first shot, Rowe said.\n\nRowe confirmed that the reason a counter-drone system was not deployed at the Butler rally earlier in the day was because of connectivity issues.\n\n\"On this day in particular, because of the connectivity challenge ... there was a delay,\" he said. Crooks flew his own drone around the area two hours before Trump took the stage.\n\nThe issue has \"cost me a lot of sleep,\" Rowe said. \"What if we would have geolocated him because that counter (unmanned aircraft system) platform would have been up.\"\n\nRowe said that had the system been up, law enforcement may have been able to see Crooks' use of his own drone and approached him well before the shooting.\n\nMoving forward, Rowe said, his agency will use drones to help better secure future events.\n\n\"It is clear to me that other protective enhancements could have strengthened our security at the Butler event,\" he told lawmakers. \"As such, I have directed the expanded use of unmanned aerial systems at protective sites to help detect threats on roofs and other elevated threats.\"\n\nThe acting director also said that the Secret Service will now work with the Department of Homeland Security to set up their own, private connection and not rely on public domain connections.\n\nAs lawmakers pressed Rowe for answers on what went wrong earlier this month, the interim Secret Service director sought to shirk some of the responsibility for the security lapses, partially blaming the issues on the local law enforcement officers with whom they were working.\n\nMoving forward, Rowe told the committees, his agency will avoid assuming local law enforcement agencies are fully capable of fulfilling their role in protecting an event.\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said of the area where Crooks climbed up the side of a building near the rally with his rifle.\n\n\"We made an assumption,\" he said, explaining that the Secret Service believed there would be sufficient eyes to cover the area and that local law enforcement would have a counter sniper in the AGR building where Crooks took his position.\n\nRowe told the lawmakers that local law enforcement was positioned in a nearby building and should have had a clear line of sight of Crooks on the roof.\n\n\"I cannot understand why there was not better coverage or at least somebody looking at that roofline when that's where they were posted,\" Rowe said, noting that a local sniper team could have looked from their post and seen the would-be assassin.\n\n\"Looking left, why was the assailant not seen?\" Rowe asked of the local team, as he showed lawmakers photographs of the roofs snipers were positioned on.\n\n\"I'm not saying that they should have neutralized him, but if they'd have held their post and looked left maybe...\" Rowe said later, though he was quickly cut off by an unrelated comment.\n\nSeveral senators lambasted Rowe for not firing any members in his agency and over the amount of security provided to former President Trump compared to President Joe Biden.\n\nIn one such exchange, Rowe loudly objected to Sen. Josh Hawley's persistent questions about why individuals weren't fired in recent weeks.\n\n\"I will not rush to judgment. People will be held accountable,\" Rowe said, adding that investigations into the failures that day are ongoing.\n\nThe Missouri Republican responded: \"Is it not prima facie that somebody has failed? The former president was shot.\"\n\n\"Sir, this could have been our Texas School Book Depository,\" Rowe responded, referring to the 1963 assassination of President John F. Kennedy in Dallas. \"I have lost sleep over that for the last 17 days, just like you have.\"\n\n\"Then fire somebody,\" Hawley shouted, to which Rowe replied: \"We have to be able to have a proper investigation into this.\"\n\nAt another point during Tuesday's hearing, Republican Sen. Ted Cruz repeatedly pressed Rowe on why Trump doesn't receive the same security level as Biden.\n\n\"There is a difference between the sitting president of the United States,\" Rowe said.\n\n\"Then what's the difference,\" Cruz yelled, cutting Rowe off.\n\n\"The difference - national command authority to launch a nuclear strike, sir,\" Rowe responded. \"There are other assets that travel with the president that the former president will not get.\"\n\nInvestigators have uncovered a social media account with posts espousing political violence that may be connected to the would-be Trump assassin, Abbate said.\n\nOfficials have repeatedly said that they have struggled to understand what the 20-year-old shooter's motive was, and that they are combing his online presence for more information.\n\n\"Something just very recently uncovered that I want to share is a social media account, which is believed to be associated with this with the shooter - in about the 2019, 2020 timeframe,\" Abbate said.\n\nOn that account, \"there were over 700 comments,\" Abbate said, which, \"if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes, to espouse political violence, and are described as extreme in nature.\"\n\nCNN has learned the account is on the YouTube platform.\n\nA separate account on the platform Gab - which was made years earlier - appears to have \"differing points of view,\" Abbate added.\n\nGab CEO Andrew Tobra revealed last week that the would-be assassin may have had an account on the site, which is an alternative social media network popular with conservatives, the alt-right and some extremists. Tobra claimed that the account in question was \"pro-Biden.\"\n\nThe Gab account has also not been conclusively connected to Crooks.\n\nThis story has been updated with additional developments.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "2024-07-438818445", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:11:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:11:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:55:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jul/30/secret-service-chief-ashamed-shooter-able-to-fire-/", "title": "Secret Service chief 'ashamed' shooter able to fire at Trump, announces disciplinary probe", "body": "The new head of the Secret Service said he's \"ashamed\" his agency failed to secure the roof of a building in Butler, Pennsylvania, where a gunman shot at and nearly assassinated former President Donald Trump.\n\nRonald Rowe, the Secret Service's acting director, told Congress Tuesday that the agency's Office of Professional Responsibility has launched a disciplinary investigation into the actions and decision-making of its agents involved in securing the July 13 rally.\n\n\"If this investigation reveals that Secret Service employees violated agency protocols, those employees will be held accountable to our disciplinary process,\" he said.\n\nMr. Rowe also revealed the Secret Service may have been able to identify the shooter earlier and potentially stopped him if its counter-drone technology had worked as intended. Drone deployment was delayed due to cellular bandwidth issues, he said.\n\nWhile he acknowledged the Secret Service had been looped in on reports of a suspicious person with a rangefinder, Mr. Rowe said Secret Service agents were never told the person was later spotted on the roof of a nearby building with a gun until after he fired at Mr. Trump.\n\nMr. Rowe visited the site of the Butler rally, climbed onto the roof and lay in the spot where 20-year-old Matthew Thomas Crooks was positioned when he shot at least eight rounds from an AR-15, grazing Mr. Trump in the ear, killing one rallygoer and injuring two others.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Mr. Rowe said. \"I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nMr. Rowe's testimony to the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs and Judiciary committees comes a week after he was appointed to temporarily lead the Secret Service.\n\nKimberly Cheatle, the former director, resigned last week a day after she testified in the House, dodging questions and drawing bipartisan condemnation and calls for her to resign.\n\n\"I regret that information was not passed to Congress and the public sooner with greater frequency,\" Mr. Rowe said.\n\nHe pledged his \"full support\" to the various investigations examining the assassination attempt and said he would hold a press conference as soon as this week to provide further updates to the public.\n\nMr. Rowe said he has begun assessing where the Secret Service failed and has already implemented \"corrective actions\" for security gaps that occurred on July 13. That includes directing agents to vet event site security plans with multiple experienced supervisors before implementation and expanding the use of drones at protected sites.\n\nFBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate also testified at the hearing, updating the committees on the bureau's ongoing criminal investigation into Crooks. He said the FBI has conducted more than 460 interviews to date and has received more than 2,000 tips.\n\nWhile Mr. Abbate revealed little new information, he did tell senators that the FBI recently uncovered a social media account they believe to be associated with Crooks containing more than 700 posts from 2019-2020. The FBI is still working to verify whether the account and posts belong to Crooks, but if they do, they contain some of the first major insights into his state of mind, he said.\n\n\"Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appeared to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature,\" Mr. Abbate said.\n\nSenators spent the majority of their time questioning Mr. Rowe. While they welcomed news of the disciplinary investigation, some were surprised no one in the agency had been let go yet.\n\n\"Somebody's got to be fired,\" Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, the top Republican on the Judiciary Committee, said. \"Nothing is going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nSen. Josh Hawley, Missouri Republican, got into a testy exchange with Mr. Rowe as he pressed him on why the agent in charge of security planning for the rally or other agents who may have failed in their roles still had their jobs.\n\n\"What more do you need to know?\" the senator asked.\n\nMr. Rowe committed to holding people accountable after the disciplinary review, but said he wouldn't rush to judgment because he doesn't want agents to be \"unfairly persecuted.\"\n\nIn a separate exchange, Mr. Rowe said the team planning security for the Democratic National Convention in Chicago next month is a separate set of agents from headquarters in Washington.\n\n\"Our Pittsburgh field office staff, they are wearing this harder than anybody right now in the Secret Service,\" he said. \"They feel completely demoralized.\"\n\nSenate Homeland Security Chairman Gary Peters, Michigan Democrat, said his panel wants to interview the Secret Service agents responsible for securing the Butler event, asking Mr. Rowe to make them available for depositions within days. Mr. Rowe committed to that.\n\nSome GOP senators said in a press conference after the hearing that Congress does not have the time or staff needed to uncover answers quickly enough and called for an independent commission to investigate the assassination attempt.\n\n\"I think that this is something that the president could appoint [or] if the House and Senate leadership got together they could do as well,\" Sen. Roger Marshall, Kansas Republican said.\n\nMost importantly, the commission should be apolitical, comprised of \"experts in the field\" not associated with Republicans or Democrats, he said.\n\nMr. Marshall also cited \"significant cultural breakdowns within the Secret Service\" and said he thinks President Biden should appoint a \"crisis management team\" to overhaul the agency.\n\n\"I think he's fine in his role right now as acting director,\" he said of Mr. Rowe. \"But I don't think that he has the skill set or the objective ability to turn this Secret Service around.\"\n\nA key revelation in the hearing came during questioning from Sen. Charles E. Grassley. The Iowa Republican said he received documents from local law enforcement showing the Secret Service had planned to have someone operate a counter-drone on July 13.\n\n\"According to the Secret Service, the drone system was supposed to be operational at 3 p.m.,\" Mr. Grassley said. \"That day, however, we've been told by Secret Service that because of the cellular bandwidth problems, it wasn't operational until about 5:20.\"\n\nMr. Rowe confirmed the drone system \"had operational difficulties and did not go operational until after 5 o'clock.\"\n\nCrooks flew his drone at 3:51 p.m. Had the Secret Service counter drone been operational at that point, it should have recognized Crooks' system.\n\n\"We could have perhaps found him. We could have perhaps stopped him,\" Mr. Rowe said, noting that the question \"has cost me a lot of sleep.\"\n\nMr. Grassley asked why the Secret Service's technology is dependent on cellular networks, and why there was no backup plan in place.\n\nMr. Rowe was reluctant to detail the technology in a public hearing so as not to provide tactical information to potential bad actors. But he admitted the failure to have a counter-drone in the air is something he has struggled to understand.\n\n\"Moving forward, we are leveraging resources from the Department of Homeland Security and others to make sure that we have dedicated connectivity so that we're not reliant on public domain -- so that we can ensure that whatever assets we have in place, those assets are operational,\" Mr. Rowe said.\n\nAnother issue senators honed in on was communication breakdowns that took place in the final few minutes before Mr. Trump was shot.\n\nWhile local law enforcement working the rally first identified Crooks as a suspicious person at 4:26 p.m., according to Mr. Abbate's timeline of events, it was not until 6:08 p.m. that they observed him on the roof.\n\nAt 6:11 p.m., one local officer hoisted another to get a visual on the roof and Crooks pointed a gun at the officer. That's the first time local law enforcement spotted Crooks with a weapon, and the officers immediately radioed in that the man on the roof was armed with a \"long gun,\" Mr. Abbate said.\n\nMr. Rowe said that radio communication never made it to the Secret Service.\n\n\"It appears that information was stuck or siloed in that state or local channel,\" he said. \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have.\"\n\nBefore the shots were fired, the Secret Service was only told that local law enforcement was working on an issue in the general direction of the building. Had agents known someone was on the roof with a gun, they would have removed Mr. Trump from the stage, Mr. Rowe said.\n\n\"Not having that real-time information is what really hindered us,\" he said.\n\nMr. Rowe said he has directed resources to improving protective site communications, particularly with our state and local partners. But he also said it is not easy to set up direct communications with all law enforcement partners working a big event.\n\n\"For a one-day or an eight-hour operation, it requires a lot,\" Mr. Rowe said. \"It would be months of planning, of knowing that we are going to go to this particular jurisdiction and that we're going to need your frequencies, the keys, and we're going to need to load you into our radios.\"\n\nSenators said that is something the Homeland Security Committee should look at addressing.\n\n\"Not just in an executive protection context, but any complex incident response, any counterterrorism, any natural disaster context, the inability swiftly to link personnel from disparate jurisdictions at the local, state and federal level is a vulnerability for the nation,\" Sen. Jon Ossoff, Georgia Democrat, said.", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "lindsey_mcpherson@washingtontimes.com", "name": Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nPeople are also reading... 2 people killed, 7 others injured in accident on Black Horse Pike in Egg Harbor Township Woman killed in Egg Harbor Township crash was 8 months pregnant and mother of 4-year-old girl Judge hits Atlantic City Housing Authority with 75% rent abatements for ignoring court orders Witness describes fiery Black Horse Pike crash that killed 2 people, injured 7 What type of restaurant would you like to see at the former Tilton Inn site? Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\nGet Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay up-to-date on the latest in local and national {"uri": "2024-07-438732875", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:01:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:01:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:13:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.wtva.com/news/national/takeaways-from-the-senate-hearing-on-the-trump-assassination-attempt-and-secret-service-failure/article_064750a6-687b-5b00-9ea0-d1512e1fa484.html", "title": "Takeaways from the Senate hearing on the Trump assassination attempt and Secret Service failure", "body": "By Holmes Lybrand, Hannah Rabinowitz, Devan Cole and Tierney Sneed, CNN\n\nWashington (CNN) -- Secret Service acting Director Ronald Rowe provided new details about the assassination attempt of Donald Trump on Tuesday, delivering forceful testimony at a Senate hearing about the agency's failures earlier this month in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nBut at the joint hearing of the Judiciary and Homeland Security committees, Rowe also highlighted the missteps of local law enforcement on July 13, when the former president was shot.\n\nRowe testified that Secret Service agents on Trump's security detail, as well as snipers on duty, were not told that the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, was positioned on a nearby roof with a rifle and only learned of his presence after he started shooting.\n\nFederal investigators are looking into a YouTube account possibly connected to Crooks in which the user espoused political violence as well as antisemitic and anti-immigration themes, a source familiar with the investigation tells CNN. Deputy FBI Director Paul Abbate described the account but did not reveal the platform at the hearing.\n\nThe hearing was the fourth such one held on Capitol Hill since the assassination attempt, and though it grew testy at times, especially during some exchanges with Republican senators, lawmakers appeared largely satisfied with the information provided by Rowe and Abbate during their more than three hours of testimony.\n\nOverall, it stood in stark contrast with a House hearing held last week in which lawmakers grilled then-Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle over what went wrong earlier this month, with several members demanding she resign over the lapses. A day later, she did just that.\n\nHere are the takeaways from Tuesday's joint hearing:\n\n'Siloed' information about Crooks' presence\n\nDuring Tuesday's hearing, Rowe highlighted the failures of communications during the rally, in Butler, saying that information about Crooks was \"siloed\" and \"stuck\" in local law enforcement channels.\n\n\"The only thing we had was that locals were working an issue at the three o'clock - which would have been the former president's right-hand side - which is where the shot came,\" Rowe said. \"Nothing about man on the roof, nothing about man with a gun. None of that information ever made it over our net.\"\n\nHomeland Security Committee Chairman Gary Peters said that local law enforcement has claimed they were \"only able to call in to a state command center\" and not able to easily communicate threats to the Secret Service.\n\nBut Peters also noted that Abbate testified during the hearing that \"there was about 30 seconds between when the local law enforcement reported that there was a man on the roof with a gun\" and when the shooter began firing.\n\n\"If it's communicated directly to a counter-sniper team, would that be enough time to react prior to the firing of those shots?\" Peters asked.\n\n\"If we'd had that information, they would have been able to address it more quickly,\" Rowe replied. \"It appears that that information was stuck or siloed in that local channel.\"\n\n\"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have,\" he said. \"We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nCrooks was killed within 15.5 seconds of the first shot, Rowe said.\n\nCounter-drone system could have prevented the attack\n\nRowe confirmed that the reason a counter-drone system was not deployed at the Butler rally earlier in the day was because of connectivity issues.\n\n\"On this day in particular, because of the connectivity challenge ... there was a delay,\" he said. Crooks flew his own drone around the area two hours before Trump took the stage.\n\nThe issue has \"cost me a lot of sleep,\" Rowe said. \"What if we would have geolocated him because that counter (unmanned aircraft system) platform would have been up.\"\n\nRowe said that had the system been up, law enforcement may have been able to see Crooks' use of his own drone and approached him well before the shooting.\n\nMoving forward, Rowe said, his agency will use drones to help better secure future events.\n\n\"It is clear to me that other protective enhancements could have strengthened our security at the Butler event,\" he told lawmakers. \"As such, I have directed the expanded use of unmanned aerial systems at protective sites to help detect threats on roofs and other elevated threats.\"\n\nThe acting director also said that the Secret Service will now work with the Department of Homeland Security to set up their own, private connection and not rely on public domain connections.\n\nRowe points fingers at local law enforcement\n\nAs lawmakers pressed Rowe for answers on what went wrong earlier this month, the interim Secret Service director sought to shirk some of the responsibility for the security lapses, partially blaming the issues on the local law enforcement officers with whom they were working.\n\nMoving forward, Rowe told the committees, his agency will avoid assuming local law enforcement agencies are fully capable of fulfilling their role in protecting an event.\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said of the area where Crooks climbed up the side of a building near the rally with his rifle.\n\n\"We made an assumption,\" he said, explaining that the Secret Service believed there would be sufficient eyes to cover the area and that local law enforcement would have a counter sniper in the AGR building where Crooks took his position.\n\nRowe told the lawmakers that local law enforcement was positioned in a nearby building and should have had a clear line of sight of Crooks on the roof.\n\n\"I cannot understand why there was not better coverage or at least somebody looking at that roofline when that's where they were posted,\" Rowe said, noting that a local sniper team could have looked from their post and seen the would-be assassin.\n\n\"Looking left, why was the assailant not seen?\" Rowe asked of the local team, as he showed lawmakers photographs of the roofs snipers were positioned on.\n\n\"I'm not saying that they should have neutralized him, but if they'd have held their post and looked left maybe...\" Rowe said later, though he was quickly cut off by an unrelated comment.\n\nShouting matches over firings and Biden v. Trump resources\n\nSeveral senators lambasted Rowe for not firing any members in his agency and over the amount of security provided to former President Trump compared to President Joe Biden.\n\nIn one such exchange, Rowe loudly objected to Sen. Josh Hawley's persistent questions about why individuals weren't fired in recent weeks.\n\n\"I will not rush to judgment. People will be held accountable,\" Rowe said, adding that investigations into the failures that day are ongoing.\n\nThe Missouri Republican responded: \"Is it not prima facie that somebody has failed? The former president was shot.\"\n\n\"Sir, this could have been our Texas School Book Depository,\" Rowe responded, referring to the 1963 assassination of President John F. Kennedy in Dallas. \"I have lost sleep over that for the last 17 days, just like you have.\"\n\n\"Then fire somebody,\" Hawley shouted, to which Rowe replied: \"We have to be able to have a proper investigation into this.\"\n\nAt another point during Tuesday's hearing, Republican Sen. Ted Cruz repeatedly pressed Rowe on why Trump doesn't receive the same security level as Biden.\n\n\"There is a difference between the sitting president of the United States,\" Rowe said.\n\n\"Then what's the difference,\" Cruz yelled, cutting Rowe off.\n\n\"The difference - national command authority to launch a nuclear strike, sir,\" Rowe responded. \"There are other assets that travel with the president that the former president will not get.\"\n\nCrooks' online presence\n\nInvestigators have uncovered a social media account with posts espousing political violence that may be connected to the would-be Trump assassin, Abbate said.\n\nOfficials have repeatedly said that they have struggled to understand what the 20-year-old shooter's motive was, and that they are combing his online presence for more information.\n\n\"Something just very recently uncovered that I want to share is a social media account, which is believed to be associated with this with the shooter - in about the 2019, 2020 timeframe,\" Abbate said.\n\nOn that account, \"there were over 700 comments,\" Abbate said, which, \"if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes, to espouse political violence, and are described as extreme in nature.\"\n\nCNN has learned the account is on the YouTube platform.\n\nA separate account on the platform Gab - which was made years earlier - appears to have \"differing points of view,\" Abbate added.\n\nGab CEO Andrew Tobra revealed last week that the would-be assassin may have had an account on the site, which is an alternative social media network popular with conservatives, the alt-right and some extremists. Tobra claimed that the account in question was \"pro-Biden.\"\n\nThe Gab account has also not been conclusively connected to Crooks.\n\nThis story has been updated with additional developments.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "8250947480", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:49:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:49:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:46:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://journalstar.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/acting-secret-service-boss-cannot-defend-why-roof-in-trump-rally-shooting-wasnt-secured/article_d05ac2bd-8be5-5b7b-9e8b-12e8122e57f3.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting wasn't secured", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The acting director of the Secret Service says he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe is testifying Tuesday before two Senate committees. Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nPeople are also reading... Time, TV for Jordan Larson and the US women's volleyball team at the Paris Olympics Judge orders Nebraska Department of Transportation to turn over records of intersection study 7 killed after plane departing Nebraska City crashes in Wyoming, including members of gospel group Nebraska Gov. Pillen would reduce own property tax bill nearly $1M if cuts pass 'Exhausting, heartbreaking, devastating': Racism at Wayne school pushes family out of Nebraska In a split decision, Nebraska Supreme Court rejects legal challenge to abortion, trans care ban 4-year-old boy escaped from cage in Iowa home; deputies found him covered in feces on street 'Ready to learn from this': John Cook updates Harper Murray's status for 2024 season 'A way of life': John Cook all-in on cowboy lifestyle, helping grow state's rodeo scene, too Kearney man runs American flag upside down as 'distress' signal Lincoln's struggles to find another air carrier worsened by subsidies to other Nebraska airports Valley lake house is a showstopper: 'It's honestly incredible,' interior designer says Nebraska lawmakers begin taking sides as property tax special session continues Notes: Ron Brown gets new title; Matt Rhule on Nebraska's place in national NIL scene Nearly 100 Lincoln Industries employees summit mountains in Colorado\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nGet Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9772518", "eventUri": "eng-9772518", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Washington (state)"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng":
