{"uri": "8251681666", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "03:48:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T03:48:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T03:46:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-07-31/secret-service-blames-local-police-for-security-failures-trump/104164294", "title": "US Secret Service chief blames Trump security lapse on local police", "body": "Mr Rowe said the Secret Service would \"never make that mistake again\" as multiple inquiries begin into the shooting.\n\nThe US Secret Service's new acting director has said that he was \"ashamed\" of a security lapse that led to the July 13 attempted assassination of Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, but blamed the shortfall on local law enforcement.\n\nIn testimony before two Senate committees, Acting Director Ronald Rowe said he visited the outdoor rally site in Butler, Pennsylvania, and climbed onto the roof of a nearby building from which 20-year-old Thomas Crooks fired shots that wounded Trump's right ear, killed one rally attendee and wounded two others with an AR-15-style rifle.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Mr Rowe told a joint hearing of the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees.\n\nThe first shooting of a US president or major party candidate in more than four decades was a glaring security lapse that led last week to the agency's former director Kimberly Cheatle's resignation under bipartisan congressional pressure.\n\nBut Mr Rowe went on to tell politicians that the Secret Service erred by assuming that local officials would cover the building and its roof, not the agency itself.\n\nRepublican senator John Cornyn pushed back on the notion that the responsibility should have been left to others.\n\n\"Isn't that something that Secret Service should have covered, as opposed to delegating it to local law enforcement?\" Senator Cornyn asked.\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Mr Rowe replied. \"I can assure you that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nDemocratic senator Richard Blumenthal asked Mr Rowe: \"Ultimately, doesn't the buck stop with the Secret Service?\"\n\n\"It stops with us, sir,\" the acting director said.\n\nBut he added: \"If they'd just held their post and looked left.\"\n\nMr Rowe's comments came days after a local SWAT team assigned to help protect Trump told American ABC News that it had no contact with Secret Service agents in charge of security at the rally before the shooting, and that an anticipated face-to-face briefing with Secret Service officials never happened.\n\nMr Rowe said he has already taken steps to prevent similar lapses from occurring amid concerns among both Democrats and Republicans about further political violence as the campaign intensifies ahead of the November 5 presidential election.\n\nFBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate, who also testified before the panels, said Mr Crooks appears to have posted violent anti-Semitic and anti-immigration content online as a teenager.\n\nIt is some of the first evidence of Mr Crooks's possible inclination toward extremism and political violence found by investigators, who have yet to identify a motive.\n\nMr Abbate said investigators found a social media account dating to 2019-2020, when Mr Crooks would have been 15 or 16 years old, adding that the account had posted more than 700 comments.\n\n\"Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect anti-Semitic and anti-immigration themes, to espouse political violence, and are described as extreme in nature,\" Mr Abbate told politicians.\n\nMr Crooks flew a drone near the rally site ahead of the shooting, a flight that Secret Service officials failed to notice because a system for detecting drones was not working properly due to problems with the local cellular network, Mr Rowe said.\n\nPoliticians sought to learn why the Secret Service did not delay the rally or prevent Trump from taking the stage, noting that local police saw Mr Crooks with a rangefinder device for measuring distances about an hour before the shooting.\n\nMr Rowe said Mr Crooks was only one among a number of individuals to draw local law enforcement attention, and added that the Secret Service was not informed when local police saw Mr Crooks on the roof with the rife, just before he opened fire.\n\n\"They were in the midst of dealing with a very critical situation and they articulated that over the radio, as I understand it. However, it was never relayed over to us,\" Mr Rowe said.\n\nThe proceedings grew heated when Republican senator Josh Hawley pushed Mr Rowe to begin expelling agency employees immediately.\n\n\"I will tell you, senator ... that people will be held accountable, and I will do so with integrity and not rush to judgement and let people be unfairly persecuted,\" Mr Rowe told Senator Hawley with a raised Paul:  Locals warned Secret Service about building before assassination attempt", "body": "Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul indicated on Tuesday that local law enforcement in Pennsylvania said it had warned U.S. Secret Service agents about the building used by Thomas Matthew Crooks to take aim at former President Donald Trump.\n\n\"Local law enforcement told my staff that they specifically flagged the vulnerability of the building to the Secret Service and were told it would be taken care of,\" Paul said. \"Clearly these vulnerabilities were not addressed.\"\n\nActing Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe Jr. and FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate appeared before a special joint Senate committee hearing on Tuesday, in which senators probed for specific answers about the security failure at the July 13 Trump rally.\n\nPaul, a Kentucky Republican, is the ranking member of the committee that oversees homeland security and government affairs.\n\nIn his remarks, Paul also stressed local law enforcement officers had expressed suspicions about Crooks 90 minutes before he fired shots at Trump from the roof of a building just 400 feet from where Trump delivered his campaign remarks in Pennsylvania that day.\n\n\"Why was Donald Trump allowed to take the stage, and why wasn't he removed from the stage when a suspicious individual was taking increasingly suspicious activities?,\" Paul asked.\n\nRowe, a 25-year Secret Service veteran, is taking the place of Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned her post after a ruinous appearance before the House Oversight Committee, chaired by Kentucky Rep. James Comer. He assumed oversight of the agency July 23.\n\nHe succeeded Kimberly Cheatle who quit under pressure from lawmakers and others. Rowe previously served as deputy director of the Secret Service, responsible for overseeing daily investigative and protective operations.\n\nStarting with his opening statement, Rowe made no excuses for the agency. He told lawmakers that he was \"ashamed\" the Secret Service failed to secure the rooftop where the gunman fired on Trump.\n\nFiring at Trump, the gunman killed one person in the crowd and critically injured two others. Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nPeople are also reading... New Food Lion grocery set to open in Troutman 'There was evil in that room': Statesville mother says her daughter was brutally killed Borders signs with Giants where he will join another Statesville native, DB coach Jerome Henderson Marshall Steam Station prepares for move from coal to natural gas in Sherrills Ford Big Lots closing 35-40 stores and warns it may close all stores HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: What does your favorite Iredell team's schedule look like this season? Statesville man arrested on drug, probation violation charges Iredell County man charged in death of parents and brother may face death penalty Troutman teen's Eagle Scout project at Allison Woods is for the birds Out of Our Past: Monster tooth found in Cool Spring; Jennings Road opens Iredell sisters arrested on drug charges after traffic stop Former Statesville Christian coach sentenced on two counts of assaulting female Man shot and killed at Kernersville Food Lion; police say it was 'isolated event' Iredell chase ends with crash; one reported dead Stony Point man, woman facing drug charges in Iredell County\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\nGet Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay up-to-date on the latest in local and national {"uri": "8251098786", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:38:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:38:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:37:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://richmond.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/acting-secret-service-director-says-hes-ashamed-after-the-trump-assassination-attempt/article_28608856-9d35-52ee-bb08-413edc5a6507.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting wasn't secured", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers on Tuesday that he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured, faulting local law enforcement for not circulating urgent information ahead of the shooting and for not adequately protecting the scene.\n\nHe also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and said, \"What I saw made me ashamed.\" He said that the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalogue to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also repeatedly lacing into local law enforcement for not sharing information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been spotted on a roof near the rally site in the minutes before the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nPeople are also reading... Outer Banks wild stallion hit, killed on the beach Youngkin names Scalia daughter to Board of Education 'Illegal' recruiting a hot topic at VHSL meeting in Abingdon; John Marshall called out Former Virginia EMS employee pleads guilty to embezzling $4 million As Kings Dominion merges with Six Flags, some fans worry quality will suffer New Virginia state law changes the way reading is taught Virginia collects $1.2 billion more revenue than expected Thousands watch Chincoteague wild ponies complete 99th swim UPDATE: Police identify man found dead in vehicle in Chesterfield pond UVa's Gretchen Walsh sets Olympic record in 100 butterfly on opening night of Paris Games UPDATE: Police ID victim, announce arrest in shooting involving Chesterfield couple Dominion customers' bills to rise for offshore project costs Woman featured on '16 and Pregnant' pronounced dead in Sandston Henrico homeowners upset by Goochland quarry expansion Richmonders weigh in on Kamala Harris as presumptive Democratic nominee\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots, less than 150 yards (135 meters) from the rally stage where Trump was speaking.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nTrump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before the gunman was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue. It also suggested that Rowe, with ready and detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers from both major political parties after responses that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nMuch of Tuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees focused on what Rowe suggested was inadequate information received by Secret Service personnel in the hour before the shooting, including that Crooks had been spotted on the roof.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers had spotted a suspicious-looking man pacing near the metal detectors and circulated but ultimately lost track of Crooks before he scaled the roof of a building at AGR International Inc. Shortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take responsibility.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"Isn't it the fact that the former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress, but he assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nSen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nOn Monday, the FBI revealed that Crooks had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. Trump, who appeared at events in the days after the shooting with a bandage on his right ear, said he expects the interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nAt Cheatle's hearing last week, she said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds {"uri": "2024-07-438490979", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:27:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:27:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/acting-secret-service-boss-cannot-defend-why-roof-in-trump-rally-shooting-wast-secured/article_3c07c8ac-471a-5362-a3c4-7c1b5c50523d.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting was't secured", "body": "Senior officials from the U.S. Secret Service and the FBI testify before the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees about the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump.\n\nWASHINGTON -- The acting director of the Secret Service says he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe is testifying Tuesday before two Senate committees. Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nHomeless and dying: La Crosse veteran diagnosed with heart failure finds peace in final weeks Mayo Clinic likely to demolish 94-year-old St. Francis Hospital building after opening new La Crosse facility Steve Cahalan: City panel to review plans for new Starbucks at Valley View Mall New building plans unveiled, along with TIF agreement at La Crosse's $300M River Point District project Complaint says La Crosse man assaulted with sheathed machete during 'school yard brawl' on lawn La Crosse County examines large affordable housing development in West Salem with nearly 600 units La Crosse man faces charges for driving under the influence of marijuana Steve Cahalan: LAX Grille opens, Pastissimo is leaving and Ichiddo Ramen is coming to La Crosse Man accused of OWI while pulling camper containing 9 kids, Wisconsin State Patrol says New retreat house for pilgrims and visitors at Shrine of Our Lady Guadalupe would house up to 66 guests Steve Cahalan: Candle maker adds to number of woman-owned shops in downtown Galesville Daylong standoff ends with arrest of man who shot Sauk County deputy, authorities say No injuries, one dog rescued from fire on Rose Street in La Crosse Three injured in two-vehicle head-on crash in rural De Soto Vintage Star Wars, G.I. Joe sets give estate shoppers chance to live out their 'man-childhood'\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nGet Government & Politics updates in your {"uri": "2024-07-438605387", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:20:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:20:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:05:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://missoulian.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/acting-secret-service-director-says-hes-ashamed-after-the-trump-assassination-attempt/article_89ce0104-ccca-570f-88f0-77ef13f3c887.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting wasn't secured", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers on Tuesday that he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured, faulting local law enforcement for not circulating urgent information ahead of the shooting and for not adequately protecting the scene.\n\nHe also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and said, \"What I saw made me ashamed.\" He said that the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalogue to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also repeatedly lacing into local law enforcement for not sharing information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been spotted on a roof near the rally site in the minutes before the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nThunderstorm rips through Missoula, Bitterroot valleys, winds reach 109 City, county declare emergency for Missoula wind storm, leaders speak out City of Missoula asking residents to stay home after wind event Straight-line winds hammer Missoula valley State declares disaster in Missoula, Mineral counties Thousands still without power around Missoula; officials asking people to limit water use Residents, businesses and governments deal with fallout of windstorm Health officials release list of Flathead restaurants associated with E. coli outbreak Storm aftermath leaves debris, hazards UPDATED: UM remains without power, free school lunch returns to MCPS properties on Friday Man arrested after shots allegedly fired at energy crew's vehicle Miller Peak fire fizzles as crews tackle new wildfire starts Brian Bird: Thank you, NorthWestern Energy customers and Missoula-area communities Aircraft with 7 people aboard crashes in northern Wyoming Fire ignites west of Lost Trail; wilderness blaze smokes Bitterroot\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots, less than 150 yards (135 meters) from the rally stage where Trump was speaking.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nTrump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before the gunman was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue. It also suggested that Rowe, with ready and detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers from both major political parties after responses that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nMuch of Tuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees focused on what Rowe suggested was inadequate information received by Secret Service personnel in the hour before the shooting, including that Crooks had been spotted on the roof.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers had spotted a suspicious-looking man pacing near the metal detectors and circulated but ultimately lost track of Crooks before he scaled the roof of a building at AGR International Inc. Shortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take responsibility.\n\n\"Isn't it the fact that the former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress, but he assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nSen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nOn Monday, the FBI revealed that Crooks had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. Trump, who appeared at events in the days after the shooting with a bandage on his right ear, said he expects the interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nAt Cheatle's hearing last week, she said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"", "source": {"uri": "missoulian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "missoulian.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@missoulian.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", {"uri": "8251515503", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:20:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:20:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:19:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/ap/washington/acting-secret-service-director-says-hes-ashamed-after-the-trump-assassination-attempt/article_41247941-a2ef-55b8-bfbd-6ff0fb85043a.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service director says he's 'ashamed' after the Trump assassination attempt", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers Tuesday that he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured and said it was regrettable that local law enforcement had not alerted his agency before the shooting that an armed subject had been spotted on a nearby roof.\n\nRonald Rowe Jr. also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and lied down on the roof of the building where shots were fired in order to evaluate the gunman's line of sight during the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed. As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year Secret Service veteran, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured,\" he said.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalog to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also pointedly criticizing local law enforcement for communication breakdowns that resulted in his agency not receiving information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been seen on the roof of a building less than 150 yards (135 meters) from the rally stage where Trump was speaking.\n\n\"Neither the Secret Service counter sniper teams nor members of the former president's security detail had any knowledge that there was a man on the roof of the building with a firearm,\" Rowe said. \"It is my understanding those personnel were not aware the assailant had a firearm until they heard gunshots.\"\n\nHe said that the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination and a \"failure to challenge our assumptions.\"\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nHe said he had implemented multiple reforms since taking over as acting director last week, including mandating that every event security plan is vetted by multiple experienced supervisors before being implemented, expanding the use of aerial drones to improve visibility of roofs, dedicating more resources to improve communications at events where the Secret Service is operating. He said he's also directed that federal and local counter snipers work together on roofs.\n\nTrump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before the gunman was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue. It also suggested that Rowe, with ready and generally detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers from both major political parties following responses at a congressional hearing that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nTuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees was the latest in a series of congressional sessions dedicated to the law enforcement lapses and missed communications that preceded the shooting.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers had first observed a suspicious-looking man at the rally site more than an hour before the event and circulated that information, including photographs of a man who turned out to be Crooks. But the officers ultimately lost track of Crooks, who was able to scale the roof of a building at AGR International Inc., a supplier of automation equipment for the glass and plastic packaging industry, and fire an estimated eight shots with an AR-15-style rife.\n\nToday's Top Headlines\n\nStory continues below\n\nSC lake hasn't allowed fishing since the 1950s. Now, it's packed with bass and open to the public Grace period is over for 'Carolina Squat' truck in SC. How many tickets have been issued? They don't want their community to look like Myrtle Beach. Could they form a new town? Donald Trump MAGA boat parade will fill Charleston Harbor with giant flotilla this weekend Salaried officers can't get overtime. So why did Williamsburg Co. officials get 200K in extra pay? Mica Miller's husband and family have reached a settlement. Here's what we know. A tropical wave is crossing the Atlantic. Could it impact South Carolina? Carnival is sailing away but other cruise ships have plans to visit Charleston Charleston's oldest park restored for grand opening A thriller recently was shot in Spartanburg. Here's where to see the movie for free.\n\nShortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\nEven though text messages among local snipers revealed anxiety about the man, Rowe said the only thing the Secret Service knew at the time of the shooting was that law enforcement was contending with a suspicious-looking man.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take sufficient responsibility.\n\n\"Isn't the fact that a former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be in the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress. He assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nSen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019-2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nAbbate did not identify the social media platform, saying investigators were still trying to definitively determine that it belonged to Crooks. However, he indicated that it was separate from an account on a different platform called Gab that was active in 2021.\n\nThe chief executive of Gab posted on X, formerly known as Twitter, during the Senate hearing that Crooks's presence on that platform was consistent with being \"pro-Biden and in particular pro-Biden's immigration policy.\"\n\nOn Monday, the FBI revealed that Crooks had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister Robert Fico.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim.", "source": {"uri": "postandcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Post and Courier"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8251405531", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:08:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:08:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:06:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/trump-shooting-failure-multiple-levels-212223145.html", "title": "Trump shooting 'a failure on multiple levels,' acting U.S. Secret Service chief says", "body": "WASHINGTON, DC - JULY 30: Acting U.S. Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe Jr. testifies before a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security and Government Affairs committees in the Dirksen Senate Office Building on Capitol Hill on July 30, 2024 in Washington, DC. Senators grilled Rowe and Deputy Federal Bureau of Investigation Director Paul Abbate about the events leading to the July 13 attempted assassination of former U.S. President Donald Trump, days before he accepted the Republican presidential nomination for the third time. (Photo by Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)\n\nWASHINGTON -- When acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe Jr. visited the site of the campaign rally where a gunman attempted to assassinate former President Donald Trump, he went up to the roof, lying flat on his stomach, to evaluate the shooter's line of sight that mid-July day.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe told U.S. senators Tuesday. \"As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year-veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nRowe recounted his trip to Butler, Pennsylvania, which he said took place after being named acting director July 23, at a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs committees examining the security failures that led to the assassination attempt. Deputy FBI Director Paul Abbate also testified.\n\nIt was the first Senate hearing on the attempted assassination since a shooter killed one rallygoer, injured two others and shot Trump's ear using an AR-15-style rifle during a campaign event in Butler on July 13. The 20-year-old gunman was killed at the scene.\n\n\"Let me be clear: This was an attack on our democracy,\" said Sen. Gary Peters, chairman of the Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee.\n\n\"Americans should be able to attend a political rally and express their political beliefs without fear of violence, and political candidates for our nation's highest office should be confident that their safety will never be compromised for their service,\" the Michigan Democrat added.\n\nPeters launched a bipartisan investigation into the security failures leading to the assassination attempt alongside ranking Republican Rand Paul of Kentucky. It's one of several congressional inquiries examining the failures of law enforcement that day.\n\nRowe stepped into his post after Kimberly Cheatle resigned as director last week. The day before her resignation, Cheatle testified in front of the House Committee on Oversight and Accountability, where lawmakers on both sides of the aisle berated her over the agency's failures to prevent the attempted assassination of Trump.\n\nFacing heavy criticism, many lawmakers called on Cheatle to resign. House Oversight Chairman James Comer of Kentucky and ranking member Jamie Raskin of Maryland also urged her to step down in a joint letter shortly after that hearing.\n\nRowe said the attempted assassination was \"a failure to imagine that we actually do live in a very dangerous world where people do actually want to do harm to our protectees.\"\n\n\"I think it was a failure to challenge our own assumptions -- the assumptions that we know our partners are going to do everything they can, and they do this every day,\" he added.\n\nSenators sought to uncover what went wrong, what policies are in place to facilitate real-time information sharing between the Secret Service and local law enforcement during an event and whether the Secret Service is developing a security plan for the upcoming Democratic National Convention in Chicago that takes into account what they learned from the July shooting.\n\nNeither the Secret Service counter sniper teams nor members of Trump's security detail \"had any knowledge that there was a man on the roof of the ... building with a firearm,\" according to Rowe.\n\nRowe said \"prior to that, they were operating with the knowledge that local law enforcement was working an issue of a suspicious individual prior to the shots being fired.\"\n\nAbbate noted that despite not having any definitive evidence as to how the gunman got the weapon onto the roof, they believe based on what they have gathered thus far that he likely had the rifle in a backpack.\n\nMeanwhile, Abbate said the FBI uncovered a social media account believed to be associated with the shooter, though they are still working to verify that the account belonged to him.\n\nMore than 700 comments were posted from the social media account \"in about the 2019, 2020 timeframe,\" when the shooter would have been in his mid-teens, and some of the comments \"appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature,\" Abbate said.\n\nAbbate said though nothing has been ruled out, the FBI's investigation has not identified any motive, co-conspirators or people with advanced knowledge. The FBI has so far held more than 460 interviews, received over 2,000 tips from the public, executed search warrants and seized electronic media.\n\nTuesday's hearing came the day after U.S. House Speaker Mike Johnson and Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries announced 13 lawmakers comprising a bipartisan task force to investigate the attempted assassination. The resolution creating the panel requires a final report by mid-December.\n\nRep. Mike Kelly, a Pennsylvania Republican whose district includes Butler, will chair the task force.\n\nRepublican Sen. Chuck Grassley of Iowa and Democratic Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto of Nevada introduced bipartisan legislation last week that would require Senate confirmation of Secret Service directors and limit them to one term of 10 years.", "source": Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nPeople are also reading... Waterloo traffic cameras adjust ticket threshold by 1 mph NEW DETAILS: Deere offers statement on severance package for salaried employees let go Wednesday in Waterloo UPDATE: 69 John Deere Waterloo salaried employees let go Wednesday, 34 in Dubuque Waterloo Christian School makes offer on old Cedar Falls High School 4-year-old boy escaped from cage in Iowa home; deputies found him covered in feces on street Chased out of Buchanan County, Balance music festival coming to Waterloo Waterloo man arrested for trying to run over women Oelwein man dead in two-vehicle crash southwest of Hazleton Neighbors, crews rescue man from sinking vehicle Waterloo man arrested following short chase Olympics: Independence wrestling coaches will serve as volunteers at Paris Games Deere held employee meeting Wednesday, no word yet on potential layoffs Waterloo man sentenced to prison for sawed-off shotgun 67 Johnston workers added to Deere layoffs list, bringing Iowa total to 170 this week John Deere idled more than 300 workers in Quad Cities on Wednesday, bringing last week's total to 489\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nGet Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay {"uri": "2024-07-438404588", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:12:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:12:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T09:51:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-07-30/us-secret-service-acting-director-ashamed-about-trump-shooting", "title": "US Secret Service Acting Director 'Ashamed' About Trump Shooting", "body": "By Allende Miglietta, David Morgan and Sarah N. Lynch\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) - The U.S. Secret Service's new acting director said in prepared congressional testimony on Tuesday he was \"ashamed\" of a major security lapse that preceded the July 13 attempted assassination of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump at a Pennsylvania campaign rally.\n\nIn testimony released before addressing two Senate committees, Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe said he visited the outdoor rally site in Butler and climbed onto the roof of a nearby building from which 20-year-old Thomas Crooks fired shots that wounded Trump's right ear, killed one rally attendee and wounded two others, with an AR-15-style rifle.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe said in the prepared testimony for a joint hearing of the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees. \"As a career law enforcement officer, and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nRowe's admission of a glaring security lapse came a week after former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned under bipartisan congressional pressure after refusing to detail security shortfalls in testimony before a House of Representatives panel.\n\nRowe sought to assure lawmakers that he has since taken steps to prevent similar lapses from occurring amid concerns among both Democrats and Republicans about further political violence as the campaign intensifies ahead of the Nov. 5 U.S. election.\n\n\"I directed our personnel to ensure every event site security plan is thoroughly vetted by multiple experienced supervisors before it is implemented,\" Rowe said.\n\nThe Secret Service, a federal law enforcement agency whose duties including protecting the president and certain other top political figures, has added six people to its protection list since July 13, including Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance and his family and independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy, while reinforcing security details, Rowe said.\n\nRowe was due to testify alongside Paul Abbate, deputy director of the FBI, which is due to interview Trump on Thursday as part of its investigation into the shooting.\n\nThe attempted assassination is the topic of multiple investigations by House and Senate committees, as well as a new bipartisan task force established by Republican House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nInvestigators have been unable to determine a clear motive for Crooks, who they have described as a loner with no close friends and a social network limited mainly to immediate family members. Much interest revolves around the timeline from when law enforcement officials first noticed Crooks to when Secret Service snipers killed him after he opened fire.\n\nThe FBI said on Monday that Crooks first came to the attention of police more than an hour before he fired at least eight shots at the former president.\n\nA local officer took a photo of Crooks and sent it to other law enforcement officials at the scene. About 30 minutes later, SWAT team members saw Crooks using a rangefinder and browsing news sites, the FBI said.\n\n(Reporting by David Morgan, Sarah N. Lynch and Allende Miglietta; Editing by Scott Malone and Will Dunham)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438435029", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "14:36:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T14:36:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:47:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13688775/US-Secret-Service-acting-director-ashamed-Trump-shooting.html", "title": "US Secret Service acting director 'ashamed' about Trump shooting", "body": "By Allende Miglietta, David Morgan and Sarah N. Lynch\n\nWASHINGTON, July 30 (Reuters) - The U.S. Secret Service's new acting director said in prepared congressional testimony on Tuesday he was \"ashamed\" of a major security lapse that preceded the July 13 attempted assassination of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump at a Pennsylvania campaign rally.\n\nIn testimony released before addressing two Senate committees, Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe said he visited the outdoor rally site in Butler and climbed onto the roof of a nearby building from which 20-year-old Thomas Crooks fired shots that wounded Trump's right ear, killed one rally attendee and wounded two others, with an AR-15-style rifle.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe said in the prepared testimony for a joint hearing of the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary Committees. \"As a career law enforcement officer, and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nRowe's admission of a glaring security lapse came a week after former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned under bipartisan congressional pressure after refusing to detail security shortfalls in testimony before a House of Representatives panel.\n\nRowe sought to assure lawmakers that he has since taken steps to prevent similar lapses from occurring amid concerns among both Democrats and Republicans about further political violence as the campaign intensifies ahead of the Nov. 5 U.S. election.\n\n\"I directed our personnel to ensure every event site security plan is thoroughly vetted by multiple experienced supervisors before it is implemented,\" Rowe said.\n\nThe Secret Service, a federal law enforcement agency whose duties including protecting the president and certain other top political figures, has added six people to its protection list since July 13, including Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance and his family and independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy, while reinforcing security details, Rowe said.\n\nRowe was due to testify alongside Paul Abbate, deputy director of the FBI, which is due to interview Trump on Thursday as part of its investigation into the shooting.\n\nThe attempted assassination is the topic of multiple investigations by House and Senate committees, as well as a new bipartisan task force established by Republican House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Democratic leader Hakeem Jeffries.\n\nInvestigators have been unable to determine a clear motive for Crooks, who they have described as a loner with no close friends and a social network limited mainly to immediate family members. Much interest revolves around the timeline from when law enforcement officials first noticed Crooks to when Secret Service snipers killed him after he opened fire.\n\nThe FBI said on Monday that Crooks first came to the attention of police more than an hour before he fired at least eight shots at the former president.\n\nA local officer took a photo of Crooks and sent it to other law enforcement officials at the scene. About 30 minutes later, SWAT team members saw Crooks using a rangefinder and browsing news sites, the FBI said.\n\n(Reporting by David Morgan, Sarah N. Lynch and Allende Miglietta; Editing by Scott Malone and Will Dunham)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438810014", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:58:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:58:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:48:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2024-07-30/senators-grill-secret-service-chief-over-trump-shooting-security-failures", "title": "'We Assume That Someone Is Going to Cover That:' Secret Service Chief Laments Lack of Communication in Trump Shooting", "body": "That's how the acting director of the Secret Service characterized the failures that led to the assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump, on Tuesday.\n\nDuring a joint Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security hearing to examine what led to the shooting, Secret Service Acting Director Ronald Rowe said he was \"ashamed\" at the handling of the incident, in which a gunman fired on Trump during a campaign rally, bloodying Trump, killing one attendee and injuring two more.\n\n\"This was a failure of imagination. A failure to imagine that we actually do live in a very dangerous world where people do actually want to do harm to our protectees,\" Rowe said.\n\nRowe also pointed to a communication breakdown between local and state law enforcement and the Secret Service, saying that \"no information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed\" to Secret Service agents.\n\n\"I think it was a failure to challenge our own assumptions,\" Rowe said. \"The assumptions that we know our partners are going to do everything they can ... We assume that someone is going to cover that. We assume that there's going to be uniform presence.\"\n\nLawmakers pushed back at placing the blame on local police and questioned why the Secret Service official who approved the security perimeter - which did not include the building the shooter perched on - wasn't fired.\n\n\"Isn't the fact that a former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded, isn't that enough mission failure for you to say that the person who decided that that building should not be in the security perimeter, probably ought to step down?\" said Republican Sen. Josh Hawley of Missouri.\n\nRowe - on hand because his former boss, Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle, resigned following a previous hearing on the shooting - said people will be held accountable after the investigation is complete, but he wouldn't be rushed to judgment by lawmakers.\n\nFBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate, who testified alongside Rowe, said the FBI's investigation is focused on the shooter's motive and timeline. To date, the FBI has not identified a motive or any co-conspirators, Abbate said.\n\n\"The FBI team has conducted more than 460 interviews, executed search warrants, including at the shooter's residence and seized electronic media to include phones, laptops, hard drives and thumb drives,\" he said. \"The full resources of the FBI have been brought to bear in furtherance of the investigation.\"\n\nAbbate said the FBI uncovered a social media account believed to be associated with the shooter in the 2019-2020 timeframe. There were over 700 posts from the account, some of which were anti-semetic, anti-immigration and espoused political violence.\n\n\"While the investigative team is still working to verify this account to determine if it did, in fact, belong to the shooter, we believe it important to share and note it today, particularly given the general absence of other information to date from social media and other sources of information that reflect on the shooter's potential, motive and mindset,\" Abbate said.\n\nThe hearing comes just a day after House Speaker Mike Johnson and Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries announced the members on the bipartisan task force investigating the assassination attempt. The group includes seven Republicans and five Democrats.\n\n\"We have the utmost confidence in this bipartisan group of steady, highly qualified and capable Members of Congress to move quickly to find the facts, ensure accountability and help make certain such failures never happen again,\" Johnson and Jeffries said in a statement.\n\nAfter its investigation, the task force will make recommendations for reform and any necessary legislation to implement the reforms.\n\nThe congressional task force comes in addition to several other federal inquiries into the shooting. The Department of Homeland Security is conducting an independent review of the Secret Service, the Secret Service is conducting its own internal review, the FBI has undertaken a criminal investigation and the Department of Homeland Security Office of Inspector General is looking into the incident.\n\nPresident Joe Biden has also ordered an independent review into the shooting. The external probe will be led in part by former DHS Secretary Janet Napolitano and Frances Townsend, who was President George W. Bush's homeland security adviser.\n\nThe shooting occurred at a campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, on July 13, where 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks accessed a building rooftop less than 500 feet from where Trump was speaking. Crooks fired at Trump with an AR-15 style rifle, injuring Trump's right ear. Rally attendee Corey Comperatore was killed, and two others were critically injured in addition to Crooks, who was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nLawmakers on Tuesday pressed for answers on how Crooks gained access to the rooftop, how he eluded the Secret Service and how he got a direct line of sight on the former president.\n\n\"We've all seen the movies, we've read the books. The international assassin with sophisticated technology and elaborate plans, sets out to kill a leading political figure in the United States. But how does that match the reality of what happened in Butler, Pennsylvania?\" asked Sen. Dick Durbin, a Democrat from Illinois.\n\n\"When a 20-year-old introverted college student outsmarted one of the most sophisticated American law enforcement agencies in history? Came within an inch of killing a former President of the United States? That's why we gather today to ask these hard questions. There's more to this story and other aspects we ought to consider as well.\"", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-07-438780740", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:09:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:09:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:08:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.wpbf.com/article/donald-trump-attempted-assassination-acting-secret-service-director-security-failures/61743511", "title": "Acting Secret Service director condemns security failures in Trump's attempted assassination", "body": "Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe Jr. condemned the security failures that led to the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump as a \"failure on multiple levels.\"\"I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured,\" Rowe said.This was the location from which Thomas Matthew Crooks fired eight shots on July 13, hitting Trump in the ear, killing a rallygoer, and injuring two others. Rowe visited the site following the attack.\"And I laid in a prone position to evaluate his line of sight. What I saw made me ashamed,\" he said.Rowe also blamed local law enforcement for not securing the roof, which was outside the Secret Service perimeter. \"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said.Text messages between local police officers revealed that Crooks was spotted 90 minutes before the shooting. \"The only thing we had was that locals were working an issue at the 3 o'clock, which is to the right of the former president,\" Rowe explained.About 30 seconds before the shooting, a local officer radioed in that he saw Crooks with a rifle. \"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said.\"How is that even possible?!\" responded Republican Sen. Mike Lee.Rowe also revealed that radio communications from that day were not recorded. \"I have directed that we will now start recording those, moving forward,\" he said.Lawmakers questioned why the agents involved haven't been fired. \"I will tell you, Senator, that I will not rush to judgment. That people will be held accountable, and I will do so with integrity,\" Rowe responded to Republican Sen. Josh Hawley's demand to \"fire somebody!\"Rowe also testified that issues with mobile connectivity caused the agency's anti-drone technology to suffer around the time Crooks flew his drone before the event. He admitted struggling to understand how those issues came to be and whether the agency could have potentially stopped the shooter if it was working.The FBI Deputy Director revealed on Tuesday that a social media account they believe belonged to Crooks espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The agency is still investigating a motive, and it's not believed the shooter has co-conspirators.Rowe also promised to make the Secret Service agents who were in the field the day of the shooting available to be questioned by lawmakers in the coming days.\n\nActing Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe Jr. condemned the security failures that led to the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump as a \"failure on multiple levels.\"\n\n\"I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured,\" Rowe said.\n\nThis was the location from which Thomas Matthew Crooks fired eight shots on July 13, hitting Trump in the ear, killing a rallygoer, and injuring two others. {"uri": "8251514170", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:19:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:19:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:18:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://thebeltwayreport.com/2024/07/watch-ss-acting-dirs-face-when-confronted-with-the-fact-ss-knew-about-sniper-before-he-took-the-shot/", "title": "WATCH SS Acting Dir's Face When CONFRONTED With The Fact SS KNEW ABOUT SNIPER BEFORE He Took The Shot!", "body": "OPINION| In a recent Senate hearing, Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe faced tough questions from lawmakers about the agency's handling of the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump. The hearing, which took place on July 30, 2024, was part of a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting that occurred on July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nDuring the hearing, Rowe was confronted with an email from a Secret Service counter-sniper warning that the agency \"SHOULD EXPECT ANOTHER assassination attempt\" before November due to inadequate leadership. The email, sent to the agency's Uniformed Division on Monday night, highlighted concerns about the agency's ability to protect Trump in the lead-up to the Republican National Convention.\n\nRowe, who was elevated to the position of acting director following the resignation of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, admitted that the July 13 shooting was \"a failure on multiple levels.\" He revealed that neither the Secret Service counter-sniper teams nor members of Trump's security detail had any knowledge that there was a man on the roof of the American Glass Research building with a firearm.\n\nThe gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, was spotted on the roof less than 150 yards from where Trump was speaking. Despite this, Rowe claimed that the Secret Service was unaware of his presence until after the shooting had occurred.\n\nRowe's testimony came under fire from several lawmakers, including Senator Josh Hawley, who accused the Secret Service of making a politically motivated decision to deny Trump extra security. Hawley also questioned Rowe about the agency's decision to not secure the roof of the American Glass Research building, which he called \"indefensible.\"\n\n\"Isn't the fact that a former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded - isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be in the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" Hawley asked.\n\nRowe defended the agency's actions, stating that the Secret Service had made an assumption that there would be sufficient security coverage from local law enforcement. He also claimed that the agency had not received information from local law enforcement about the presence of an armed subject on the roof.\n\nThe hearing also revealed new details about the investigation into the shooting. The FBI announced that Crooks had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices, and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister. The bureau also revealed that Trump had agreed to be interviewed as a crime victim, as he had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one during the shooting.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8250740967", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "13:33:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T13:33:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T13:32:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/live-updates/trump-shooting-hearing-fbi-secret-service-assassination-attempt-senate/", "title": "FBI, Secret Service officials to testify about Trump shooting before Senate panels", "body": "Washington -- Top officials with the U.S. Secret Service and FBI are poised to testify before two Senate committees Tuesday about the security lapses that led to the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump during a campaign rally in Pennsylvania.\n\nThe joint hearing with FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate and Secret Service Acting Director Ronald Rowe, which begins at 10 a.m., will mark the third congressional proceeding in just over a week focused on the shooting at Trump's rally, where he and two others were injured, and one attendee was killed. Abbate and Rowe are testifying before members of the Senate Homeland Security Committee and Judiciary Committee.\n\nThe fallout from the July 13 attack led to the resignation of former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle, who announced her decision to step down from her post just one day after she faced sharp criticism from the House Oversight and Accountability Committee. Rowe, the agency's deputy director, was appointed to temporarily lead the Secret Service.\n\nThe Secret Service has faced significant criticism in the wake of the attack, as questions have arisen as to how the gunman, identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, was able to gain access to a rooftop so close to where Trump was addressing the crowd of supporters in Butler, Pennsylvania. He was killed by a Secret Service sniper after firing eight rounds from the roof of a building belonging to AGR International, which was outside the security perimeter controlled by the agency.\n\nFBI officials told reporters Monday that they believe Crooks used the building's HVAC system and piping to climb up onto the roof, and he was spotted wearing a backpack and walking near the AGR building roughly 15 minutes before opening fire.\n\nKevin Rojek, the special agent in charge of the FBI's Pittsburgh field office, said the shooter also searched for information related to power plants, mass shooting events, improvised explosive devices and the assassination attempt against the prime minister of Slovakia in May.\n\nThe former president has agreed to speak with the FBI about the
