{"uri": "8251078602", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:22:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:22:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:21:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://pressofatlanticcity.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/acting-secret-service-director-says-hes-ashamed-after-the-trump-assassination-attempt/article_fab4cbe2-ad7a-5bda-a37f-a82ff7f14205.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting wasn't secured", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers on Tuesday that he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured, faulting local law enforcement for not circulating urgent information ahead of the shooting and for not adequately protecting the scene.\n\nHe also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and said, \"What I saw made me ashamed.\" He said that the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalogue to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also repeatedly lacing into local law enforcement for not sharing information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been spotted on a roof near the rally site in the minutes before the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nPeople are also reading... 2 people killed, 7 others injured in accident on Black Horse Pike in Egg Harbor Township Woman killed in Egg Harbor Township crash was 8 months pregnant and mother of 4-year-old girl Judge hits Atlantic City Housing Authority with 75% rent abatements for ignoring court orders Witness describes fiery Black Horse Pike crash that killed 2 people, injured 7 What type of restaurant would you like to see at the former Tilton Inn site? Over 200 boaters parade through Cape May County waters to support Donald Trump Atlantic City Housing Authority extends time by which all Stanley Holmes residents must be out Atlantic City Boardwalk named top choice for spreading ashes Did the world's oldest message in a bottle just wash up on a beach in Ocean City? 4 arrested after Atlantic City police find drugs, guns in hotel room Relatives, community members mourn Wildwood Crest native fatally shot by ex-mother-in-law in New York Holy Spirit hires new girls basketball coach Hamilton Township police searching for missing 16-year-old Fish falls from sky in New Jersey, smashes windshield Cumberland County couple die by murder-suicide, prosecutor says\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots, less than 150 yards (135 meters) from the rally stage where Trump was speaking.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nTrump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before the gunman was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue. It also suggested that Rowe, with ready and detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers from both major political parties after responses that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nMuch of Tuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees focused on what Rowe suggested was inadequate information received by Secret Service personnel in the hour before the shooting, including that Crooks had been spotted on the roof.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers had spotted a suspicious-looking man pacing near the metal detectors and circulated but ultimately lost track of Crooks before he scaled the roof of a building at AGR International Inc. Shortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take responsibility.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"Isn't it the fact that the former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress, but he assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nSen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nOn Monday, the FBI revealed that Crooks had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. Trump, who appeared at events in the days after the shooting with a bandage on his right ear, said he expects the interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nAt Cheatle's hearing last week, she said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\nGet Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay up-to-date on the latest in local and national government and political topics with our newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9772518", "eventUri": "eng-9772518", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Washington (state)"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": {"uri": "8251339614", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:02:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:02:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:01:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/acting-secret-director-says-ashamed-205206830.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service director says he's 'ashamed' about Trump assassination attempt, as he avoids Sen. Lee's questions", "body": "The acting chief of the U.S. Secret Service told senators he was \"ashamed\" for his agency's failure to secure the rooftop from which a 20-year-old gunman took aim at former President Donald Trump at a rally in Pennsylvania on July 13. But despite his admission of fault, Republican lawmakers, including Sen. Mike Lee, pressed him for more answers at the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing Tuesday.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe said in his testimony. \"As a career law enforcement officer, and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nIn his testimony, Rowe detailed the action the federal agency has taken since the attack on Trump. But throughout the hearing, even as he explained the security failures at the rally, he failed to provide concrete answers about the Secret Service's lapses when questioned by GOP senators who accused the agency of treating Trump differently than they would President Joe Biden.\n\nSen. Mike Lee, R-Utah, pressed Rowe over why Trump took the stage minutes \"after multiple suspicious person reports were provided, complete with photos and information suggesting that the assailant had a range finder.\"\n\nRowe said the Secret Service didn't hear any communication about the individual being armed or having an intention to shoot. He said he would get back to Lee with the number of suspicious person reports the law enforcement agency received that day.\n\nIn his written testimony, Rowe said, \"At 5:43 p.m., a local Butler County Emergency Services Unit counter sniper team member texted the Secret Service counter sniper team leader about a suspicious person and sent two photos of the individual, later identified to be the assailant.\" The former president took the stage seven minutes later.\n\nLee continued, \"Would President Biden ever be allowed on stage under similar circumstances with an unresolved set of multiple suspicious person reports provided, including indicating that there was a rangefinder involved?\"\n\nTo this, Rowe said it would depend on the situation. \"For us, it comes down to ... a potential threat. Is the individual carrying an (improvised explosive device)? Is there a weapon?\"\n\nDuring his interaction with Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, Rowe maintained that \"Secret Service agents are not political.\" The conversation got heated when Cruz accused the federal agency of diverting resources from the Trump campaign to first lady Jill Biden's event. Rowe said Cruz's assertion was false.\n\nMeanwhile California Democratic Sen. Laphonza Butler praised Rowe for being \"authoritative.\"\n\nShe added, \"He has proven that he had been out at the camps, at the site, and he is taking responsibility.\"\n\nAccording to CNN, Cruz said Rowe appeared more \"forthcoming\" than Kimberly A. Cheatle, the former Secret Service director, who resigned after Republicans and Democrats called for her ouster after she testified in the U.S. House.\n\n\"That's a step forward,\" the Texas senator said. \"But when asked specific questions, (Rowe) would not provide specific answers.\"\n\nRowe sidestepped several of Lee's questions, including one about the eight shell casings found next to the assailant's body. \"He was neutralized after the first shot, where did those other shots come from?\" the Utah senator asked.\n\nRowe said the Secret Service is still carrying out a ballistic analysis. He also couldn't answer why the sniper teams were assigned to the rooftop overlooking where the shots were fired.\n\nLee called on Rowe to provide details to Congress on the questions left unanswered as more information comes to light. He also asked Rowe to submit the list of requests Trump's protective detail and campaign made to the Secret Service for additional resources.\n\nThe shooter fired three shots aimed at Trump at 6:11 p.m., around the same time when the sniper team checked in with local law enforcement about a tip of a suspicious person.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on the roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said at the hearing.\n\n\"Within three seconds, the former President's detail rushed the stage and covered former President Trump, shielding him with their bodies,\" Rowe said. Roughly 15 seconds later, the Secret Service neutralized the assailant. One of the first three shots pierced through Trump's ear, Rowe said.\n\nUpon Rowe's direction, the Secret Service will now require three agents to ensure security plans are vetted, expand the use of drones to detect threats on roofs and other high structures and heighten the use of agents, uniformed officers and technical support personnel for events like the upcoming Democratic National Convention in November.\n\nThe Secret Service also began protecting vice presidential nominee Sen. JD Vance and his family, as well as presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., whose father and uncle were killed by assassins.\n\nRowe also indicated during the hearing that the agency will add 200 agents to its force before the 2028 Olympics in Los Angeles, marking the first time the agency increased its staffing in a \"number of years.\"\n\nRowe promised his agency would cooperate with all the investigations launched into the attack, including those opened by Congress, the FBI, the Homeland Security Department and the White House. The Secret Service's Office of Professional Responsibility is conducting an internal review of whether any agents violated protocol.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8251343870", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:05:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:05:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:03:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://theglobalherald.com/news/new-secret-service-leadership-addresses-security-breaches-at-trump-rally/", "title": "New Secret Service Leadership Addresses Security Breaches at Trump Rally - The Global Herald", "body": "The newly appointed acting director of the U.S. Secret Service, Ronald Rowe, expressed grave concerns regarding security lapses that permitted an assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump during a congressional hearing held on Tuesday. During the intense session, both Rowe and FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate provided insights into the investigation surrounding the incident, detailing discoveries related to the alleged assailant and outlining the security deficiencies that were evident.\n\nRowe's appearance before a joint gathering of the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary committees followed the recent resignation of his predecessor, Kim Cheatle, who faced severe backlash for the Secret Service's management of a Trump rally in Butler on July 13, which resulted in a fatality and injuries to Trump and others.\n\nThroughout the often charged hearing, Rowe acknowledged the emotional strain that the events in Butler had on him and his personnel. \"My people are hurting right now,\" Rowe remarked, indicating the emotional rawness of the situation.\n\nOne significant shortcoming highlighted by Rowe was the inability of the Secret Service to utilize a \"counter unmanned aerial system\" before the event due to connectivity issues. This lack of preparedness may have led to the failure to detect a drone operated by the shooter, identified as Thomas Matthew Crooks, prior to the rally. Investigators later determined that Crooks had likely conducted preliminary surveillance of the site.\n\nRowe expressed, \"That is something that has cost me a lot of sleep,\" emphasizing the regret he experiences over the potential that the situation could have been mitigated if proactive measures had been taken. \"I have no explanation...I feel as though we could have found him,\" he added, suggesting that active law enforcement might have deterred the attack.\n\nRowe discussed that the Secret Service was already in the process of addressing the identified security gaps but was cautious about revealing too many specifics due to the sensitive nature of their operations. He did state that he would not await the conclusion of various investigations before implementing reforms to prevent future lapses.\n\nAmong the measures Rowe plans to introduce include improved internal communication among agents and coordination with local police, particularly in high-stakes environments. He noted that ineffective communication at the Butler event contributed to misunderstandings regarding potential threats.\n\nOne persistent question relates to how Crooks managed to bring a rifle onto the roof of a nearby building, from which he had a clear line of sight to Trump. While investigators have theories suggesting that the rifle may have been disassembled and concealed in a backpack, concrete evidence on this matter remains elusive.\n\nMoreover, as investigators sift through extensive digital evidence, they are still pursuing a clear motive for Crooks' actions. Abbate revealed the discovery of a social media account that may be linked to Crooks, containing posts reflective of extreme views, including antisemitic and anti-immigration sentiments.\n\nIn the course of the hearing, lawmakers voiced their expectations for accountability within the Secret Service. Senator Lindsey Graham noted, \"the best way to make sure it doesn't have to happen again is to fire people,\" emphasizing the need for consequences for security failures. Rowe assured that any violations of policy would be addressed and that accountability measures would be instituted, including potential terminations.\n\nThe unfolding investigation and the actions by the Secret Service leadership illustrate a significant focus on enhancing security and preventing similar incidents in the future.", "source": {"uri": "theglobalherald.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8251415109", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:19:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:19:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:16:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/07/30/nation/acting-head-secret-service-ashamed-that-roof-trump-rally-was-unwatched/", "title": "Acting head of Secret Service 'ashamed' that roof at Trump rally was unwatched - The Boston Globe", "body": "But Rowe also acknowledged to lawmakers that it was the Secret Service's responsibility to make that expectation clear to the local countersnipers there that day and that his agency might have failed to do so.\n\nIt was the most straightforward explanation yet of what led to the glaring security failure that allowed a would-be assassin to fire eight shots at Trump, injuring him and others and killing a rally attendee, at the Butler Farm Show grounds on July 13. Yet Rowe often acknowledged to lawmakers that he was baffled by some of the decisions made before and on the day of the shooting, including some by his own agency.\n\nHis testimony about the delineation of responsibility for protecting a roof that was within a rifle bullet's range of Trump highlighted a weak link in the protection of the country's leaders. While the Secret Service relies on local law enforcement agencies for assistance, these officers are typically not experienced in the requirements of protective operations and therefore need detailed instructions from the federal agency.\n\n\"We need to be very direct to our local law enforcement counterparts that they understand exactly what their expectation is,\" he said.\n\nUltimately, Rowe said, the events of July 13 were a result of \"a failure of imagination\" to see that \"we actually do live in a very dangerous world where people do actually want to do harm to our protectee.\"\n\n\"But we didn't challenge our own assumptions,\" he said. \"We assumed that someone is going to cover that.\"\n\nHis comments were sure to rankle some officers who assisted at the rally. Details about what happened have been inconsistent and confusing, as the multiple federal, state and local law enforcement agencies involved have offered their own accounts, leading to a dizzying array of fingerpointing.\n\nIn Butler, Rowe said, two local countersnipers were in one of the warehouses, watching the crowd from windows at the time the shooter, later identified as Thomas Crooks of Bethel Park, Pa., ascended to the roof of the adjacent warehouse. He said that, in his view, the countersnipers would have been able to see Crooks on the roof if they had looked left out the window.\n\n\"We are looking at this, and they should have been on the roof, and the fact they were in the building is something I'm still trying to understand,\" Rowe said, adding that in the future, the Secret Service would ensure that local and state law enforcement are on roofs.\n\nLocal law enforcement officials have previously said the countersnipers were given permission from the Secret Service to surveil the fenced-in grounds from the warehouse windows because of the heat that day.\n\nRichard Goldinger, the Butler County district attorney who oversees the local countersnipers who were at the rally, issued a statement previously saying that the Secret Service never told his agents to cover the roof that Crooks used. \"I stand by my prior statement that that was not part of their duties that day,\" Goldinger said Tuesday.\n\nDuring the three-hour joint hearing before the Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs and Judiciary committees, Rowe offered more details about the sequence of events on July 13 than his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, did a week ago, drawing bipartisan outrage from House lawmakers. Cheatle resigned the following day.\n\nRowe described problems with communications among law enforcement agencies that delayed crucial information from being relayed to the Secret Service. There was a 30-second window between when local law enforcement saw Crooks with a firearm and when Crooks started shooting. It would have been enough time for a Secret Service countersniper to react, Rowe said, but only if the countersniper had received that information contemporaneously.\n\n\"It appears that that information was stuck or siloed in that state and local channel,\" Rowe said, drawing questions from lawmakers about why the various law enforcement agencies could not communicate with one another better.\n\nAll the Secret Service knew, he said, was that local law enforcement was working on an issue regarding a suspicious person. While the Secret Service received a photograph of Crooks about 30 minutes before the shooting, he was one of several who had drawn the eye of local law enforcement that day.\n\nThe agency also had plans to use equipment that would have detected the gunman's use of a drone hours before the shooting. But problems with the local cellular service delayed that from happening. Rowe said this is one issue that he has lost sleep over.\n\n\"I have no explanation for it,\" Rowe said. \"We could have maybe stopped him.\"\n\nMultiple investigations are underway into what happened on July 13 and what led Crooks to try to kill Trump.\n\nTrump has complimented his Secret Service detail for its bravery. But overall, he said, there were holes.\n\n\"Nobody on that roof and, and no coordination with the police, it seems to be coming out that there was absolutely no coordination,\" Trump said Tuesday during an interview with a New York radio station. \"And that's, that's a pretty bad thing, when you think of it.\"\n\nIn one of his first actions as acting director, Rowe said, he went to the site of the shooting and specifically to the warehouse roof that the gunman used. Rowe climbed onto the building and lay on the roof so he could see the direct line that the shooter had to Trump.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston {"uri": "8251071052", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:16:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:16:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:15:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://theeagle.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/acting-secret-service-director-says-hes-ashamed-after-the-trump-assassination-attempt/article_656e33bb-f98b-50f3-9326-0995c126a763.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting wasn't secured", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers on Tuesday that he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured, faulting local law enforcement for not circulating urgent information ahead of the shooting and for not adequately protecting the scene.\n\nHe also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and said, \"What I saw made me ashamed.\" He said that the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalogue to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also repeatedly lacing into local law enforcement for not sharing information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been spotted on a roof near the rally site in the minutes before the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nPeople are also reading... Hometown superhero: College Station's Brianna Hildebrand lands in 'Deadpool & Wolverine' A&M's Prager passes on Angels and will return Texas A&M announces 2024 class of distinguished alumni Rudder's Kimora Maxey has run cut short at Junior Olympics Chris Johnson makes return to Bryan as football team's offensive coordinator After closure, Village Cafe staff creates weekly food delivery business Noms of the Week Texas A&M student claims dorm mold caused adverse health effects Teen victim identified in College Station homicide A&M tennis greats Krajicek, Habib get things rolling for the Aggies in Paris Texas A&M selected for research security initiative by National Science Foundation Rudder's Kimora Maxey qualifies for girls 100-meter hurdles semifinals at Junior Olympics The Eagle's 2024 All-Brazos Valley Baseball Team BVSWMA eliminates tipping fees, saving Bryan-College Station $6M yearly Profiles of Aggies at the Paris Olympics Activist protests against CPS system at Brazos County Courthouse\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots, less than 150 yards (135 meters) from the rally stage where Trump was speaking.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nTrump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before the gunman was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue. It also suggested that Rowe, with ready and detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers from both major political parties after responses that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nMuch of Tuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees focused on what Rowe suggested was inadequate information received by Secret Service personnel in the hour before the shooting, including that Crooks had been spotted on the roof.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers had spotted a suspicious-looking man pacing near the metal detectors and circulated but ultimately lost track of Crooks before he scaled the roof of a building at AGR International Inc. Shortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take responsibility.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"Isn't it the fact that the former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress, but he assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nSen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nOn Monday, the FBI revealed that Crooks had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. Trump, who appeared at events in the days after the shooting with a bandage on his right ear, said he expects the interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nAt Cheatle's hearing last week, she said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\nGet Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay up-to-date on the latest in local and national government and political topics with our newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and {"uri": "8251580816", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:47:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:47:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:46:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/trump-shooting-failure-multiple-levels-003731980.html", "title": "Trump shooting 'a failure on multiple levels,' acting U.S. Secret Service chief says", "body": "Republican presidential candidate former President Donald Trump is rushed offstage during a rally on July 13, 2024 in Butler, Pennsylvania. (Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images)\n\nWASHINGTON -- When acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe Jr. visited the site of the campaign rally where a gunman attempted to assassinate former President Donald Trump, he went up to the roof, lying flat on his stomach, to evaluate the shooter's line of sight that mid-July day.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe told U.S. senators Tuesday. \"As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year-veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nRowe recounted his trip to Butler, Pennsylvania, which he said took place after being named acting director July 23, at a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs committees examining the security failures that led to the assassination attempt. Deputy FBI Director Paul Abbate also testified.\n\nIt was the first Senate hearing on the attempted assassination since a shooter killed one rallygoer, injured two others and shot Trump's ear using an AR-15-style rifle during a campaign event in Butler on July 13. The 20-year-old gunman was killed at the scene.\n\n\"Let me be clear: This was an attack on our democracy,\" said Sen. Gary Peters, chairman of the Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee.\n\n\"Americans should be able to attend a political rally and express their political beliefs without fear of violence, and political candidates for our nation's highest office should be confident that their safety will never be compromised for their service,\" the Michigan Democrat added.\n\nPeters launched a bipartisan investigation into the security failures leading to the assassination attempt alongside ranking Republican Rand Paul of Kentucky. It's one of several congressional inquiries examining the failures of law enforcement that day.\n\nRowe stepped into his post after Kimberly Cheatle resigned as director last week. The day before her resignation, Cheatle testified in front of the House Committee on Oversight and Accountability, where lawmakers on both sides of the aisle berated her over the agency's failures to prevent the attempted assassination of Trump.\n\nFacing heavy criticism, many lawmakers called on Cheatle to resign. House Oversight Chairman James Comer of Kentucky and ranking member Jamie Raskin of Maryland also urged her to step down in a joint letter shortly after that hearing.\n\nRowe said the attempted assassination was \"a failure to imagine that we actually do live in a very dangerous world where people do actually want to do harm to our protectees.\"\n\n\"I think it was a failure to challenge our own assumptions -- the assumptions that we know our partners are going to do everything they can, and they do this every day,\" he added.\n\nSenators sought to uncover what went wrong, what policies are in place to facilitate real-time information sharing between the Secret Service and local law enforcement during an event and whether the Secret Service is developing a security plan for the upcoming Democratic National Convention in Chicago that takes into account what they learned from the July shooting.\n\nNeither the Secret Service counter sniper teams nor members of Trump's security detail \"had any knowledge that there was a man on the roof of the ... building with a firearm,\" according to Rowe.\n\nRowe said \"prior to that, they were operating with the knowledge that local law enforcement was working an issue of a suspicious individual prior to the shots being fired.\"\n\nAbbate noted that despite not having any definitive evidence as to how the gunman got the weapon onto the roof, they believe based on what they have gathered thus far that he likely had the rifle in a backpack.\n\nMeanwhile, Abbate said the FBI uncovered a social media account believed to be associated with the shooter, though they are still working to verify that the account belonged to him.\n\nMore than 700 comments were posted from the social media account \"in about the 2019, 2020 timeframe,\" when the shooter would have been in his mid-teens, and some of the comments \"appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature,\" Abbate said.\n\nAbbate said though nothing has been ruled out, the FBI's investigation has not identified any motive, co-conspirators or people with advanced knowledge. The FBI has so far held more than 460 interviews, received over 2,000 tips from the public, executed search warrants and seized electronic media.\n\nTuesday's hearing came the day after U.S. House Speaker Mike Johnson and Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries announced 13 lawmakers comprising a bipartisan task force to investigate the attempted assassination. The resolution creating the panel requires a final report by mid-December.\n\nRep. Mike Kelly, a Pennsylvania Republican whose district includes Butler, will chair the task force.\n\nRepublican Sen. Chuck Grassley of Iowa and Democratic Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto of Nevada introduced bipartisan legislation last week that would require Senate confirmation of Secret Service directors and limit them to one term of 10 years.", "source": {"uri": "8250938527", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:41:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:41:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:40:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/acting-secret-service-boss-cannot-defend-why-roof-in-trump-rally-shooting-wasnt-secured/article_3c07c8ac-471a-5362-a3c4-7c1b5c50523d.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting wasn't secured", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The acting director of the Secret Service says he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman in the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump was not secured.\n\nRonald Rowe is testifying Tuesday before two Senate committees. Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nPeople are also reading... Homeless and dying: La Crosse veteran diagnosed with heart failure finds peace in final weeks Mayo Clinic likely to demolish 94-year-old St. Francis Hospital building after opening new La Crosse facility Steve Cahalan: City panel to review plans for new Starbucks at Valley View Mall New building plans unveiled, along with TIF agreement at La Crosse's $300M River Point District project Complaint says La Crosse man assaulted with sheathed machete during 'school yard brawl' on lawn La Crosse County examines large affordable housing development in West Salem with nearly 600 units La Crosse man faces charges for driving under the influence of marijuana Steve Cahalan: LAX Grille opens, Pastissimo is leaving and Ichiddo Ramen is coming to La Crosse Man accused of OWI while pulling camper containing 9 kids, Wisconsin State Patrol says New retreat house for pilgrims and visitors at Shrine of Our Lady Guadalupe would house up to 66 guests Steve Cahalan: Candle maker adds to number of woman-owned shops in downtown Galesville Daylong standoff ends with arrest of man who shot Sauk County deputy, authorities say No injuries, one dog rescued from fire on Rose Street in La Crosse Three injured in two-vehicle head-on crash in rural De Soto Vintage Star Wars, G.I. Joe sets give estate shoppers chance to live out their 'man-childhood'\n\nSenate lawmakers are grilling the officials about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump in the latest in a series of congressional hearings dedicated to the shooting.\n\nRowe became acting director of the agency last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned in the aftermath of a House hearing in which she was berated by lawmakers and failed to answer specific questions about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\n\"If this happened in the military, a lot of people would be fired,\" said Sen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nGet Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay up-to-date on the latest in local and national government and political topics with our newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user {"uri": "8251068502", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:14:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:14:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:13:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/acting-secret-service-director-says-hes-ashamed-after-the-trump-assassination-attempt/article_fc4a3747-b501-50f6-9b0e-3b0385453ec8.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting wasn't secured", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers on Tuesday that he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured, faulting local law enforcement for not circulating urgent information ahead of the shooting and for not adequately protecting the scene.\n\nHe also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and said, \"What I saw made me ashamed.\" He said that the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalogue to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also repeatedly lacing into local law enforcement for not sharing information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been spotted on a roof near the rally site in the minutes before the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nPeople are also reading... Roses Discount Store in Marion set to close in August McDowell calendar: Trump Road Rally goes from Morganton to Marion, and more events Two Marion women charged with drug crimes Sheriff: Marion man intentionally hit pedestrian with car Young child found wandering on road in Morganton alone; mother charged McDowell girls basketball coach Zack McCartha to coach in 2025 East-West All-Star game Hickory law firm partner disbarred for taking $55,000 for personal use McDowell native wants to create Marion walk of fame Play by McDowell 14-year-old centers on Marion water treatment Family of missing Burke woman pleads for her return; $1K reward offered Drag queens help open Olympics but 'Last Supper' tableau draws criticism McDowell Titans wrapping up summer camp as 2024 football season nears Three polling places changing in McDowell County Catawba County mother charged in death of 9-month-old appears in court Orchard at Altapass releases August 2024 music and events schedule\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots, less than 150 yards (135 meters) from the rally stage where Trump was speaking.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nTrump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before the gunman was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue. It also suggested that Rowe, with ready and detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers from both major political parties after responses that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nMuch of Tuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees focused on what Rowe suggested was inadequate information received by Secret Service personnel in the hour before the shooting, including that Crooks had been spotted on the roof.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers had spotted a suspicious-looking man pacing near the metal detectors and circulated but ultimately lost track of Crooks before he scaled the roof of a building at AGR International Inc. Shortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take responsibility.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"Isn't it the fact that the former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress, but he assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nSen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nOn Monday, the FBI revealed that Crooks had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. Trump, who appeared at events in the days after the shooting with a bandage on his right ear, said he expects the interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nAt Cheatle's hearing last week, she said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\nGet Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay up-to-date on the latest in local and national government and political topics with our newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and {"uri": "8251293424", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:22:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:22:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:21:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www2.cbn.com/news/us/secret-service-failures-exposed-ashamed-acting-director-visits-roof-where-trump-shooter", "title": "Secret Service Failures Exposed: 'Ashamed' Acting Director Visits Roof Where Trump Shooter Fired", "body": "PHOTO: U.S. Secret Service Acting Director Ronald Rowe, left, and Federal Bureau of Investigation Deputy Director Paul Abbate, right, testify to questions during a Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Senate Judiciary hearing examining the security failures leading to the assassination attempt on Republican presidential candidate former President Donald Trump, Tuesday, July 30, 2024 in Washington. (AP Photo/Rod Lamkey, Jr.)\n\nWASHINGTON - Recent revelations surrounding the assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump have exposed critical failures within the Secret Service. During a high-profile hearing on Capitol Hill Tuesday, Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe testified about significant oversights in the agency's security measures.\n\nIn his testimony before two Senate committees, Rowe conceded that the Secret Service's failure to secure the roof from which the gunman fired was a grave error.\n\n\"I went to the roof of the AGR building where the assailant fired shots and I laid in a prone position to evaluate his line of sight. What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe stated. His remarks represent the agency's most direct admission of fault since the attack on July 13th.\n\nThe revelation comes on the heels of new information from the FBI. It was disclosed that the gunman, identified as Thomas Crooks, had actively searched for details on previous mass casualty events as well as current and former U.S. Presidents, raising questions about the effectiveness of the Secret Service's intelligence and security protocols.\n\nDuring the hearing, Rowe emphasized that the failure lay not with local law enforcement but with the Secret Service.\n\n\"As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year veteran of the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured,\" he said.\n\nThis admission follows Rowe's appointment to lead the agency after Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned under pressure for failing to address communication failures during a previous House hearing.\n\nSen. Roger Marshall (R-Kansas) criticized the Secret Service's handling of the situation, labeling it a \"dysfunctional organization\" and pointing to serious lapses in security management.\n\nAdding to the scrutiny, members of the Beaver County SWAT team, who played a critical role during the incident, expressed frustration over the lack of communication and coordination with the Secret Service.\n\nGreg Nichol, a member of the SWAT team, noted that the shooter's behavior seemed suspicious and out of place but questioned whether this information reached Trump's security detail.\n\nJason Woods, also from the Beaver County SWAT, highlighted that there was no face-to-face briefing with Secret Service snipers before the rally.\n\nIn response to these revelations, former President Trump defended the Secret Service agents but criticized the lack of security on the roof and poor communication with local police. Trump has agreed to be interviewed by FBI agents regarding the incident, with the interview expected to take place on Thursday.", "source": {"uri": "cbn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBN.com - Rowe says he recently traveled to the Pennsylvania shooting site and says what he saw made him ashamed.\n\nRowe is being joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nThe FBI's No. 2 official says a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, would have been in high school.\n\nPeople are also reading... Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee. \"And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe hearing comes one day after the FBI released new details about its investigation into the shooting, revealing that the gunman had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. The bureau said last week that the former president had been struck in the ear by a bullet or fragment of one. Trump said Monday evening that he expected that interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nBut most of the questions Tuesday are expected to be directed at Rowe as lawmakers demand answers about how Crooks was able to get so close to Trump. Investigators believe Crooks fired eight shots in Trump's direction from an AR-style rifle after scaling the roof of a building of some 135 meters (147 yards) from where Trump was speaking in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nOne rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured. Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\nSubscribe to stay connected to Tucson. {"uri": "8252204941", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:08:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:08:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:06:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.westhawaiitoday.com/2024/07/31/nation-world-news/acting-head-of-secret-service-ashamed-that-roof-at-trump-rally-was-unwatched/", "title": "Acting head of Secret Service 'ashamed' that roof at Trump rally was unwatched - West Hawaii Today", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The acting Secret Service director told senators Tuesday that the agency failed on July 13 by not having a countersniper focused on the roof where a would-be assassin fired eight shots at former President Donald Trump, injuring him and others and killing a rally attendee.\n\nWhile Ronald L. Rowe Jr., the acting director, provided a more complete account of what happened that day than his predecessor did a week ago, he failed to answer a crucial question about that day: Who was supposed to be watching that roof?\n\nIn one of his first actions as acting director, Rowe said he went to the site of the shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, and specifically to the warehouse roof that the gunman used, which had been unmanned and apparently unwatched.\n\nRowe said he climbed onto the building and laid on the roof so he could see the direct line that the shooter, later identified as Thomas Crooks of Bethel Park, Pennsylvania, had to Trump.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe told a joint hearing of the Senate Homeland Security and Judiciary committees. \"As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nHe said the Secret Service would ensure that local and or state law enforcement are on roofs in the future. In Butler, there were two local countersnipers in one of the warehouse buildings, watching the crowd from windows, at the time Crooks ascended to the roof of the adjacent warehouse.\n\n\"We are looking at this, and they should have been on the roof, and the fact they were in the building is something I'm still trying to understand,\" Rowe said.\n\nThe Butler County district attorney, who oversees local countersnipers who were at the rally, has previously said that the Secret Service never told his agents to cover the roof Crooks used.\n\nRowe described problems with communications among law enforcement agencies that ultimately delayed crucial information from being relayed to the Secret Service. He said that the agency's plans to use equipment that would have detected the gunman's use of a drone hours earlier was stymied by the local cellular service.\n\nUltimately, Rowe said, the events of July 13 were a result of \"a failure of imagination\" to see that \"we actually do live in a very dangerous world where people do actually want to do harm to our protectee.\"\n\n\"But we didn't challenge our own assumptions,\" he said. \"We assumed that someone is going to cover that.\"\n\nThis article originally appeared in The New York Times.", "source": {"uri": "westhawaiitoday.com", {"uri": "8251374792", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:32:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:32:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:31:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://penncapital-star.com/dc-bureau/trump-shooting-a-failure-on-multiple-levels-acting-u-s-secret-service-chief-says/", "title": "Trump shooting 'a failure on multiple levels,' acting U.S. Secret Service chief says * Pennsylvania Capital-Star", "body": "WASHINGTON -- When acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe Jr. visited the site of the campaign rally where a gunman attempted to assassinate former President Donald Trump, he went up to the roof, lying flat on his stomach, to evaluate the shooter's line of sight that mid-July day.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed,\" Rowe told U.S. senators Tuesday. \"As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year-veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured.\"\n\nRowe recounted his trip to Butler, Pennsylvania, which he said took place after being named acting director July 23, at a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs committees examining the security failures that led to the assassination attempt. Deputy FBI Director Paul Abbate also testified.\n\nIt was the first Senate hearing on the attempted assassination since a shooter killed one rallygoer, injured two others and shot Trump's ear using an AR-15-style rifle during a campaign event in Butler on July 13. The 20-year-old gunman was killed at the scene.\n\n\"Let me be clear: This was an attack on our democracy,\" said Sen. Gary Peters, chairman of the Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee.\n\n\"Americans should be able to attend a political rally and express their political beliefs without fear of violence, and political candidates for our nation's highest office should be confident that their safety will never be compromised for their service,\" the Michigan Democrat added.\n\nPeters launched a bipartisan investigation into the security failures leading to the assassination attempt alongside ranking Republican Rand Paul of Kentucky. It's one of several congressional inquiries examining the failures of law enforcement that day.\n\nRowe stepped into his post after Kimberly Cheatle resigned as director last week. The day before her resignation, Cheatle testified in front of the House Committee on Oversight and Accountability, where lawmakers on both sides of the aisle berated her over the agency's failures to prevent the attempted assassination of Trump.\n\nFacing heavy criticism, many lawmakers called on Cheatle to resign. House Oversight Chairman James Comer of Kentucky and ranking member Jamie Raskin of Maryland also urged her to step down in a joint letter shortly after that hearing.\n\nRowe said the attempted assassination was \"a failure to imagine that we actually do live in a very dangerous world where people do actually want to do harm to our protectees.\"\n\n\"I think it was a failure to challenge our own assumptions -- the assumptions that we know our partners are going to do everything they can, and they do this every day,\" he added.\n\nSenators sought to uncover what went wrong, what policies are in place to facilitate real-time information sharing between the Secret Service and local law enforcement during an event and whether the Secret Service is developing a security plan for the upcoming Democratic National Convention in Chicago that takes into account what they learned from the July shooting.\n\nNeither the Secret Service counter sniper teams nor members of Trump's security detail \"had any knowledge that there was a man on the roof of the ... building with a firearm,\" according to Rowe.\n\nRowe said \"prior to that, they were operating with the knowledge that local law enforcement was working an issue of a suspicious individual prior to the shots being fired.\"\n\nAbbate noted that despite not having any definitive evidence as to how the gunman got the weapon onto the roof, they believe based on what they have gathered thus far that he likely had the rifle in a backpack.\n\nMeanwhile, Abbate said the FBI uncovered a social media account believed to be associated with the shooter, though they are still working to verify that the account belonged to him.\n\nMore than 700 comments were posted from the social media account \"in about the 2019, 2020 timeframe,\" when the shooter would have been in his mid-teens, and some of the comments \"appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature,\" Abbate said.\n\nAbbate said though nothing has been ruled out, the FBI's investigation has not identified any motive, co-conspirators or people with advanced knowledge. The FBI has so far held more than 460 interviews, received over 2,000 tips from the public, executed search warrants and seized electronic media.\n\nTuesday's hearing came the day after U.S. House Speaker Mike Johnson and Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries announced 13 lawmakers comprising a bipartisan task force to investigate the attempted assassination. The resolution creating the panel requires a final report by mid-December.\n\nRep. Mike Kelly, a Pennsylvania Republican whose district includes Butler, will chair the task force.\n\nRepublican Sen. Chuck Grassley of Iowa and Democratic Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto of Nevada introduced bipartisan legislation last week that would require Senate confirmation of Secret Service directors and limit them to one term of 10 years.", "source": {"uri": "8251068633", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:14:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:14:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:14:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://buffalonews.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/acting-secret-service-director-says-hes-ashamed-after-the-trump-assassination-attempt/article_38024388-2621-5d94-963e-c7e82b22d056.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service boss 'cannot defend' why roof in Trump rally shooting wasn't secured", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers on Tuesday that he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured, faulting local law enforcement for not circulating urgent information ahead of the shooting and for not adequately protecting the scene.\n\nHe also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and said, \"What I saw made me ashamed.\" He said that the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalogue to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also repeatedly lacing into local law enforcement for not sharing information that a gunman, later identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, had been spotted on a roof near the rally site in the minutes before the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nPeople are also reading... Kim Pegula greets Bills players, coaches after training camp practice: 'That's still the Mama Bear' Erie County prosecutor charged with misconduct, fired from DA's office Mystery still unsolved: Niagara Falls Police conclude probe into Rainbow Bridge crash that killed couple Another property near the new Bills stadium is going up for sale Bills GM Brandon Beane claps back at NFL executive who called Josh Allen 'overrated' End of an era as Rev. Jud Weiksnar departs, leaving Buffalo without Franciscans for first time in 166 years The NFL hopes its radical new kickoff rule produces excitement. Here's how it will work Under pressure: Some Bills fans feeling angst over new stadium season ticket decision 97 Rock's 'Slick Tom' Tiberi fired over Facebook meme showing Trump in coffin Kenmore East sophomore dies after being hit while riding bicycle Judge dismisses lawsuit filed by Dunkirk mother drug tested without consent at Children's Hospital Sabres sign goalie Ukko-Pekka Luukkonen to five-year, $23.75 million deal Salamanca killer Edward Kindt breaks parole, taken into custody Erie County real estate transactions Man hospitalized with severe leg injury after Chautauqua Lake boating mishap\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots, less than 150 yards (135 meters) from the rally stage where Trump was speaking.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nTrump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before the gunman was killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue. It also suggested that Rowe, with ready and detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers from both major political parties after responses that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nMuch of Tuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees focused on what Rowe suggested was inadequate information received by Secret Service personnel in the hour before the shooting, including that Crooks had been spotted on the roof.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers had spotted a suspicious-looking man pacing near the metal detectors and circulated but ultimately lost track of Crooks before he scaled the roof of a building at AGR International Inc. Shortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take responsibility.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n\"Isn't it the fact that the former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress, but he assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nSen. Lindsey Graham, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said if something like this happened in the military, \"a lot of people would be fired. And if a lot of people are not fired, the system failed yet again.\"\n\nHe added: \"Nothing's going to change until somebody loses their job.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment. The posts were from the 2019 and 2020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nOn Monday, the FBI revealed that Crooks had looked online for information about mass shootings, power plants, improvised explosive devices and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI also said that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim. Trump, who appeared at events in the days after the shooting with a bandage on his right ear, said he expects the interview to take place on Thursday.\n\nAt Cheatle's hearing last week, she said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\n\"They didn't speak to each other,\" he said.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have been good if it was nine seconds sooner.\"\n\n0 Comments Get Government & Politics updates in your inbox!\n\nStay up-to-date on the latest in local and national government and political topics with our newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I
