{"uri": "8251328956", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:52:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:52:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:52:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.texastribune.org/2024/07/30/ted-cruz-trump-secret-service-assassination/", "title": "Ted Cruz, Secret Service leader tangle at Senate hearing over assassi...", "body": "Sign up for the We the Texans newsletter to receive twice-monthly updates on our year-long initiative dedicated to boosting civic engagement and chronicling how democracy is experienced in Texas.\n\nWASHINGTON -- U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz accused the U.S. Secret Service on Tuesday of making a politically motivated decision to deny former President Donald Trump extra security, exposing him to an assassination attempt during a campaign rally in Pennsylvania earlier this month.\n\n\"I believe the Secret Service leadership made a political decision to deny these requests,\" Cruz said during a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees Tuesday. \"And I believe the Biden administration has been suffused with partisan politics.\"\n\nRonald Rowe, acting director of the Secret Service who has served since 1999 for presidents of both parties, responded indignantly to the remark in a tense exchange where he asserted, \"Secret Service agents are not political.\"\n\nCruz retorted that Secret Service leadership is appointed by the president and is therefore a political position.\n\nSecret Service has faced withering bipartisan criticism after a gunman came within an inch of shooting Trump in the head during a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, just ahead of the Republican National Convention. Trump's ear was grazed by a bullet, the FBI later reported, but he was otherwise unharmed.\n\nKim Cheatle, who was director of the agency when the shooting occurred, faced ire from lawmakers in both parties for her role in one of the biggest security failures since the 1981 attempted assassination of President Ronald Reagan. Secret Service failed to prevent Thomas Crooks, a 20-year-old man, from gaining access to a roof where he had a clear shot at the former president. Cheatle resigned from her post last week.\n\nThe U.S. House has opened a bipartisan inquiry into the security failures. U.S. Rep. Pat Fallon, R-Sherman, was named to serve on the inquiry, the only Texan.\n\nCruz has also previously blamed Secret Service's efforts to diversify its ranks for distracting the agency from its core mission of protecting officials. During a podcast he released two weeks ago -- after the Butler shooting -- Cruz criticized the agency for its efforts to have 30% of agents be women by 2030.\n\n\"Well, this is yet another manifestation of what we've seen throughout the Biden administration, which is an obsessive focus on bean counting, on quotas, on DEI at the expense of the mission,\" Cruz said.\n\nSecret Service spokesperson Anthony Guglielmi said to CNN that criticisms of female officers \"an insult to the women of our agency to imply that they are unqualified based on gender. Such baseless assertions undermine the professionalism, dedication and expertise of our workforce.\"\n\nCruz confronted Rowe with reporting by The Washington Post that Trump's security detail repeatedly -- and unsuccessfully -- requested additional resources from Secret Service in the years leading to the Butler, Pennsylvania, rally. Rowe acknowledged that that may have been the case in the past but said no resources were denied for the Butler rally.\n\nCruz demanded a full accounting of requests from Trump's security detail and Secret Service's responses, which Rowe agreed to provide. Cruz also repeatedly asked for who in the agency denied requests by Trump's security detail and was unsatisfied when Rowe said requests went through an approval process.\n\n\"It's a conversation. It's not just an absolute yea or nay,\" Rowe said of approving additional security requests.\n\n\"Does the buck stop anywhere?\" Cruz asked.\n\nCruz also asked for the size of Trump's security detail relative to President Joe Biden's. Rowe said Trump traveled with a full security crew, though he acknowledged a sitting president has more personnel.\n\n\"What's the difference?\" Cruz interjected.\n\n\"National command authority to launch a nuclear strike, sir,\" Rowe responded, impatience rising in his voice. \"There are other assets that travel with the president that the former president will not get.\"\n\nRowe said he would get a more detailed breakdown in the number of personnel for Trump and Biden for Cruz.\n\nDuring the hearing, Rowe placed much of the blame for the security failures in Butler with local police. Secret Service often delegates to state and local law enforcement to cover all vulnerabilities.\n\nSen. John Cornyn, R-Texas, who also serves on the Judiciary Committee, asked Rowe how the Secret Service, \"being an elite law enforcement agency, would delegate to local enforcement or others who did not meet\" the same standards as their agency, which admits only two percent of applicants.\n\n\"It was a failure to challenge our assumptions,\" Rowe responded. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniform presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there were going to be counter sniper teams in the AGR building, and I can assure you that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"", "source": {"uri": "texastribune.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Texas Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "matthew_choi@texastribune.org", "name": "Matthew {"uri": "8250913645", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:23:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:23:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:22:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/us/secret-service-did-not-know-trump-shooter-had-gun-until-shots-fired-official-5696449", "title": "Secret Service Did Not Know Trump Shooter Had Gun Until Shots Fired: Official", "body": "The Secret Service counter-snipers and personnel guarding former President Donald Trump on July 13 were both unaware that a man on the rooftop of a nearby building had a gun, the agency's top official said on Tuesday.\n\n\"Neither the Secret Service counter-sniper teams, nor members of the former president's security detail, had any knowledge that there was a man on the roof of the AGR building with a firearm,\" Ronald Rowe Jr., the Secret Service's acting director, told senators on Capitol Hill in Washington.\n\n\"It is my understanding that those personnel were not aware the assailant had a firearm until they heard gunshots,\" he added. \"Prior to that, they were operating with the knowledge that local law enforcement was working an issue of a suspicious individual prior to the shots being fired.\"\n\nThomas Crooks, 20, climbed onto the rooftop of the AGR building in Butler, Pennsylvania, on July 13 as the former president was speaking, according to authorities. Mr. Crooks allegedly fired multiple shots from a rifle starting at 6:11 p.m. He hit four people, including the former president. Former President Trump and two others survived, but the other individual, firefighter Corey Comperatore, died.\n\nAfter Mr. Crooks pointed his rifle at the officer, the officer dropped to the ground, officials say.\n\n\"I know that local law enforcement was attempting to locate him,\" Mr. Rowe said, after Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) wondered why Secret Service personnel did not take action once Mr. Crooks was seen with a rangefinder.\n\nOnce Mr. Crooks fired his weapon, a Secret Service counter-sniper took him out within seconds, Mr. Rowe said on Tuesday. The counter-sniper had full discretion to respond to the attack and did not need authorization to fire, according to Mr. Rowe.\n\nThe acting director said he was proud of Secret Service agents' dedication while vowing to hold personnel accountable if an internal investigation finds failures. He said that some personnel may be fired.\n\nMr. Rowe was testifying for the first time since being named acting director in the wake of the resignation of Kimberly Cheatle, who was director when the {"uri": "8251072241", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:18:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:18:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T17:16:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/rep-mike-kelly-tapped-lead-163017138.html", "title": "Rep. Mike Kelly tapped to lead bipartisan House task force on Trump assassination attempt", "body": "U.S. Rep. Mike Kelly will chair a House committee that will investigate the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump at a rally in Kelly's hometown of Butler.\n\nThe Pennsylvania Republican, who represents the 16th Congressional District, was appointed by Speaker of the House Mike Johnson to lead the bipartisan task force, which will include seven Republicans and six Democrats. Kelly sponsored the legislation to form the task force, which was approved last week.\n\nIn a statement, Kelly thanked Johnson for entrusting him in with the \"important and solemn role\" and he said the task force must \"set politics aside\" to \"restore the faith, trust and confidence\" in our government.\"\n\nMinutes into a rally at the Butler Farm Show grounds on July 13, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks opened fire with an AR-style rifle from the roof of a building near where Trump was speaking. Crooks killed one attendee, Corey Comperatore, a volunteer firefighter who was attempting to shield his wife and daughters when he was struck in the head, and injured two others, who have since been released from the hospital. One of the bullets or bullet fragments grazed Trump's right ear, according to the FBI.\n\nCrooks was killed by U.S. Secret Service sniper fire, which came from an agent positioned on the roof of another building.\n\nThe U.S. Secret Service and other law enforcement agencies at the rally have faced questions about how Crooks was able to get on the roof and open fire. Reports indicate that several people, including law enforcement, spotted Crooks before the incident and reported him as suspicious. Secret Service snipers spotted Crooks on the roof 20 minutes before the shooting.\n\nFormer U.S. Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle was forced to resign July 23, a day after a House Oversight Committee hearing in which lawmakers from both parties called on her to step down.\n\n\"It's critical that we investigate, detail, and explain the security breakdowns that tragically killed one person, injured two others, and nearly claimed President Trump's life,\" Kelly said in a statement. \"We must never let something like this happen again. The American people have a right to know what happened. Congress has a responsibility to find out.\"\n\nMore: Investigation into Trump shooting started within minutes on the roof, but questions linger\n\nJohnson and Democratic Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries issued a joint statement about the bipartisan task force:\n\n\"We have the utmost confidence in this bipartisan group of steady, highly qualified, and capable members of Congress to move quickly to find the facts, ensure accountability, and help make certain such failures never happen again,\" Johnson and Jeffries said.\n\nOn Tuesday, members of the U.S. Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs committees held a hearing on the assassination attempt, questioning the new acting director of the Secret Service, Ronald Rowe, and FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate. In his opening statement, Rowe characterized the security measures taken to protect Trump and rallygoers as a \"failure on multiple levels.\"\n\nMatthew Rink can be reached at mrink@timesnews.com or Crooks was shot dead by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nAt her hearing last week, Cheatle said the Secret Service had \"failed\" in its mission to protect Trump. She called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nCheatle acknowledged that the Secret Service was told about a suspicious person two to five times before the shooting at the rally. She also revealed that the roof from which Crooks opened fire had been identified as a potential vulnerability days before the rally.\n\nCheatle said she apologized to Trump in a phone call after the assassination attempt.\n\nIn a Monday night interview on Fox News Channel, Trump defended the Secret Service agents who protected him from the shooting but said that someone should have been on the roof with Crooks and that there should have been better communication with local police.\n\nHe praised the sniper who killed Crooks with what he said was an amazing shot but noted: \"It would have {"uri": "8251352061", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:11:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:11:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:09:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.click2houston.com/news/texas/2024/07/30/ted-cruz-secret-service-leader-tangle-at-senate-hearing-over-assassination-attempt-motive/", "title": "Ted Cruz, Secret Service leader tangle at Senate hearing over assassination attempt motive", "body": "Sign up for the We the Texans newsletter to receive twice-monthly updates on our year-long initiative dedicated to boosting civic engagement and chronicling how democracy is experienced in Texas.\n\nRecommended Videos\n\nWASHINGTON -- U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz accused the U.S. Secret Service on Tuesday of making a politically motivated decision to deny former President Donald Trump extra security, exposing him to an assassination attempt during a campaign rally in Pennsylvania earlier this month.\n\n\"I believe the Secret Service leadership made a political decision to deny these requests,\" Cruz said during a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees Tuesday. \"And I believe the Biden administration has been suffused with partisan politics.\"\n\nRonald Rowe, acting director of the Secret Service who has served since 1999 for presidents of both parties, responded indignantly to the remark in a tense exchange where he asserted, \"Secret Service agents are not political.\"\n\nCruz retorted that Secret Service leadership is appointed by the president and is therefore a political position.\n\nSecret Service has faced withering bipartisan criticism after a gunman came within an inch of shooting Trump in the head during a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, just ahead of the Republican National Convention. Trump's ear was grazed by a bullet, the FBI later reported, but he was otherwise unharmed.\n\nKim Cheatle, who was director of the agency when the shooting occurred, faced ire from lawmakers in both parties for her role in one of the biggest security failures since the 1981 attempted assassination of President Ronald Reagan. Secret Service failed to prevent Thomas Crooks, a 20-year-old man, from gaining access to a roof where he had a clear shot at the former president. Cheatle resigned from her post last week.\n\nThe U.S. House has opened a bipartisan inquiry into the security failures. U.S. Rep. Pat Fallon, R-Sherman, was named to serve on the inquiry, the only Texan.\n\nCruz has also previously blamed Secret Service's efforts to diversify its ranks for distracting the agency from its core mission of protecting officials. During a podcast he released two weeks ago -- after the Butler shooting -- Cruz criticized the agency for its efforts to have 30% of agents be women by 2030.\n\n\"Well, this is yet another manifestation of what we've seen throughout the Biden administration, which is an obsessive focus on bean counting, on quotas, on DEI at the expense of the mission,\" Cruz said.\n\nSecret Service spokesperson Anthony Guglielmi said to CNN that criticisms of female officers \"an insult to the women of our agency to imply that they are unqualified based on gender. Such baseless assertions undermine the professionalism, dedication and expertise of our workforce.\"\n\nCruz confronted Rowe with reporting by The Washington Post that Trump's security detail repeatedly -- and unsuccessfully -- requested additional resources from Secret Service in the years leading to the Butler, Pennsylvania, rally. Rowe acknowledged that that may have been the case in the past but said no resources were denied for the Butler rally.\n\nCruz demanded a full accounting of requests from Trump's security detail and Secret Service's responses, which Rowe agreed to provide. Cruz also repeatedly asked for who in the agency denied requests by Trump's security detail and was unsatisfied when Rowe said requests went through an approval process.\n\n\"It's a conversation. It's not just an absolute yea or nay,\" Rowe said of approving additional security requests.\n\n\"Does the buck stop anywhere?\" Cruz asked.\n\nCruz also asked for the size of Trump's security detail relative to President Joe Biden's. Rowe said Trump traveled with a full security crew, though he acknowledged a sitting president has more personnel.\n\n\"What's the difference?\" Cruz interjected.\n\n\"National command authority to launch a nuclear strike, sir,\" Rowe responded, impatience rising in his voice. \"There are other assets that travel with the president that the former president will not get.\"\n\nRowe said he would get a more detailed breakdown in the number of personnel for Trump and Biden for Cruz.\n\nDuring the hearing, Rowe placed much of the blame for the security failures in Butler with local police. Secret Service often delegates to state and local law enforcement to cover all vulnerabilities.\n\nSen. John Cornyn, R-Texas, who also serves on the Judiciary Committee, asked Rowe how the Secret Service, \"being an elite law enforcement agency, would delegate to local enforcement or others who did not meet\" the same standards as their agency, which admits only two percent of applicants.\n\n\"It was a failure to challenge our assumptions,\" Rowe responded. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniform presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there were going to be counter sniper teams in the AGR building, and I can assure you that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nThe Texas Tribune answering reader questions about 2024 elections. To share your question or feedback with us, you can fill out this form.\n\nThe full program is now LIVE for the 2024 Texas Tribune Festival, happening Sept. 5-7 in downtown Austin. Explore the program featuring more than 100 unforgettable conversations on topics covering education, the economy, Texas and national politics, criminal justice, the border, the 2024 elections and so much more. {"uri": "8252223309", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:18:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:18:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:17:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/news/state-regional/government-politics/grassley-communication-breakdown-trump-rally-shooting/article_2f8f5902-4eb5-11ef-ab46-bbfc2eb47f8e.html", "title": "Grassley cites 'communication breakdown' at Trump rally shooting", "body": "U.S. Sen. Chuck Grassley, R-Iowa, called for answers Tuesday over the \"communication breakdown\" between Pennsylvania law enforcement and the Secret Service that led to the assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee.\n\nText messages, police body camera footage and an after-action report obtained by Grassley provide the most detailed picture yet of security failures surrounding the shooting at the July 13 campaign rally in Butler, Pa.\n\nGrassley, appearing Tuesday on Fox News' \"America's Newsroom\" ahead of a Senate hearing with the FBI and Secret Service, said \"there's just a lot of shortcomings\" about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump.\n\n\"It's just bad when a member of Congress has to get his information from local law enforcement instead of from the federal agencies,\" Grassley said. \"(I've) turned over everything (I) have now, and if (I) get more, (I)'ll turn it over. I believe in transparency. The public's business ought to be public, and the protection of a presidential candidate ought to be a top priority.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... NEW DETAILS: Deere offers statement on severance package for salaried employees let go Wednesday in Waterloo Waterloo traffic cameras adjust ticket threshold by 1 mph Waterloo Christian School makes offer on old Cedar Falls High School 4-year-old boy escaped from cage in Iowa home; deputies found him covered in feces on street UPDATE: 69 John Deere Waterloo salaried employees let go Wednesday, 34 in Dubuque Waterloo man arrested for trying to run over women Waterloo man arrested following short chase Oelwein man dead in two-vehicle crash southwest of Hazleton West Lake Okoboji home sells for state record $9.5M Bremer Avenue bridge in Waverly to be demolished, closed for a year starting Thursday Olympics: Independence wrestling coaches will serve as volunteers at Paris Games Timeline: Deere has cut 2,700 jobs in 10 months in Iowa and Illinois 67 Johnston workers added to Deere layoffs list, bringing Iowa total to 170 this week Chased out of Buchanan County, Balance music festival coming to Waterloo John Deere idled more than 300 workers in Quad Cities on Wednesday, bringing last week's total to 489\n\nThe acting director of the Secret Service said Tuesday he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman was not secured, the Associated Press reported.\n\nRonald Rowe became acting director last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned amid mounting criticism by members of Congress over a lack of substantive answers during a hearing about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nRowe testified Tuesday before two Senate committees. He was joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees.\n\nGrassley pressed Rowe about the failed vetting and communications procedures that led to the near-assassination of the former president.\n\nRowe said he \"had no explanation\" for some of the Secret Service's shortcomings at the July 13 campaign rally, and committed to improving certain agency procedures and providing \"rolling\" updates to Congress and the public.\n\nGrassley also asked about the Secret Service and local law enforcement's use of a drone to monitor the rally location. In a letter last week asking for the Secret Service's operational plan and other records, Grassley included a document showing that a Counter Unmanned Aerial System operator was on the list of personnel for the rally.\n\nNBC News has reported that deceased gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks flew a drone over the rally site a few hours before Trump began speaking.\n\n\"According to the Secret Service, the drone system was supposed to be operational at 3 p.m. that day,\" Grassley said during his questioning of Rowe. \"However, we've been told by Secret Service that because of cellular bandwidth problems, it wasn't operational until about 5:20 (p.m.) on that day. If the system was operational, Secret Service would've had the ability to detect the shooter and his own drone use. Why is the Secret Service dependent upon local cellular networks? Does Secret Service have back up plans in place?\"\n\nRowe said the Secret Service's failure to detect the shooter's drone has \"cost me a lot of sleep.\" Had the Secret Service's platform been operational, Rowe noted, it might have been able to locate Crooks and intervene.\n\nRowe committed to leveraging Department of Homeland Security resources to provide the Secret Service guaranteed connectivity to its drone. He said the lapse \"is something that I have struggled with to understand.\"\n\n\"It is something that I feel as though we could have perhaps found him,\" he said. \"We could have maybe stopped him.\"\n\nAccording to documents released by Grassley's office, law enforcement officers knew of and communicated presence of Crooks, 20, of Bethel Park, Pa., at the rally to federal counterparts more than 90 minutes before he climbed onto a roof of what's known as the AGR Building and fired eight rounds toward Trump.\n\nBelow is a summary of local law enforcement's planning and communications regarding the Trump event, according to records released by Grassley's office:\n\nJuly 139 a.m.: The Butler County Emergency Response Unit hosts a briefing for local law enforcement ahead of the Trump event. The Secret Service was absent from the briefing.1:03 p.m.: Beaver, Butler and Washington County snipers connect via group chat.Local sniper locations are noted.4:26 p.m.: A Beaver County sniper finishes his shift and departs the AGR Building. While exiting, he spots Crooks at a picnic table outside and alerts the remaining Beaver and Butler snipers in the AGR Building to Crooks' presence.5:38 p.m.: A Beaver County sniper sends photos of Crooks to the Beaver, Butler and Washington snipers group chat. The Beaver sniper notes Crooks was using \"a range finder looking toward the stage\" and recommends that they notify Secret Service snipers to \"look out.\"5:45 p.m.: A Beaver County sniper sends photos of Crooks to the Beaver County ESU group chat. Beaver law enforcement recommends they alert \"command.\"\n\nGrassley underscored the need to pass legislation he introduced with Nevada Democratic U.S. Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto, which would subject Secret Service directors to Senate confirmation and a single, 10-year term.\n\n\"The Secret Service's core mission is to protect the individuals entrusted to its care,\" Grassley said in a statement. \"President Trump's brush with death was a Secret Service failure of epic proportions, and this mission failure must never be repeated.\"\n\nHe called the bill a \"crucial step toward providing the transparency and accountability that Congress and the American people deserve from the Secret Service.\"\n\nRelated It is the first time a member of the Secret Service will appear before Congress since the resignation of former chief Kimberly Cheatle earlier this month.\n\nThe Secret Service did not immediately respond to a request for Rowe's prepared remarks to the committees.\n\nRowe has assumed the helm of the Secret Service as elected officials and the public grow increasingly wary of the agency following the assassination attempt on former President Trump.\n\nRowe is now responsible for leading the more than 7,800 special agents, uniformed division officers and technical law enforcement officers, as well as administrative and technical staff.\n\nPrior to joining the Secret Service, Rowe was a member of the West Palm Beach Police Department in Florida. West Palm Beach Assistant Police Chief Tony Spatara told CBS 12 that Rowe is \"very intelligent\" and \"well-rounded.\"\n\n\"Knowing him personally, I am very proud he achieved his goal and then some in the Secret Service,\" Spatara said. \"Ron is a very intelligent person who is well-rounded, has a multitude of experience.\"\n\nTuesday's hearing comes after the FBI released new details regarding the investigation into the would-be presidential assassin, Thomas Matthew Crooks. The FBI told reporters on Monday that Crooks had a long-standing \"interest in science\" and \"experiments,\" and as a result, his family \"wasn't concerned\" about the myriad packages he was receiving at their house.\n\n\"The shooter had a long interest in science and things like this and had been doing experiments and things like that over a period of time,\" said Kevin Rojek, special agent in charge of the FBI's Pittsburgh Field Office. \"For that reason, [his family] wasn't concerned that [the packages] were focused on committing an attack of this nature of harming other people.\"\n\nCrooks, 20, made 25 gun-related purchases online between spring 2023 and the first half of this year, and bought materials used to make explosives six times, all with aliases, according to the agency.\n\nPresident Biden is now tasked with appointing a permanent head of the Secret Service. Biden wrote in a statement that he plans to make his choice \"soon.\"\n\n\"The independent review to get to the bottom of what happened on July 13 continues, and I look forward to assessing its conclusions. We all know what happened that day can never happen again,\" Biden wrote. \"As we move forward, I wish Kim all the best, and I will plan to appoint a new Director soon.\"\n\nFox News' Sarah {"uri": "8251034194", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:48:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:48:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:47:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://dailycaller.com/2024/07/30/secret-service-director-cost-sleep-trump-assassination-attempt/", "title": "Acting Secret Service Director Reveals What Has 'Cost' Him 'A Lot Of Sleep' With Trump Assassination Attempt", "body": "Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe Jr. disclosed on Tuesday that he has lost sleep over his agency not detecting the man who shot former President Donald Trump when he was flying a drone ahead of the assassination attempt.\n\nThomas Michael Crooks flew a drone over Trump's rally location in Butler, Pennsylvania, for 11 minutes near the former president's podium at around 3:50 PM, hours before he took the stage, according to The New York Times. Republican Iowa Sen. Chuck Grassley, during a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing, asked Rowe why the Secret Service did not have a system in place to track Crooks' drone, with the acting Secret Service director saying he has \"no explanation for it\" and that he has lost sleep over the issue. (RELATED: Security Had Reportedly Been Stationed On Rooftop Used By Trump Rally Shooter, But Abandoned It Due To 'Hot Weather')\n\n\"Secret Service deployed a counter, unmanned aerial system operator on July 13, according to the Secret Service. The drone system was supposed to be operational at 3:00 PM that day.\" Grassley said. \"However, we have been told by Secret Service that because of cellular bandwidth problems, it was not operational until about 5:20 of that day. If the system was operational, Secret Service would have had the ability to detect the shooter and his own drone use. Why is the Secret Service dependent upon local cellular network? Does the Secret Service have a backup plan in place?\"\n\n\"That is something ... that has cost me a lot of sleep because of the eventual outcome of the assailant, that what if we had geo-located him because that counter [unmanned aerial system] platform had been up? It is something that I have struggled with, to understand, and I have no explanation for it,\" Rowe said. \"It is something that I feel as though we could have perhaps found him. We could have maybe stopped him.\"\n\nCrooks killed former volunteer fire chief Corey Comperatore in the attack. He also injured two rally attendees and the former president.\n\n\"Maybe on that particular day he would have decided, this isn't the day to do it because law enforcement just found me flying my drone,\" Rowe continued. \"People fly drones all the time on the peripheries of our sites. And we go out, and we talk to them and ascertain what their intentions are.\"\n\nRowe added that the Secret Service will now be \"leveraging resources from the Department of Homeland Security and others to make sure we have dedicated connectivity so we are not reliant on public domain, so we can ensure whatever assets we have in place, those assets are operational.\"\n\nU.S. Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle recently resigned in the aftermath of the assassination attempt and her evasive testimony before Congress.\n\n\"I take full responsibility for the security lapse,\" Cheatle said in an email to staff obtained by the Associated Press. \"In light of recent events, it is with a heavy heart that I have made the difficult decision to step down as your director.\"\n\nAll content created by the Daily Caller News Foundation, an independent and nonpartisan newswire service, is available without charge to any legitimate news publisher that can provide a large audience. Mike Lee also went off on Rowe, recalling how the Secret Service let Trump take the stage 17 minutes after receiving reports of a suspicious person with a rangefinder and then didn't remove him from the stage when they learned that would-be assassin Thomas Crooks had a gun with him up on that unmanned roof.\n\nLee wasn't done yet, though. {"uri": "8251012741", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:32:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:32:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:32:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.thedailybeast.com/fbi-thomas-matthew-crooks-may-have-hid-antisemitic-anti-immigrant-social-page", "title": "FBI: Thomas Matthew Crooks May Have Hid Antisemitic, Anti-Immigrant Social Page", "body": "The FBI revealed Tuesday that Donald Trump's would-be assassin Thomas Matthew Crooks may have owned a social media account whose posts were antisemitic, anti-immigrant, and ultimately \"extreme in nature.\"\n\nFBI deputy director Paul Abbate did not say what social platform the account was active on, but he said it had pushed out hundreds of posts in 2019 and 2020. Support for political violence was among the posts, he said.\n\n\"There were over 700 comments posted from this account,\" said Abbate. \"Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature.\"\n\nAbbate testified that investigators have not determined a definitive motive behind the assassination attempt. However, he said agents are beginning to get a clearer picture of who Crooks, a 20-year-old who lived with his parents and worked at a nursing home, really was.\n\nDespite its ownership not being confirmed, Abbate said the agency felt it was important to detail the social account's nature because of the \"general absence of other information\" about Crooks' \"motive and mindset.\"\n\nThe comments come as lawmakers have pressed the Secret Service and FBI for answers about Crooks, who was shot dead within seconds of opening fire at a Trump rally on July 13.\n\nRonald Rowe, the Secret Service's acting director, testified Tuesday that he was \"ashamed\" by his agency's failures and was prepared to be candid about them. He said he visited the rally site in Pennsylvania after the attack and couldn't believe how clear of a shot -- from less than 400 feet -- Crooks was able to take at Trump.\n\n\"I laid in a prone position to evaluate his line of sight,\" Rowe said. \"What I saw made me ashamed. As a career law enforcement officer and a 25 year veteran with the Secret Service, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured to prevent similar lapses from occurring in the future.\"", {"uri": "8250624985", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "12:22:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T12:22:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T12:21:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.dailywire.com/news/senate-to-question-secret-service-fbi-about-attempted-trump-assassination", "title": "Senate To Question Secret Service, FBI About Attempted Trump Assassination", "body": "Top FBI and Secret Service officials will face questions from senators on Tuesday about the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump during a combined hearing in front of the Senate's Judiciary and Homeland Security committees.\n\nActing Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe and FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate will speak to lawmakers about the security failures that led to Trump nearly being assassinated during a campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, earlier this month. The two are expected to be questioned about how 20-year-old Thomas Mathew Crooks was able to access a rooftop within 150 yards of Trump and fire several shots at the former president.\n\nAbbate is also expected to give lawmakers an update on the FBI investigation into the attack, which injured Trump, two rally attendees, and killed 50-year-old Corey Comperatore.\n\nSen. Dick Durbin (D-IL), who heads up the Senate Judiciary Committee, said on Monday that the hearing would focus on the security lapses surrounding the incident.\n\n\"Despite the implementation of a security plan to secure the rally site on July 13, the shooter involved was able to fly a drone outside of the security perimeter for 11 minutes,\" Durbin said. \"His suspicious activity was reported twice, and he was spotted on the roof of a building prior to taking his first shot -- yet his violent plan continued unimpeded, and he was able to fire eight shots before a Secret Service countersniper killed him.\"\n\nText messages obtained by Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-IA) and shared with the New York Times show that Crooks was flagged by law enforcement as suspicious more than 90 minutes before he started shooting.\n\nSenator Roger Marshall (R-KS), who is on the Homeland Security committee, told The Daily Wire that security lapses occurred because Secret Service agents didn't work closely with local law enforcement.\n\n\"Time and time again, we see three letter agencies and their bureaucratic processes and political biases fail our communities,\" he told The Daily Wire. \"This is a top-down systemic failure and culture that's plaguing these agencies and must be addressed.\"\n\n\"The U.S. Secret Service team blew off Butler County local law enforcement, the officers who know this community the best- why is that?\" he asked. \"Would things be different today if communication and respect between local and D.C. officials was stronger?\"\n\nLawmakers in both the House and Senate have launched investigations into the attack. On Monday, the House named a task force to spearhead an inquiry. {"uri": "8251377052", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:35:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:35:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:34:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/news/state-regional/grassley-cites-communication-breakdown-at-trump-rally-shooting/article_6a5c8868-4eb8-11ef-b0f5-5bdc53e1a932.html", "title": "Grassley cites 'communication breakdown' at Trump rally shooting", "body": "Tom Barton Journal Des Moines Bureau\n\nIowa Republican U.S. Sen. Chuck Grassley called for answers Tuesday over the \"communication breakdown\" between Pennsylvania law enforcement and the Secret Service that led to the assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump, the 2024 Republican presidential nominee.\n\nText messages, police body camera footage and an after-action report obtained by Grassley provide the most detailed picture yet of security failures surrounding the shooting at the July 13 campaign rally in Butler, Pa.\n\nGrassley, appearing Tuesday on Fox News' \"America's Newsroom\" ahead of a Senate hearing with the FBI and Secret Service, said \"there's just a lot of shortcomings\" about law enforcement lapses in the hours before the attempted assassination of Trump.\n\n\"It's just bad when a member of Congress has to get his information from local law enforcement instead of from the federal agencies,\" Grassley said. \"(I've) turned over everything (I) have now, and if (I) get more, (I)'ll turn it over. I believe in transparency. The public's business ought to be public, and the protection of a presidential candidate ought to be a top priority.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Sierra signage going up at former Sioux City Bed Bath & Beyond North Sioux City crash kills one 4-year-old boy escaped from cage in Iowa home; deputies found him covered in feces on street Sioux City's Lyons Park getting $1.22 million in upgrades BNSF Railway wants to remove collapsed Big Sioux River train bridge Now streaming and on DVD: 'The Richmond Way' gives us the whole 'Ted Lasso' story Jason's Frozen Treats open second dine-in ice cream parlor Body found in Floyd River in Sioux City Sioux City driver charged with vehicular homicide from weekend crash Elk Point man killed in North Sioux City crash Wife of Dakota Dunes fatal stabbing suspect charged as an accessory Financial situation for McCook Lake residents still murky a month after flood State baseball: Scrapy dynamic duo sends Crusaders to state title game, down top seed Wahlert Woodbury County Court Report for July 22, 2024 Two dead following Sunday night two-vehicle accident in Sioux City's westside\n\nThe acting director of the Secret Service said Tuesday he \"cannot defend\" why the roof used by the gunman was not secured, the Associated Press reported.\n\nRonald Rowe became acting director last week after Kimberly Cheatle resigned amid mounting criticism by members of Congress over a lack of substantive answers during a hearing about the communication failures preceding the July 13 shooting.\n\nRowe testified Tuesday before two Senate committees. He was joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees.\n\nGrassley pressed Rowe about the failed vetting and communications procedures that led to the near-assassination of the former president.\n\nRowe said he \"had no explanation\" for some of the Secret Service's shortcomings at the July 13 campaign rally, and committed to improving certain agency procedures and providing \"rolling\" updates to Congress and the public.\n\nGrassley also asked about the Secret Service and local law enforcement's use of a drone to monitor the rally location. In a letter last week asking for the Secret Service's operational plan and other records, Grassley included a document showing that a Counter Unmanned Aerial System operator was on the list of personnel for the rally.\n\nNBC News has reported that deceased gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks flew a drone over the rally site a few hours before Trump began speaking.\n\n\"According to the Secret Service, the drone system was supposed to be operational at 3 p.m. that day,\" Grassley said during his questioning of Rowe. \"However, we've been told by Secret Service that because of cellular bandwidth problems, it wasn't operational until about 5:20 (p.m.) on that day. If the system was operational, Secret Service would've had the ability to detect the shooter and his own drone use. Why is the Secret Service dependent upon local cellular networks? Does Secret Service have back up plans in place?\"\n\nRowe said the Secret Service's failure to detect the shooter's drone has \"cost me a lot of sleep.\" Had the Secret Service's platform been operational, Rowe noted, it might have been able to locate Crooks and intervene.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nRowe committed to leveraging Department of Homeland Security resources to provide the Secret Service guaranteed connectivity to its drone. He said the lapse \"is something that I have struggled with to understand.\"\n\n\"It is something that I feel as though we could have perhaps found him,\" he said. \"We could have maybe stopped him.\"\n\nAccording to documents released by Grassley's office, law enforcement officers knew of and communicated presence of Crooks, 20, of Bethel Park, Pa., at the rally to federal counterparts more than 90 minutes before he climbed onto a roof of what's known as the AGR Building and fired eight rounds toward Trump.\n\nBelow is a summary of local law enforcement's planning and communications regarding the Trump event, according to records released by Grassley's office:\n\nJuly 13\n\n9 a.m.: The Butler County Emergency Response Unit hosts a briefing for local law enforcement ahead of the Trump event. The Secret Service was absent from the briefing\n\n1:03 p.m.: Beaver, Butler and Washington County snipers connect via group chat\n\nLocal sniper locations are noted\n\n4:26 p.m.: A Beaver County sniper finishes his shift and departs the AGR Building. While exiting, he spots Crooks at a picnic table outside and alerts the remaining Beaver and Butler snipers in the AGR Building to Crooks' presence\n\n5:38 p.m.: A Beaver County sniper sends photos of Crooks to the Beaver, Butler and Washington snipers group chat. The Beaver sniper notes Crooks was using \"a range finder looking toward the stage\" and recommends that they notify Secret Service snipers to \"look out\"\n\n5:45 p.m.: A Beaver County sniper sends photos of Crooks to the Beaver County ESU group chat. Beaver law enforcement recommends they alert \"command\"\n\nGrassley underscored the need to pass legislation he introduced with Nevada Democratic U.S. Sen. Catherine Cortez Masto, which would subject Secret Service directors to Senate confirmation and a single, 10-year term.\n\n\"The Secret Service's core mission is to protect the individuals entrusted to its care,\" Grassley said in a statement. \"President Trump's brush with death was a Secret Service failure of epic proportions, and this mission failure must never be repeated.\"\n\nHe called the bill a \"crucial step toward providing the transparency and accountability that Congress and the American people deserve from the Secret Service.\"\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry attempt in latest hearing", "body": "Secret Service and FBI officials are testifying in the congressional hearings dedicated to the assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump on July 13.\n\nSenate legislators are expected Tuesday to question Ronald Rowe, the acting director of the Secret Service, regarding law enforcement lapses in the hours before the incident.\n\nRELATED: Trump was struck by a bullet during assassination attempt, FBI says\n\nLast week, Rowe became acting director of the agency after Kimberly Cheatle resigned following a House hearing where she was questioned by legislators and didn't answer questions regarding communication failures before the shooting earlier this month.\n\nRowe will be joined by FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate at a joint hearing of the Senate committees on the Judiciary and Homeland Security.\n\nRELATED: Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigns after Trump assassination attempt\n\nAccording to the Associated Press, the hearing comes a day after the FBI released new details about the probe into the shooting, stating that the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, searched online for information about mass shootings, power plants, explosive devices, and the May assassination attempt of the Slovakian prime minister.\n\nThe FBI told the AP that Trump has agreed to be interviewed by agents as a crime victim.\n\nText messages reveal that authorities responsible for monitoring former President Trump's Pennsylvania rally spotted his would-be assassin and flagged him to colleagues as suspicious at least 90 minutes before he opened fire.\n\nThe messages, obtained by Fox News Digital from Sen. Chuck Grassley, R-Iowa, who obtained them from Beaver County Emergency Services Unit (ESU), showed that officers flagged Thomas Matthew Crooks after he was spotted using a range finder - but did not approach him.\n\nAccording to FOX News, the first screenshot is a group chat of Beaver ESU officers, while the second is from one Beaver County sniper departing his shift at around 4:30 - approximately 90 minutes before Trump took the stage. The New York Times first reported the text screenshots.\n\nKimberly Cheatle was called to testify in Congress more than a week after the shooting.\n\nShe called the attempt on Trump's life the Secret Service's \"most significant operational failure\" in decades, and vowed to \"move heaven and earth\" to get to the bottom of what went wrong and make sure there's no repeat of it.\n\nDemocrats and Republicans were united in their exasperation as Cheatle said she didn't know or couldn't answer numerous questions more than a week after the shooting that left one spectator dead. At one point, Mace used profanity as she accused Cheatle of lying and dodging questions, prompting calls for lawmakers to show \"decorum.\"\n\nLawmakers pressed Cheatle on how the shooter could get so close to the Republican presidential nominee when he was supposed to be carefully guarded, and why Trump was allowed to take the stage after local law enforcement had identified Crooks as suspicious.\n\nDonald Trump survived the assassination attempt before he was whisked off the stage at a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, when gunshots rang through the crowd on July 13.\n\nThe former president and Republican nominee was showing off a chart of border crossing numbers when the sound of gunfire started ringing through the crowd. Trump could be seen reaching with his right hand toward his neck, and there appeared to be blood on his face.\n\nHe quickly ducked behind the riser as agents from his protective detail rushed the stage and screams were heard in the crowd of several thousand people. Josh Hawley and Acting Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe during a hearing on the attempted assassination of former president Donald Trump.\n\nIn a heated exchange during a joint hearing by the Senate Judiciary and Governmental Affairs committees on the July 13 assassination attempt, Hawley criticized Rowe for not firing those involved in security decisions.\n\nRowe said the investigations remain ongoing \"into the failures\" on that day and stated loudly that he would \"not rush to judgment.\"\n\n\"People will be held accountable,\" said Rowe.\n\nLater, the senator asked: \"Is it not prima fascia that somebody has failed? The former president was shot.\"\n\n\"Sir, this could have been our Texas School Book Depository,\" Rowe responded. \"I have lost sleep over that for the last 17 days, just like you have.\"\n\n\"Then fire somebody,\" Hawley responded.\n\nRowe reiterated that he would not rush to judgment and unfairly persecute individuals, adding that there must be a proper investigation into the assassination.\n\nAnother heated exchange came from Republican Sen. Ted Cruz, regarding the number of agents protecting Trump, asking why the former president does not get the same number of agents as President Joe Biden.\n\n\"There is a difference between the sitting President of the United States,\" Rowe responded.\n\n\"Then what's the difference,\" shouted Cruz.\n\n\"The difference, national command authority to launch a nuclear strike, sir,\" Rowe said in response. \"There are other assets that travel with the president that the former president will not get.\"\n\nCruz later accused the agency of making a \"political decision\" by denying requests or inquiring about the security the former president is receiving.\n\nRowe denied the claim, saying: \"What I will tell you is that Secret Service agents are not political.\"\n\nThomas Matthew Crooks, a Trump on Saturday, July 13, 2024, in Butler, Pennsylvania, was a failure on multiple levels,\" he began.\n\nAfter giving credit to members of the Secret Service who leaped in to keep Trump safe, as well as the sniper team that killed assailant Thomas Crooks, Rowe detailed what he believed went wrong in securing the location where the former president was speaking.\n\nREAD MORE: Mike Johnson's now-deleted Trump social media post sparks controversy\n\n\"Since my appointment as the acting director one week ago, I identified gaps in our security on July 13 and have implemented corrective actions,\" he said. \"One of my first actions as acting director was traveling to the Butler farm site to better understand how our protection failed.\n\n\"I went to the roof of the AGR building where the assailant fired shots and I laid in a prone position to evaluate his line of sight. officer had climbed onto the roof and spotted the suspect with a rifle 30 seconds before shots were fired.\n\nWhile a motive has yet to be established, members of Congress heard that the FBI has now uncovered a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman.\n\nPaul Abbate, deputy director of the FBI, said: \"There were over 700 comments posted from this account.\n\n\"These leading figure in the United States.\n\n\"But how does that match the reality... when a 20-year-old introverted college student outsmarted one of the most sophisticated American law enforcement agencies in history and came within an inch of killing a former president of the United States?\" he asked.\n\nMs Cheatle, who described it as \"the most significant operational failure in decades\", {"uri": "8251267431", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:00:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:00:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:59:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.fox5dc.com/news/trump-assassination-attempt-senators-grill-secret-services-communication-drone-failures-butler", "title": "Trump assassination attempt: Senators grill the Secret Service's communication and drone failures in Butler", "body": "WASHINGTON - The head of the U.S. Secret Service and FBI were grilled by Senators about the attempted assassination of former President Trump at a campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nMembers of the Senate Judiciary Committee and the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee questioned FBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate and Secret Service Acting Director Ronald Rowe on the security failures that took place on July 13th.\n\n\"I am still shocked how a 20-year-old loner could outsmart two of the most established federal agencies. And almost pull it off,\" Senator Tom Carper said, summing up what many in the room were thinking.\n\nOne of the major flaws discussed: the Secret Service's drone was not operational at the rally site.\n\nThe acting director attributed the drone issues to the rocky cell service in the area surrounding the rally.\n\n\"Communication that day at the Butler rally site was challenging,\" Rowe said. \"This day, in particular, there was a connectivity problem.\"\n\n\"Faulty connectivity\" kept the Secret Service's drone out of operation until 5 pm. Senator Mike Lee from Utah explicitly asked Rowe why the shooter's drone could fly despite poor service, but the Secret Service's drone did not. Rowe could provide an answer.\n\nIf the drone was active and surveying the rally grounds, it would have detected the shooter's drone and alerted the Secret Service of the potential threat.\n\n\"We could have perhaps found him,\" Rowe said. \"Maybe even stopped him before.\"\n\nSenator Chuck Grassley of Iowa expressed serious concern about why such an advanced federal agency depends on local cell service.\n\nOther grave flaws were picked apart by Senators, including the communication and planning between local law enforcement and the Secret Service.\n\n\"We did have a meeting in the days leading up to the event to assess any potential threats. The focus is to coordinate times for walk-throughs. Those walk-through assessments of the Butler site did happen,\" Abbate said.\n\nLocal law enforcement was stationed inside of the AGR building which Crooks climbed on top of. A whistleblower claimed that police were supposed to be stationed on the roof of the building, but it got too hot and they went down. Rowe said he heard the same claims but did not confirm it.\n\nSenator Lee asked Rowe why local law enforcement officers covered the AGR building, a location that should have been covered by the Secret Service when the individuals did not meet the qualifications to work for the agency. Lee emphasized that a decision like this is \"lethal.\"\n\nRowe stated that information about an active shooter \"stayed within state and local enforcement and did not get passed to the Secret Service.\" This raised many questions in the Senate about whether any communication mechanisms exist to connect all layers of security at these kinds of events.\n\nQuestions spiraled among the Senate regarding why the shooter's use of a range finder did not alter his classification from just a suspicious person to a serious threat.\n\nRowe argued that \"a suspicious person turns to a threat when there is a weapon involved.\" Ignoring the suspicion that a range finder would only have been useful to someone who had a weapon and planned to use it.\n\nSenators criticized the secrecy of the Secret Service and suggested they speak directly to the press to avoid conspiracies and the spread of false information. They argued for more frequent and public information releases.\n\n\"You guys are a black hole,\" said Senator Ted Cruz. \"You're making the federal government look bad, and you're losing the trust of the American people. You need to commit to talking to the press.\"\n\nSenator Ron Johnson said that the transparency of the July 13th events will be unveiled to the public.\n\n\"We need to find out literally second by second what happened, so the American public knows what happened,\" said Johnson.", "source": {"uri": "fox5dc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX 5 DC"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8250034401", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "06:08:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T06:08:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T06:07:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.ntd.com/acting-secret-service-chief-faces-congress-over-trump-security-failures_1007740.html", "title": "Acting Secret Service Chief Faces Congress Over Trump Security Failures", "body": "Former President Donald Trump with blood on his face surrounded by secret service agents as he is taken off the stage at a campaign event in Butler, Pa., on July 13, 2024. (Rebecca Droke/AFP via Getty Images)\n\nThe acting Secret Service director will face lawmakers for the first time Tuesday to testify about security failures that led up to the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump.\n\nThe Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs committees are set to convene the joint hearing at 10 a.m. ET.\n\nActing U.S. Secret Service Director Ronald Rowe is expected to offer more details about the communications with other law enforcement agencies and security arrangements made during the former president's campaign rally on July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nMr. Rowe is serving as interim chief of the Secret Service after Kimberly Cheatle stepped down as head of the agency. She resigned shortly after her testimony before the House Oversight and Accountability Committee, in which she frustrated lawmakers by repeatedly saying she would not answer questions before the FBI's investigation was complete.\n\nMr. Rowe started his career with the Secret Service in 1999. He previously served as a police officer in West Palm Beach, Florida.\n\nDuring his 25-year career with the Secret Service, he \"coordinated major security operations, collaborating with other government and law-enforcement agencies,\" according to his biography.\n\nFBI Deputy Director Paul Abbate is also expected to testify to provide an update on the FBI's probe into the assassination attempt. This comes after FBI Director Christopher Wray testified last week before the House Judiciary Committee. Mr. Wray revealed details about the gunman's actions leading up to the July 13 shooting in Pennsylvania.\n\nIn a speech on Monday from the Senate floor, U.S. Senate Majority Whip Dick Durbin (D-Ill.), Chair of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said Americans still need answers and hopes more information will be revealed in Tuesday's joint oversight hearing.\n\n\"There is an urgent need for bipartisan collaboration in Congress to provide these answers to the American people as soon as possible so that the Secret Service can begin to rebuild trust and more effectively fulfill its mission,\" Mr. Durbin said.\n\n\"The work has already begun, and tomorrow's joint hearing will help bring about transparency and accountability for Secret Service failures in Butler on July 13.\"\n\nMeanwhile, House leaders on Monday announced members of a bipartisan task force to investigate the shooting and make recommendations to prevent such an attack from happening again. The task force, which will have subpoena authority, is composed of seven Republicans and six Democrats. House Speaker Mike Johnson and Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries chose the members.\n\nA motive for the July 13 shooting remains unclear. In addition to former President Trump, two others were wounded, and one person was killed that day.", "source": {"uri": "ntd.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NTD"}, "authors": [], "concepts": Hassan presses acting Secret Service head over protection of Trump on July 13", "body": "A rally attendee was killed and two others were critically injured after they were struck by bullets from the AR-15-style rifle that Crooks fired at Trump.\n\nAbbate confirmed Trump was stuck in the right ear by a bullet, correcting the speculation of FBI Director Christopher Wray, who late last week said Trump could have been struck by shrapnel.\n\n\"On July 13, major failures nearly led to the assassination of a presidential candidate who is also a former president of the United States,\" Hassan said at the hearing.\n\n\"The Secret Service has to be fully transparent about how this happened and how it's going to change moving forward.\"\n\nFBI officials said Crooks flew a drone over the property for about 11 minutes from 3:50 p.m. to around 4 p.m. that afternoon.\n\nRowe said the Secret Service's counter-drone system had \"technical difficulties\" and didn't work that day until after 5 p.m. At 6:11 p.m., Crooks began shooting.\n\nHassan asked if there was backup, anti-drone technology that could have been deployed.\n\n\"We are working to determine that right now, getting the redundancies in place,\" Rowe responded. He told the senators the Secret Service has the technology to take down another drone.\n\nRepublican members on the committee urged Rowe to complete the agency's internal probe and hold those responsible accountable for the failures.\n\n\"Sir, this could have been our Texas School Book Depository,\" Rowe responded, referring to the 1963 assassination of then-President John F. Kennedy in Dallas, Texas.\n\n\"I have lost sleep over that for the last 17 days, just like you have.\"\n\n\"Then fire somebody,\" responded Sen. {"uri": "8252041765", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:32:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:32:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:25:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/secret-service-chief-says-hes-ashamed/article_06dd8f9c-885d-5515-a656-b5f820b6536f.html", "title": "SECRET SERVICE CHIEF SAYS HE'S 'ASHAMED'", "body": "FARNOUSH AMIRI, REBECCA SANTANA, ERIC TUCKER AND CLAUDIA LAUER\n\nAssociated Press FARNOUSH AMIRI, REBECCA SANTANA, ERIC TUCKER AND CLAUDIA LAUER\n\nAssociated Press\n\nTRUMP SHOOTING\n\nWASHINGTON -- The Secret Service's acting director told lawmakers Tuesday he considered it indefensible that the roof used by the gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump was unsecured and said it was regrettable that local law enforcement didn't communicate to his agency that a gunman was spotted on a nearby roof.\n\nRonald Rowe also testified that he recently visited the shooting site and laid down on the roof of the building where shots were fired to evaluate the gunman's line of sight during the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"What I saw made me ashamed. As a career law enforcement officer and a 25-year Secret Service veteran, I cannot defend why that roof was not better secured,\" he said.\n\nThe testimony was the most detailed catalogue to date by the Secret Service of law enforcement failings and miscommunications, with Ronald Rowe accepting blame for his own agency's mistakes while also criticizing local law enforcement for not sharing information that a gunman, later identified as Thomas Matthew Crooks, 20, was spotted on a roof of a building less than 150 yards from the rally stage where Trump spoke.\n\nPeople are also reading... Homeless and dying: La Crosse veteran diagnosed with heart failure finds peace in final weeks Onalaska man faces felony charge after injury hit-and-run in La Crosse Mayo Clinic likely to demolish 94-year-old St. Francis Hospital building after opening new La Crosse facility Steve Cahalan: City panel to review plans for new Starbucks at Valley View Mall New building plans unveiled, along with TIF agreement at La Crosse's $300M River Point District project UPDATE: New public hearing date set to discuss overnight unsheltered sleeping areas in La Crosse La Crosse County examines large affordable housing development in West Salem with nearly 600 units La Crosse man faces charges for driving under the influence of marijuana Man accused of OWI while pulling camper containing 9 kids, Wisconsin State Patrol says Complaint says La Crosse man assaulted with sheathed machete during 'school yard brawl' on lawn New retreat house for pilgrims and visitors at Shrine of Our Lady Guadalupe would house up to 66 guests Steve Cahalan: LAX Grille opens, Pastissimo is leaving and Ichiddo Ramen is coming to La Crosse Steve Cahalan: Candle maker adds to number of woman-owned shops in downtown Galesville John Paul Gillespie Daylong standoff ends with arrest of man who shot Sauk County deputy, authorities say\n\n\"Neither the Secret Service counter-sniper teams nor members of the former president's security detail had any knowledge that there was a man on the roof of the building with a firearm,\" Rowe said. \"It is my understanding those personnel were not aware the assailant had a firearm until they heard gunshots.\"\n\nHe said the shooting amounted to a \"failure on multiple levels,\" including a failure of imagination and a \"failure to challenge our assumptions.\"\n\n\"We assumed that the state and locals had it,\" Rowe said. \"We made an assumption that there was going to be uniformed presence out there, that there would be sufficient eyes to cover that, that there was going to be counter-sniper teams\" in the building from whose roof Crooks fired shots.\n\n\"And I can assure you,\" Rowe added, \"that we're not going to make that mistake again.\"\n\nHe said he implemented reforms since taking over as acting director last week, including mandating that every event security plan is vetted by multiple experienced supervisors before being implemented, expanding the use of aerial drones to improve visibility of roofs and dedicating more resources to improve communications at events where the Secret Service operates.\n\nTrump, now the 2024 Republican presidential nominee, was struck in the ear by a bullet or a bullet fragment in the assassination attempt, one rallygoer was killed and two others were injured before a Secret Service counter-sniper shot and killed the gunman.\n\nThe blunt and at times emotional testimony Tuesday, featuring combative exchanges with lawmakers, ensured that an already simmering blame game between federal and local authorities will continue.\n\nIt also suggested Rowe, with ready and generally detailed answers, was determined to strike a different posture than that of his predecessor, Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned last week after facing intense criticism from lawmakers after responses at a congressional hearing that were seen as evasive and lacking in specifics.\n\nTuesday's hearing before the Senate Judiciary and Homeland Security committees was the latest in a series of congressional sessions dedicated to the law enforcement lapses and missed communications that preceded the shooting.\n\nLocal law enforcement officers first observed a suspicious-looking man at the rally site more than an hour before the event and circulated that information, including photographs of a man who turned out to be Crooks.\n\nThe officers ultimately lost track of Crooks, who scaled the roof of a building at AGR International Inc., a supplier of automation equipment for the glass and plastic packaging industry, and fired an estimated eight shots with an AR-15-style rife.\n\nShortly before the shooting, a local officer climbed up to the roof to investigate. Crooks turned and pointed his rifle at the officer, who retreated.\n\nEven though text messages among local snipers revealed anxiety about the man, Rowe said the only thing the Secret Service knew at the time of the shooting was that law enforcement was contending with a suspicious-looking man.\n\n\"No information regarding a weapon on a roof was ever passed to our personnel,\" Rowe said. At another point, he noted, \"It is troubling to me that we did not get that information as quickly as we should have. We didn't know that there was this incident going on.\"\n\nBut Rowe's willingness to assign blame to local law enforcement opened him up to harsh criticism from Senate Republicans, who saw him as failing to take sufficient responsibility.\n\n\"Isn't the fact that a former president was shot, that a good American is dead, that other Americans were critically wounded -- isn't that enough mission failure for you to say to the person who decided that that building should not be in the security perimeter, probably ought to be stepped down?\" said Sen. Josh Hawley, a Missouri Republican.\n\nRowe, raising his voice, responded that he has \"lost sleep over this for the last 17 days\" and that he would not be rushed \"to judgment\" by Congress. He assured lawmakers that \"people will be held accountable.\"\n\nThe FBI, meanwhile, disclosed new details about Crooks, with Deputy Director Paul Abbate saying a social media account believed to be associated with the gunman suspected in the assassination attempt espoused political violence and included antisemitic and anti-immigrant sentiment.\n\nThe posts were from the 20192020 timeframe, when Crooks would have been in high school.\n\nAbbate did not identify the social media platform, saying investigators were still trying to definitively determine that it belonged to Crooks. However, he indicated that it was separate from an account on a different platform called Gab that was active in 2021.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news {"uri": "8251008638", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:32:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:32:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:29:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/fbi-thomas-matthew-crooks-may-162801971.html", "title": "FBI: Thomas Matthew Crooks May Have Hid Antisemitic, Anti-Immigrant Social Page", "body": "The FBI revealed Tuesday that Donald Trump's would-be assassin Thomas Matthew Crooks may have owned a social media account whose posts were antisemitic, anti-immigrant, and ultimately \"extreme in nature.\"\n\nFBI deputy director Paul Abbate did not say what social platform the account was active on, but he said it had pushed out hundreds of posts in 2019 and 2020. Support for political violence was among the posts, he said.\n\n\"There were over 700 comments posted from this account,\" said Abbate. \"Some of these comments, if ultimately attributable to the shooter, appear to reflect antisemitic and anti-immigration themes to espouse political violence and are described as extreme in nature.\"\n\nAbbate testified that investigators have not determined a definitive motive behind the assassination attempt. However, he said agents are beginning to get a clearer picture of who Crooks, a 20-year-old who lived with his parents and worked at a nursing home, really was.\n\nTexts Show How Officers Lost Track of Trump Gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks\n\nDespite its ownership not being confirmed, Abbate said the agency felt it was important to detail the social account's nature because of the \"general absence of other information\" about Crooks' \"motive and mindset.\"\n\nThe comments come as lawmakers have pressed the Secret Service and FBI for answers about Crooks, who was shot dead within seconds of opening fire at a Trump rally on July 13.\n\nRonald Rowe, the Secret Service's acting director, testified Tuesday that he was \"ashamed\" by his agency's failures and was prepared to be candid about them. He said he visited the rally site in Pennsylvania after the attack and couldn't believe how clear of a shot -- from less than 400 feet -- Crooks was able to take at Trump.\n\n\"I laid in a prone position to evaluate his line of sight,\" Rowe said. \"What I saw made me ashamed.
